title: Free speech legal supremacy Dominic Raab unveils plan stop democratic debate
story: Share this article Harry Potter author JK Rowling and other public figures have been vilified for voicing concerns over an erosion of womenâ€™s rights by the transgender lobby, for example.Only this week, the creator of comedy series Father Ted Graham Linehan declared that he had been â€˜thoroughly cancelledâ€™ and that trans activists had cost him his family and his marriage. Recent years have seen cancel culture extend across society, with growing numbers attacked in public life, on university campuses and on social media for expressing their views.The author Jacqueline Wilson recently compared â€˜scaryâ€™ cancel culture to â€˜walking a tightropeâ€™.Yesterday, Vladimir Putin tried to use the issue to score political points, suggesting the West was trying to â€˜cancelâ€™ Russia in the same way some have with JK Rowling.Mr Raab told the Mail that under plans being drawn up for the Bill of Rights, there would be only very limited restrictions placed on the new over-arching protections on free speech.He said it would be given a â€˜different status in the pecking order of rightsâ€™, with checks to stop people abusing it to promote terrorism.Although the main impact of this will be on legal disputes, ministers believe that placing such a heavy emphasis on free speech is likely to have an effect beyond the courts and could help iniduals trying to push back against cancel culture.Mr Raab said: â€˜We will still be clamping down on those who try and use either media or free speech to incite violence, to radicalise terrorists, or to threaten children. All of those safeguards will be in place.â€˜But weâ€™ve got to be able to strengthen free speech, the liberty that guards all of our other freedoms, and stop it being whittled away surreptitiously, sometimes without us really being conscious of it.â€˜So it will have a different status in the pecking order of rights and I think that will go a long way to protecting this countryâ€™s freedom of speech and our history, which has always very strongly protected freedom of speech.â€™The Human Rights Act was introduced by Tony Blairâ€™s Labour government 20 years ago, and Tory ministers believe it is ripe for reform.Â

title: england v bangladesh womens cricket world cup live
story: England will go through with a win. How they do it, net run-rate wise could affect who they end up playing in the semis, with obviously Australia the side to avoid. Whoever finishes in fourth place will face Meg Lanning and co. At the moment it could be England, India or, if one of those two lose today, West Indies. Speaking of Nasser...Itâ€™s been a topsy-turvy campaign by England. They were gaping down the barrel of an early World Cup Exit after three defeats at the start of the tournament, ever since then itâ€™s been pressure on - effectively playing elimination cricket in every match since.  Heather Knight will be desperately hoping that her sideâ€™s 2022 World Cup journey in New Zealand continues to go the way of the tortoise and the hare. That their ugly duckling early performances of dropped catches and wayward bowling continue to transform into something swan-like as the competition reaches the sharp end. Lose against Bangladesh today though and it will be Goodnight, Moon.  The signs are promising, some of those who had been having a â€˜quieterâ€™ time of it have stepped up. Danni Wyatt was in the runs and Katherine Brunt the wickets in the defeat of Pakistan. Kate Cross, Sophie Ecclestone, Nat Sciver and Sophia Dunkley have all performed consistently, so to the skipper herself.  â€œEveryone is peaking at the right time going into this game and then hopefully the semi-finalsâ€¦ itâ€™s not how you start, itâ€™s how you finish,â€ declared opener Tammy Beaumont in the run up to todayâ€™s match at the Basin Reserve in Wellington.  They wonâ€™t be taking Bangladesh lightly. Nigar Sultanaâ€™s side have beaten Pakistan and pushed both West Indies and India close. They nearly pulled off the shock of the tournament at a blustery Basin Reserve just a couple of days ago, reducing the unbeaten Aussies to 70-5 chasing a tricksy target of 135. If theyâ€™d been more proactive with the bat earlier on the piece then they could have pulled off a spectacular upset. They have a spin contingent that could damage England, especially with all the pressure on pale blue shoulders. I predict a bum-squeaker.  Play starts at 10pm GMT11 AM local time. Jim here with the call for the first half before Tanya takes over in the wee small hours. Iâ€™ll be back shortly with news of the toss and the teams. As ever do get in touch with your musings and mirth. You can whang me an email or fling me a tweet.

title: michael viney why secret of everlasting youth might lie in bats
story: The lesser horseshoe bat, now numbering some 13,000 iniduals, leads the nine resident Irish bats described in a new identification guide. Illustration: Michael VineyThe little corpse at the edge of the path was the merest scrap of fur with a squiggle of a tail. To come upon it at the back end of winter was no great surprise. Irelandâ€™s smallest mammal, the pygmy shrew, has a frantic, insect-munching lifestyle that rarely lasts much longer than 13 months.Compare that with the common pipistrelle, the tiny bat of so many Irish roof spaces. Its body size, at the heart of those flickering wings, is much the same as the shrew â€“ it will, as one scientist friend put it, â€œfit on the end of your thumbâ€. Its feeding schedule, too, can be hectic: as much as 3,500 insects in one night. But the pipistrelle may live as long as 15 years.The extreme longevity of bats seems to counter the rule that bigger animals live longer. Of the 19 mammals that live longer than humans, all but one are bats. This has led one Irish geneticist to a line of research that now has a keen global following.Deep in the DNA that gives bats their longevity, hopes Prof Emma Teeling of Trinity College Dublin, â€œmay lie the secret of everlasting youthâ€.In 2012, this conclusion startled a 2,000-strong Dublin audience at a TED Talk about the evolutionary characteristics of bats. Since then, in research that warranted the cover of Nature, she and the team at her Trinity â€œBat Labâ€ have been exploring the bat genome that gives them their â€œunique and peculiar adaptationsâ€.Forty-two yearsA key species for the research, with blood sampled at roosts in a village in Brittany, has been the greater mouse-eared bat, Myotis myotis. It lives as long as 37 years. Another species, Brandtâ€™s bat, a vagrant visitor to Ireland, sets the record at 42 years.With more than 1,400 species identified so far, bats make up a fifth of the worldâ€™s mammals. Their consumption of flying insects (in annual thousands of tonnes) and pollination of many tropical fruits make them vital to the planetâ€™s ecosystems.Of possibly huge importance to humans, bat DNA gives the animals a unique immune system and longevity. It tolerates viruses toxic to people and other mammals. It may also hold genes secure against blindness and deafness. The chance of insights into such woes of human ageing is the big drive to research.It also makes even more absurd the common human attitudes to bats. Born within a parish or two of Bram Stoker, Teeling forgives the vampire narratives. And the generous flow of fair hair around her shoulders disdains another cultural myth.The nonsense about bats entangled in womenâ€™s hair particularly incensed Prof James Fairley, now long retired from NUI Galway to his native Belfast. In the 1980s, as Europeâ€™s zoologists were sounding alarm on the wide decline of bats, Fairley launched a wave of student interest in Irelandâ€™s species and enthusiastic research by a group of young women.ThreatenedAmong them was Dr Kate McAney, later cofounder of Bat Conservation Ireland (BCI) and head of Irish conservation for the UK-based Vincent Wildlife Trust. Her special concern was for the welfare of the threatened lesser horseshoe bat, for whom roosts in caves, old farm buildings and big-house attics of Irelandâ€™s western seaboard have been an important refuge.The hibernating bat in my drawing was hanging from the wall of an old mine shaft on a Connemara hillside, to which McAney had guided me. The lesser horseshoe, now numbering some 13,000 iniduals, leads the nine resident Irish bats described in a new identification guide published by the National Bioersity Data Centre and the BCI.Prepared by Niamh Roche and Andrew Torsney and well-crafted for the pocket, it pictures key features of animals held in the hand and gives sonograms of their calls as recorded on bat detectors.The echolocation calls of night-flying bats are pitched too high for human hearing and have to be tuned in, as to a radio station. The booklet offers downloadable, distinctive sound files for each species and a commentary offers much field experience.The brown bat, for example, is nicknamed the whispering bat and â€œcan usually only be detected within 5m to 8mâ€, whereas the call of Leislerâ€™s bat â€œsounds like chi-chi-chi-chop-chop when tuned in at 25Hzâ€.Yearly trendsWith funding from the National Parks and Wildlife Service, a cross-border Centre for Irish Bat Research studies three rare woodland bats.d BCI volunteers have tracked yearly trends in key species since 2003.All seem to be stable or increasing, despite loss of traditional roosts and hedgerows. Newer threats come from the spread of over-intense LED lighting and wind farm development.The first Irish research into the impact of wind turbines on bat populations, involving years of fieldwork, launched Dr Una Nealon as yet another woman expert in chiropterology.

title: checks for non irish entering ni says brandon lewis
story: Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney and Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis met under the auspices of the British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference at Farmleigh House in Dublin. Photograph: PA Proposals that would see non-Irish people forced to get an electronic visa waiver before crossing the border are not yet finalised as far as the Government is conerned, Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney has said.Speaking following talks with Northern secretary Brandon Lewis in Dublin on Wednesday, Mr Coveney said the proposals were still in the legislative process in the UK and that Ireland would continue making representations on the issue.â€œI think it is important to say that this is not legislation that is finalised yet, there was a vote in the House of Commons last night but my understanding is this is likely to go back to the Lords and back to the Commons again,â€ he said.â€œWhat we have looked for here is an exemption for any non-Irish or British nationals who are resident in Ireland to be able to cross without having to get an ETA (Electronic Travel Authorisation), but as I say, thatâ€™s an ongoing conversation and as far as weâ€™re concerned, that legislative process hasnâ€™t concluded yet.â€MPs at Westminster on Tuesday night voted to reinstate the requirement of a US-style visa waiver for non-Irish EU citizens crossing the Border as part of the proposed regime. The British government challenged an amendment introduced in the House of Lords, which would have exempted Northern Ireland from the legislation. Mr Coveney â€“ who met Mr Lewis under the auspices of the British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference at Farmleigh House in Dublin â€“ said on Tuesday night following the Commonsâ€™ vote that the Irish position had been â€œignoredâ€.He said that since the peace process was agreed, the relationship between North and South â€œhas been based on uninterrupted travel opportunities and movement of people and we think thatâ€™s worth protectingâ€. â€œNorthern Ireland, and the island of Ireland in terms of the relationships between North and South, is a very unusual construct and series of relationships and treaties and agreements,â€ he said, adding that it was â€œnot for the first time weâ€™ll be asking for special treatment to try to protect that relationshipâ€. Mr Lewis said the decision to move ahead with the ETA legislation had nothing to do with reported concerns in the British government about whether Ukrainian refugees could cross into the UK. The plan had been in development for years and was â€œcompletely separateâ€ to the Ukraine crisis, he said. The measure could affect as many as 645,000 non-Irish nationals living in the Republic - almost 13 per cent of the population, which will increase again with the arrival of Ukrainians fleeing the invasion by Russia. Sinn FÃ©in reactionSpeaking in the DÃ¡il, Sinn FÃ©in leader Mary Lou McDonald said the proposal would create â€œa disgraceful situationâ€ which undermined the Belfast Agreement and Common Travel Area. â€œIt creates significant restrictions on freedom of movement across our island,â€ she said. Ms McDonald said she found it â€œwholly unacceptableâ€ for a Polish person who lived and worked in Lifford, Co Donegal, would need papers to travel to Strabane, Co Tyrone, and that this was the reality â€œor so many people living in our Border regionâ€. She urged the Taoiseach to intervene with British prime minister Boris Johnson and â€œto call this outâ€. Minister for Public Expenditure Michael McGrath said the Government stood â€œfoursquare behind the Common Travel Area and the open Border in all respects. We do not in any way support or endorse the decision that was taken in the House of Commons. We have serious concerns about the proposal for an electronic travel authorisation system. â€œWe do not believe it is either practical or fair to seek to distinguish between EU citizens from another member state versus Irish citizens for example going over and across the Border.â€The SDLPâ€™s Lilian Seenoi-Barr, the only elected councillor in the North from a minority ethnic background, said Westminsterâ€™s Nationalities and Borders Bill will lead to more â€œracial profilingâ€ and stigmatizing of minorities. â€œIt is a racist bill,â€ she said. â€œIt will strengthen the invisible hard border that already exists for non-Irish and non British citizens.â€Ms Seenoi-Barr, a former asylum seeker from Kenya, added: â€œPeople like myself, who are black and brown, will be suspect communities. We will be asked to prove that we have the right to be on this island. How else can you tell if someone is Irish or British?â€ SDLP South Belfast MP Claire Hanna said the proposed legislation would be â€œhugely disruptiveâ€ for non-Irish or UK citizens living on the island, while damaging the Northâ€™s tourism industry. â€œThis is a terrible piece of legislation overall, with a horrible approach to refugee and asylum issues,â€ she said, adding that it went â€œagainst the spiritâ€ of the Common Travel Area. Troublesâ€™ amnestyRegarding Westminsterâ€™s proposed amnesty for Troubles-era legacy crimes, mooted last year in the face of a backlash from victims groups and others, Mr Lewis said the move had not proceeded because the government wanted to consult with parties and civil society bodies in Northern Ireland. â€œWe want to bring something forward that helps people of Northern Ireland get to the truth and get information,â€ he said, adding that he would not put a timeframe on that. Mr Coveney said the issue could not be forgotten â€œbecause the current status quo in terms of getting the truth and securing prosecutions and so on isnâ€™t as it should be for many families and victims groupsâ€. He said the Irish Governmentâ€™s position was that the strictures of the Stormont House agreement on legacy cases was the agreed position. However, he added: â€œWe also have accepted that if some want to move in a different direction, weâ€™ll listen to those arguments and see if we can agree in places to move forward. Weâ€™re still very open to that engagement and partnership.â€On comparisons drawn by British prime minister Boris Johnson between the Brexit vote and the Ukranian resistance to Russiaâ€™s invasion, Mr Coveney said Mr Johnson had clarified them and that his spokespeople had recognised â€œthatâ€™s not a good comparison to have in the same sentenceâ€.A joint communique issued by the ministers after the meeting said they had discussed the development of the British-Irish relationship in the coming years, including â€œpotential synergiesâ€ between the UKâ€™s levelling up plan and Irelandâ€™s National Development Plan. It noted â€œwith regretâ€ the developments at Stormont since it last met in December and reiterated commitments from both governments to the functioning of the political institutions established by the Belfast Agreement.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: long delays reported by passengers at dublin airport
story: A spokesman for Dublin Airport apologised for the delays people have been experiencing. File photograph: Alan BetsonLong delays have been reported by people passing through Dublin Airport this weekend with queues of up to an hour forming at security as a reduced number of staff struggle to cope with the volume of passengers.A spokesman for the airport apologised for the delays people have been experiencing and said difficulties in training and recruiting staff in the post-pandemic period were to blame. He said that the logjam was likely to continue at peak times for the foreseeable future. Passengers have been posting images of long queues on social media and expressing frustration at the length of time they have had to wait. Some have noted the fast track facility, which allows certain cohorts of travellers to bypass the normal queues, has been closed.Passengers can save time at security screening by being prepared in advance. See our airport security FAQ's to answer questions you may have ğŸ’.https:t.coO9hZztARcZ pic.twitterW7K8HprSUqâ€” Dublin Airport (@DublinAirport) â€œWe are working extremely hard to ramp up our operation at Dublin Airport after the collapse of international travel over the past two years,â€ the spokesman said. He pointed out the â€œrecruitment, training and background security checks for all staff working at an international airportâ€ take several weeks. â€œWe apologise in advance but queues for security will be experienced at peak hours,â€ he said. He encouraged passengers anxious to minimise the impact of delays to to check in bags where possible and to carry the minimum amount with them when presenting at security. â€œWe would also encourage all passengers to be at the airport a minimum of two hours before boarding a short haul flight and three hours prior to boarding a long-haul flight,â€ he continued.According to the spokesman, more than 100 new security staff have been recruited since the start of the year but there have been delays in bringing some of these people into the operation because of the requirement for enhanced background checks for aviation workers that came into effect on January 1st. â€œThis log jam is now easing, and we hope that more new staff can begin working on the frontline in the coming weeks. In the meantime, we appreciate the patience and understanding of our customers as we work to restore customer service levels to 2019 levels.â€All told, around 1,000 staff left Dublin Airport under a voluntary severance scheme because of the pandemic, and while there is an ongoing recruitment drive to replace frontline staff in areas such as security and retail, â€œall companies who operate at airports across Europe are experiencing similar challenges as we approach the start of the busy summer season aheadâ€.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: british and irish relationship should be based on equal respect says starmer
story: Labour leader Keir Starmer speaks to the Labour Party Irish Society Annual St Patrickâ€™s Day reception at the London Irish Centre. Photograph: Stefan RousseauPA WireBritish Labour party leader Keir Starmer has called for a relationship between Britain and Ireland based on equal respect that acknowledges both governmentsâ€™ roles as co-guarantors of the Belfast Agreement rather than simply consultees.He said the relationship had been dominated by Brexit in recent years but it had a rich and long history that was bigger than the current dispute over the Northern Ireland protocol.â€œAnd I felt they were some of the most uplifting years in my working life because there was so much progress going on, so much change going on. You could feel it, you could see it, you could sense it when you were there. And that has given me a really strong sense of the importance of that partnership.â€œThe relationship requires respect, equal respect and understanding of what it means to be a country and to have that status, that friendship, that relationship and that respect.â€Mr Starmer was speaking at the Labour Party Irish Societyâ€™s St Patrickâ€™s Day reception at the London Irish Centre in Camden, which is in his constituency of of Holborn and St Pancras. Other speakers included Trade Union Congress (TUC) general secretary Frances Oâ€™Grady, Labour MP Conor McGinn, who chairs Westminster All-Party Parliamentary Group on the Irish in Britain and Adrian Oâ€™Neill, Irelandâ€™s ambassador to Britain.Mr Oâ€™Neill said that this yearâ€™s St Patrickâ€™s Day events in London had been conceived as a celebratory return to personal contact after two years of the coronavirus pandemic but they had been overshadowed by the war in Ukraine.â€œTo some extent, we have to kind of dial it down a little bit or at least recognise that while we are enjoying this opportunity to meet in person and celebrate all the things that we really cherish, our democracy, our human rights, our independence, sovereignty, all of those core values that they are absolutely now being trampled on in Ukraine,â€ he said.â€œIn Ireland, weâ€™re working very, very closely with the UK, with the US with like-minded partners in the Security Council of the UN, within the EU, the Human Rights Council in Geneva, the International Criminal Court, using all the mechanisms at our disposal to isolate and increase pressure on Putin and his regime.â€

title: liz truss right now differences eu seem lot smaller
story: She is Foreign Secretary at the time of a war in Europe, Iran on the verge of developing nuclear weapons and the UK charting its own course after 47 years of EU membership. It is, perhaps, therefore not unreasonable that Liz Truss has concluded that now is the busiest time for foreign policy since the 1980s.Â It also becomes quickly apparent that her experience of one seismic task is influencing her approach to another.Â While reiterating her determination to â€œfixâ€ the Northern Ireland Protocol agreed as part of the UKâ€™s exit deal with the EU, Ms Truss stated: â€œThere is a difference between a negotiation between countries who respect the rule of law, respect basic principles like sovereignty and dealing with a rogue state like Russia.Â â€œI have frank conversations with all our partners, whether itâ€™s the United States, whether itâ€™s the EU, whether itâ€™s Japan, whether itâ€™s India. There are always going to be differences that we need to resolve.Â But those types of differences between friends and allies are different from the scale and the sheer belligerence and aggression and lying of Russia.The scale of the issue that weâ€™re facing with Russia is so big, itâ€™s so important, itâ€™s so vital that we all stick together.â€Â Not even the most ardent Brexiteers would take issue with her distinction between the EU and Vladimir Putinâ€™s Russia. However, some may be less sanguine if it emerges that the Foreign Secretaryâ€™s comparison is the precursor to a climbdown from securing urgent changes to the protocol.Ms Truss sticks to the government line that Article 16 - the mechanism that the UK could trigger to override parts of the Northern Ireland Protocol - â€œremains on the tableâ€ as an option. But her rhetoric about the importance of harmonious relations with the EU appears a far cry even from Boris Johnsonâ€™s remarks just six weeks ago, when he said: â€œIf our friends donâ€™t show the requisite common sense then of course, we will trigger Article 16.â€Â Senior Brexiteer MPs, including at least two members of the Cabinet, have been arguing that the UK must trigger Article 16 in order to break the logjam in talks and fix the problems the agreement is said to be causing to Northern Ireland businesses.Â Ms Truss still insists â€œthat the Northern Ireland Protocol isnâ€™t working to protect the BelfastGood Friday Agreementâ€ and that the Governmentâ€™s priority is to protect that deal. But she does not deny having shelved the idea of triggering Article 16 any time soon, because of the need for a united EU front in the face of Russian aggression.Â Earlier this month, The  revealed that Ms Truss wrote to Mr Johnson about putting Article 16 on hold because of the Ukraine crisis. She asked that the Government instead helped Northern Ireland businesses with an â€œeconomic stimulusâ€ package, including tax cuts.Â Such a move could only take place with the backing of Rishi Sunak, the Chancellor. Amid internal discussions over the issue, Ms Truss will only say of the protocol: â€œI am working to fix it as a matter of urgency.â€Ms Truss, 46, was promoted from her role as international trade secretary last September, replacing Dominic Raab as Foreign Secretary.Â Within weeks, she said, it was clear that Russia was going to dominate her time in the post.Â â€œBy December last year, we had a very strong view that he was likely to invade,â€ she said.The â€œweâ€ here includes a multitude of Russia experts and intelligence officials who have been working to get the Foreign Secretary up to speed with the Kremlinâ€™s playbook, which some argue has changed very little since the Cold War.Among those who advised Ms Truss as she navigated meetings with Sergei Lavrov, her Russian opposite number, in the run-up to the invasion was Sir Tim Barrow, the Foreign Officeâ€™s political director, formerly the UKâ€™s envoy to the EU.Sir Tim joined the Foreign Office in 1986, where he learnt Russian before being posted to Kyiv in 1989 and Moscow the following year.Â Ms Truss jokingly refers to Sir Tim as a â€œrelicâ€ when she later introduces him at Lancaster House, a 19th century building often used to host foreign dignitaries.Â Sir Tim, 58, and the Foreign Secretary were both at Lancaster House for an away day for the Foreign Officeâ€™s board on Thursday, when Ms Truss sat down for an interview with The Â  in a lavishly decorated ground floor room overlooking the Â garden.â€œThis is one of the many reasons why I think the UK has such an important role to play in this crisis,â€ Ms Truss said of figures such as Sir Tim.â€œWe do have Russia experts, we do have Ukraine experts and we have people who were around at the end of the Cold War, who were doing things like supporting the Baltic governments in exile. And weâ€™ve seen the playbook again, in Syria, in other conflicts Russia has been involved in, but we also saw it during the Cold War. And some of those techniques that were there then are there now.â€As a more junior Cabinet minister under Theresa May, Ms Trussâ€™ kitchen table in her South West Norfolk constituency was the subject of regular Instagram posts documenting family breakfasts and â€œpizza Thursdaysâ€. She is seen as the Cabinetâ€™s most enthusiastic adopter of social media.Today, her posts are dominated by pictures of the now Foreign Secretary standing behind lecterns and holding talks with world leaders and fellow foreign ministers. Her kitchen table, too, has become a hub of discussions about the finer details of foreign policy.â€œMy elder daughter is actually studying the Cold War, so there are quite a lot of family discussions about what happened then and the parallels to whatâ€™s happening now,â€ said Ms Truss. She has two daughters with her husband Hugh Oâ€™Leary, the eldest of whom, Frances, is 16.The Ukraine crisis â€œis taking up my night and dayâ€, she said, pointing out that it is difficult to switch off after conversations in which her Ukrainian counterpart telephones from Kyiv to press her for more sanctions and weapons.Ms Truss has played a leading role in the campaign for crippling sanctions against Moscow. She is now continuing to push Western countries to end all oil and gas imports from Russia.Â Along with Ben Wallace, the Defence Secretary, she has also been working to counter disinformation before it can take hold, setting up the Government Information Cell to dispel Kremlin falsehoods relating to the invasion of Ukraine.She said: â€œWeâ€™ve been exposing the plans to create a false flag around chemical weapons and I think this has been crucial in removing the aspect of surprise from what Putin is doing, and also convincing the international community that Putin is the aggressor.â€œHeâ€™s been unable to create a pretext for his invasion.â€Ms Truss also revealed that she has set up a specialist negotiations unit to provide support to Ukraine â€œwhen the Russians are serious about negotiationsâ€.She added: â€œI donâ€™t believe they are serious at present and thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve said we need to be tough to get peace.Â We need to double down on sanctions. We need to double down on the weapons that weâ€™re sending Ukraine. But when there does come a time for negotiations, I want the UK to be a key part of making sure we support Ukraine to get a deal that works.â€Ms Truss is convinced that a continuation - and in some cases escalation - of the current tactics being deployed by Ukraine and the West could bring Putin to the negotiating table.â€œPutin needs to be put under even more pressureâ€, she said - both â€œdomestically through the economy and Russia being debilitatedâ€, as well as by countries such as the UK continuing to supply lethal weapons to Ukraine.â€œWith the supply of more weaponry to the Ukrainians, I think we could see his attempts to invade stall, she said. Over time, this will bear down on Putinâ€™s ability to succeed and will ensure that he loses in Ukraine.â€œAnd at that point, we need to make sure that there isnâ€™t a repeat of the Minsk process - that we actually end up in a situation where there is a genuine ceasefire, thereâ€™s a genuine withdrawal of troops from Ukraine, and there are real levers on Russia in the future to stop any future aggression.â€The Minsk agreements were designed to secure a ceasefire between Ukraine and Russia-backed separatists in the east of the country in 2014 and 2015, in a process brokered by Germany and France, then represented by Francois Hollande and Angela Merkel.â€œWe should have been part of those negotiations,â€ said Ms Truss, who was environment secretary at the time of the talks, when David Cameronâ€™s coalition was in power.â€œWe should have done more to stop Putin in 2014. And we are essentially facing the situation we are in now because - and this is not just Britain - the entire West, the entire free world, didnâ€™t do enough to stop Putin.â€Lessons have been learned, she said, adding: â€œWhat we know is that Russia signed up to multiple agreements they simply donâ€™t comply with. So there needs to be hard levers. Of course, sanctions are a hard lever.â€œThose sanctions should only come off with a full ceasefire and withdrawal, but also commitments that there will be no further aggression. And also, thereâ€™s the opportunity to have snapback sanctions if there is further aggression in future. That is a real lever that I think can be used. That wasnâ€™t used in 2014.â€Her remarks about the conditions for lifting the current sanctions appear to sketch out Britainâ€™s blueprint for the â€œoff rampâ€ that could be offered to Putin to end his invasion. They chime with remarks by Antony Blinken, her US counterpart, who has said that American sanctions against Russia are â€œnot designed to be permanentâ€ and could â€œgo awayâ€ if Moscow changes its behaviour.Mr Blinken has said that, for US sanctions to be lifted, there must be a Russian withdrawal that is â€œin effect, irreversibleâ€ - so â€œRussia won't pick up and do exactly what itâ€™s doing in a year or two years or three yearsâ€.Â When asked about Joe Bidenâ€™s remarks that Nato â€œwould respondâ€ if Putin uses chemical weapons in Ukraine, Ms Truss echoed he White House's message.â€œThat would represent an escalation of this appalling conflict, she said. Weâ€™ve already seen abhorrent acts committed against civilians in Ukraine, but the use of chemical weapons would represent an escalation and there would be a response.â€In the final months of Theresa Mayâ€™s premiership, Ms Truss was seen as constantly â€œon manoeuvresâ€ and attempting to flaunt her own potential leadership credentials. But as the Prime Minsiterâ€™s position weakened in late 2021 and the first weeks of 2022 amid several scandals, she has shown dogged loyalty towards the Prime Minister.Â Ms Truss is careful not to criticise Mr Sunak's Spring Statement. But she does pinpoint â€œsupply-side reformsâ€, such as tax cuts and deregulation, including an overhaul of childcare, as key to reducing the cost of living.â€œThe Chancellor has committed that taxes are going to be cut, she said. Thatâ€™s very, very important because ultimately, the way to get the cost of living down in the long-term is supply side reform, and itâ€™s doing what we need to do to generate economic growth.Â And whether itâ€™s on making childcare more affordable, which Iâ€™ve long been a champion of, whether itâ€™s making housing more affordable, that is ultimately what will bring down the cost of living.â€She defended Mr Johnson against claims that he likened the Ukrainian resistance against Putin to the UKâ€™s decision to leave the EU. â€œI was sitting in the audience for that speech and I certainly donâ€™t think thatâ€™s what he was doing. He was talking about the British peopleâ€™s right to exercise their democratic freedom, as part of a general speech about freedom in which he also talked about peopleâ€™s freedom once they had got the coronavirus vaccine.â€Here, she segued into another reminder of the closeness with which Britain is working with the EU on the Western response to Putinâ€™s invasion.â€œOne of the points I would make about this crisis is we have worked very, very closely with the European Union, she said.â€œThe EU are doing a lot of work to reduce their dependence on Russian gas, including sourcing liquid natural gas from the States and I support and applaud those efforts.â€œOf course, there are some areas with which we have differences with the EU. But fundamentally, we are all democratic nations, we all believe in freedom and the right of people to select their own governments and we are very much united in the fight.â€More from NewsAll schools to be open for 32.5 hours weekly by 2023, ministers will announcePrince William suggests he may not succeed the Queen and his father as head of the CommonwealthChinese oil and gas company cancels $500m investment in RussiaKremlin confusion as Moscow contradicts own generals with claim it still wants to take KyivChaos as Joe Biden says Vladimir Putin â€˜cannot remain in powerâ€™Russian MP accuses Poland of planning to take Kaliningrad back from MoscowMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: workers world unite delia smith cooks manifesto new world order
story: Delia Smith has claimed that the â€œworkers of the worldâ€ should be in charge instead of a â€œfew at the topâ€, as she swaps cookery for politics.The celebrity cook has deviated from her six-decade-long culinary career with a new book on spirituality, You Matter: The Human Solution, and told fans on Saturday that her days presenting food programmes are now behind her.Veering from gastronomy to political philosophy, she has claimed that party politics is at an end and that the â€œworkersâ€ and â€œpeople at the coalfaceâ€ should unite and replace â€œshoddyâ€ leaders.Addressing fans at an Oxford Literary Festival talk on her new book, Smith said: â€œThe workers of the world should be running the world, not a few t-----s up at the top. The people that are running the world are not the right people.â€Taking inspiration from her dealings in business and running Norwich City football club, she has argued for a collective approach to power and politics, where â€œyou donâ€™t have hierarchies and you donâ€™t have leaders in this, that and the other. You have collaborationâ€.In addition, Smith has also suggested that political parties should be a thing of the past, claiming that party politics is finishedâ€ and â€œwe need to have a new politicsâ€.The cook, who in 2015 pledged to support Labour, has argued that this new politics should avoid ideological distinction, saying: â€œI would like to see our country get rid of â€˜Leftâ€™, get rid of â€˜Rightâ€™, and find people who can collaborate together and care about how to make it work.â€Smith has argued for a change in You Matter, but told fans in Oxford that she herself is not a â€œprophetâ€ and â€œcanâ€™t start a political movementâ€.She did however express the hope that â€œyounger people will start a movementâ€ to bring about change, and that her new book could be a â€œdrop in the oceanâ€ which could help inspire this and â€œmake us all thinkâ€.Her new publication explores questions of spirituality and the place of humanity in the universe, taking inspiration from the work of Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, the French Jesuit theologian and scientist.Smith acknowledged that her new venture is an â€œambitiousâ€ departure from most of her previous work â€“ although she has written books on Catholic teachings in the past â€“ but explained that after turning 70 in 2011, her agent told her she could â€œdo whatever you likeâ€.Her book makes no mention of religion, instead aiming at â€œnatural spiritualityâ€, but Smith said she still attends church.While not leaving her faith behind with her new work, the presenter best known for programmes such as How To Cook has confirmed that she will leave cooking shows behind her, and that she does not watch the work of contemporary TV cooks.Smith attended the Oxford Literary Festival with Michael Wynn-Jones, her husband who is also a shareholder in Norwich City. She spoke about the future of the club, which she came to love through her partnerâ€™s passion for the team.She said that the â€œbillionsâ€ of other clubs made progress difficult for Norwich, but suggested that although no outside financier with similar funds had yet approached her about investing in the club, any investment of this kind would be decided by supporters.More from NewsAll schools to be open for 32.5 hours weekly by 2023, ministers will announcePrince William suggests he may not succeed the Queen and his father as head of the CommonwealthChinese oil and gas company cancels $500m investment in RussiaKremlin confusion as Moscow contradicts own generals with claim it still wants to take KyivChaos as Joe Biden says Vladimir Putin â€˜cannot remain in powerâ€™Russian MP accuses Poland of planning to take Kaliningrad back from MoscowMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

news politics -mini-budget-graphs-expose-"Spring Statement: Rishi Sunaks announcements explainedByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Rishi Sunakâ€™s Spring Statement has been blown apart by experts who warn .million Brits - including half a million children - will be plunged into poverty.Every Budget event starts with a preening Chancellor and ends with expert complaints. But what sets this one apart is the sheer scale of the crisis hitting Brits. whose disposable incomes will see the sharpest fall since records began in . The millionaire Chancellor promised to help families with skyrocketing prices through a p fuel duty cut now, and a big rise in National Insurance thresholds in July.Itâ€™s Â£bn of tax cuts - but analysis shows itâ€™s a drop in the ocean, as inflation soars close to % and the tax burden still rises overall between now and . The Resolution Foundation also slammed the Chancellor for giving Â£ out of every Â£ to the wealthier half, as thereâ€™s no new increase to benefits or cash help for energy bills. With UK inflation soaring to .% - its fastest rise in  years - millions of households will be worrying about their own finances. The  cost of living crisis is hitting energy prices, fuel and the cost of food, with the governmentaposs only solution so far to offer all households a Â£ loan to help pay off their energy bills - which must be paid back eventually. Chancellor Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement saw him announce a cut in fuel duty, although this will cost the Treasury billions without putting cash back in familiesapos pockets. Boris Johnson said â€œit will continue to be tough, it will continue to be chippy, but we will get through it and we will look after people throughoutâ€.But what do the charts from his own Treasury, watchdogs, and independent think tanks say  Weâ€™ve taken a look at  that highlight the enormity of the problems facing the economy... It shows inflation will peak above the .% it hit in  andto levels not seen since the early s. Disposable incomes will suffer the biggest drop since the s - at least  Britsâ€™ household disposable incomes per person will fall .% in real terms in -, due to inflation outstripping wages. That is the biggest fall in a single year since records began in . And this is even after factoring in Â£ support for energy bills, the temporary cut in fuel duty and rise in National Insurance thresholds. The Office for Budget Responsibility said this help announced since October has offset around a third of the fall in living standards.  This Office for Budget Responsibility graph is an even starker way of portraying the same data. It shows disposable incomes only fell in real terms in nine years since the s - four of them since the Tories took power in . It is still predicted to be .% of the UKâ€™s entire GDP in . And the cost of servicing that debt rockets as inflation rises. Since the last forecast, the cost of servicing the national debt has risen by more than Â£billion in - alone.  This chart shows the same data but with a longer timescale, showing how debt was more than double Britainâ€™s GDP after the Second World War - but fell steadily as the decades rolled on. That falling of debt continued through the s and stayed low until the financial crash. It jumped, then climbed further under the Tories. Rishi Sunakaposs new apostax cutsapos do exist - but overall itaposs still a tax hike  Rishi Sunak boasted heâ€™d become the tax-cutting Chancellor with cuts to National Insurance, fuel duty and a p income tax cut from April .But the IFS think tank has warned the tax burden will in fact be rising, not falling, overall because frozen thresholds will drag .million more people into paying income tax. A median earner on Â£, will be Â£ worse off in   than   - a Â£k earner will be nearly Â£ worse off. Boris Johnson claimed the Chancellor had â€œcut taxes for working people by, I think, the biggest single amount for the last  years.â€ The IFS said this is technically true. But IFS Director Paul Johnson said: â€œHe can now expect to raise more in tax as a share of national income by  than he expected last October. In fact, taxes are set to rise to their highest level as a fraction of national income since Clement Attlee was prime minister.â€  This graph shows just how fast the tax burden has shot up to a record high since Covid. story: .MILLION Brits set to be dragged into absolute poverty in Spring Statement disasterThe Resolution Foundation think tank said the typical working age household will see their real income fall % next year, casting millions into absolute poverty including , kidsAmong those to fall into absolute poverty next year will be half a million children, says the think tank Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments.milion Brits including half a million children will be dragged below the poverty line despite Rishi Sunakâ€˜s Spring Statement, devastating analysis says. A typical working-age household will see their real income fall % next year - a loss of Â£,, the Resolution Foundation think tank said. Absolute poverty - rather than relative poverty - is crucial because it is the measure Boris Johnson chooses to use.In  the PM controversially boasted poverty had fallen when relative poverty was up and absolute poverty was down. It comes after the Budget watchdog said soaring inflation - expected to nudge % in a four-decade high - will inflict the biggest disposable income drop since records began in the s. And today the Foundation warned poorer Brits will be hit harder as the Tory Chancellor refused to raise benefits - which will rise at less than half inflation. Meanwhile his Â£bn in cuts to National Insurance and fuel duty will mostly benefit people in work.Even with a p cut in income tax from , seven out of eight workers will still be paying more tax overall by , the overnight analysis found.The experts said: â€œThe scale and distribution of the cost of living squeeze, coupled with the lack of support for low-income families, means that a further . million people are set to fall into absolute poverty next year, including , children â€“ the first time Britain has seen such a rise outside of recessions.â€ With UK inflation soaring to .% - its fastest rise in  years - millions of households will be worrying about their own finances. The  cost of living crisis is hitting energy prices, fuel and the cost of food, with the governmentaposs only solution so far to offer all households a Â£ loan to help pay off their energy bills - which must be paid back eventually. Chancellor Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement saw him announce a cut in fuel duty, although this will cost the Treasury billions without putting cash back in familiesapos pockets. Despite the tax cuts yesterday, the think tank said only those earning between Â£, and Â£, will actually pay less income tax in -. And only those earning between Â£, and Â£, will pay less tax and National Insurance . Of the  million people in work, around  millionwill pay more in income tax and NI in -, the think tank said. By  earnings will be Â£, behind what they would have beenthey had continued growing on the pre- path.  Torsten Bell, Chief Executive of the Resolution Foundation, said: â€œIn the face of a cost of living crisis that looks set to make this Parliament the worst on record for household incomes, the Chancellor came to the dispatch box yesterday promising support with the cost of living today, and tax cuts tomorrow. Signicant measures were announced on both counts, but the big picture is that policy does not measure up to the rhetoric. â€œThe decision not to target support at those hardest hit by rising prices will leave low-and-middle income households painfully exposed, with . million people, including half a million children, set to fall below the poverty line this coming year. â€œAnd despite the eye-catching p cut to income tax, the reality is that the Chancellorâ€™s tax changes mean that seven-in-eight workers will see their tax bills rise. Those tax rises mean the Chancellor is able to point to a swt fiscal consolidation and signicant headroom against his fiscal rules. â€œThe big picture is that Rishi Sunak has prioritised rebuilding his tax-cutting credentials over supporting the low-to-middle income households who will be hardest hit from the surging cost of living, while also leaving himself fiscal flexibility in the years ahead. Whether that will be sustainable in the face of huge income falls to come remains to be seen.â€  Office for Budget Responsibility watchdog chairman Richard Hughes said despite the measures announced by Rishi Sunak, people still face an unprecedented fall in living standards. He told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: So in total, they amount to about an Â£ billion giveaway in this spring statement coming from the Chancellor. That offsets around a third of the overall hit to living standards that people would otherwise have felt had he not taken those measures, so without the Chancellor taking action, people would have felt a % fall in their living standards in the coming  months. That reduces it down to around %, but itaposs still an unprecedented fall in peopleaposs standard of living over the next  months. Mr Hughes also said energy bills are doubling over the course of the year, rising by around % in April and another % in October. title: sunak accused gaslighting families over
story: Sunak accused of gaslighting families over Britains cost of living crisisChancellor Rishi Sunak also repeatedly refused to rule out a future bid for the Tory leadership in a tense Sky News interview Image: PRU AFP via Getty ImagesByPress AssociationRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Mar |comments Rishi Sunak has been accused of â€œgaslightingâ€ the country over the cost of living crisis as he repeatedly declined to rule out launching a bid to lead the Conservative Party.The Chancellor has defended the package of measures he announced in his spring statement on Wednesday, after he had been criticised for not going far enough to those facing falling into poverty due to the rising cost of living. But he said he had â€œalways tried to be honest with peopleâ€, and said: â€œI canâ€™t protect them from absolutely everything that we face.â€ Mr Sunak said he was â€œanxiousâ€ on behalf of the country and said he knew rising financial pressures were â€œthe number one concern that people have right nowâ€. Speaking on Beth Rigby Interviews on Sky News, he said: â€œFamilies are struggling with the rising cost of lots of things and thatâ€™s why in the spring statement I wanted to make sure that we demonstrated we were on peopleâ€™s side, and we announced the tax plan that will deliver the biggest net cut taxes, net cut to personal taxes in two years, in quarter of a century taken together.â€ He said: â€œWhere we can make a dference, we will, and Iâ€™m confident that the plan yesterday will do that.â€  The Chancellor added: â€œI think what weâ€™ve done is substantial. If you take together Â£ billion to help people with energy bills announced last month, the signicant tax cuts that we announced yesterday, they will all help. But of course they canâ€™t mitigate all the dficulties that high inflation is causing. No chancellor could do that.â€Earlier, Downing Street said ministers stood ready to provide further support to householdsrequired after Prime Minister Boris Johnson appeared to suggest more measures could be announced.Mr Johnson admitted it was â€œgoing to be toughâ€ as households had to cope with rising prices and the cost-of-living squeeze. He said: â€œIt will continue to be tough, continue to be choppy but we will get through it and we will look after people throughout.â€ Separately, he told LBC â€œas we go forward, we need to do moreâ€ and insisted the Government would â€œfixâ€ the rising cost of living.Richard Hughes, chairman of the Office for Budget Responsibility, said on Thursday that despite the measures announced by Mr Sunak, people still face an â€œunprecedentedâ€ fall in living standards.The Institute for Fiscal Studiessaid the Chancellor had failed to protect the countryâ€™s poorest households. But Mr Sunak insisted he had â€œprotected those on the lowest incomes the mostâ€ in recent years.  Asked about figures from the Resolution Foundation think tank, which said . million Britons were set to fall below the poverty line next year, including , children, Mr Sunak told Beth Rigby Interviews: â€œWell, I mean, what we do know is the track record, because thereâ€™s lots of projections and speculation about the future, but the track record shows that over the last  years, since weâ€™ve had Conservative governments in charge, the number of people living in poverty has actually declined by about . million people. â€œThat includes , children from memory. So actually, thatâ€™s a record that Iâ€™m proud of. â€œNow, obviously, a lot of that happened before I was in post. But the actions Iâ€™ve taken over the past couple of years have ensured that we have protected those on the lowest incomes the most.â€ Told that it felt like the country was being â€œgaslightedâ€ by his reassurances amid the rising costs and as inflation rose, he said: â€œIâ€™m not denying for one second that inflation is dficult. Of course itâ€™s dficult, and itâ€™s most dficult for those on lower incomes.â€ The Chancellor, who has been tipped as a potential successor to the PM, also failed three times to rule out that he could launch a leadership bid in the future. He read a quote from Mr Johnson, who said in  that being prime minister â€œwould be a great, great thing to have a crack atâ€,â€œthe ball came loose from the back of the scrumâ€, and askedhe felt the same. Mr Sunak said: â€œIâ€™m much more a cricket and football fan, so I donâ€™t know what the appropriate analogy is. But as weâ€™ve talked about at the moment, thereâ€™s a lot going on, thereâ€™s a big job to do and Iâ€™m fully focused on doing that job and trying to do it as well as I can.â€ Asked again, with a cricket analogy,he would be interested, he said: â€œAt this point, Iâ€™m just trying to stay at the crease and keep in place and not get out.â€ Asked a third time, this time with a football comparison, he said: â€œWeâ€™re stretching these analogies too far.â€ Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyRichard HughesBoris JohnsonEnergy billsLiving standardsPrice risesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: climbers spent four days grappling
story: Exclusive: Climbers spent four days grappling below M in motorway bridge challengePeter Whittaker and Tom Randall spent four days climbing along an -yard crevice on the bottom of a motorway bridge, sleeping high in the air for three nightsTom Randall and Pete Whittaker during their epic climb along the underside of the M road bridge Image: Ray WoodByRoss Kaniuk:,  Mar |commentsClimbers Peter Whittaker and Tom Randall took on a cracking challenge â€“ navigating a crevice running  yards on the underside of a motorway bridge. The pair spent four days â€“ and three nights â€“ grappling below the six-lane M road bridge over the River Exe, near Exeter, Devon. Suspended from the six-lane span, the pair had to grip and put pressure against the sides of the crack with every move. It meant squeezing their hands and feet into the crack thousands of times as it vibrated and flexed from lorries thundering past. The pair, from Sheffield, often wore ski goggles because of small debris falling through the crack.Bigger obstacles wedged between the concrete sections included an electric toothbrush charger and a stray car bumper. Tom, , said: â€œThe bridge was actively contracting and expanding so it took a while to get used to it and not freak out.â€ Nights were on a portaledge suspended from the bridge. Toilet breaks involved bottles and bags. And a pal even brought them pizza â€“ which they gratefully winched up.Peter, , said: â€œIt was a tough and physically exhausting four days â€“ like doing , pull-ups. But I think we are the only pair of climbers in the world who could have pulled it off as itâ€™s a specialised niche style.â€ The pair have tackled iconic rock faces across the world and opted for the M challenge as Covid curtailed their travels. A film of the feat â€“ completed at the second go after police thwarted the first â€“ has its online premiere at the Reel Rock Film Festival this weekend.You can watch the impressive footage here.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON PizzaClimbingFitnessSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news dad-transforms-damp-unused-basement-"Dad transforms unused basement into rustic barByWilliam LaileyGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA dad has transformed his previously damp and unused basement into a rustic bar that can hold up to  guests. Adam Cone spent nine months creating a stunning underground bar in his home that hosts family film nights, quiz nights, poker nights, football matches, and even family birthday parties. The -year-old says  per cent of the materials he used were reclaimed and the total project cost him Â£, which included a double fridge, a beer pump, lighting and some of the other fixtures and fittings that he couldnapost get for free. Adam, an excavator operator, added: It was a wasted space that was full of damp. It wasnapost useful for storage because things would get ruined.  We enjoy having family and friends around at our house so it made sense to make something to host guests but also a clean and cosy place for the family to spend time. Iaposd say the bar has a rustic and cosy atmosphere with a mix of traditional and industrial elements.I used a lot of timber that I got from work, old pallets and items that I found on the Facebook marketplace. All the tiles were free and other bits we used were extremely cheap, such as the door and flooring which we got from Facebook. Other people chipped in to help us out too. My friendaposs dad upholstered the corner seat and my mother in law upholstered the chairs for us. My dad helped with digging out the floor which had to go down nearly two-foot because we needed to gain enough headroom to stand up as Iaposm ft inches.David roped his children and friends into the project who helped carrying materials and doing other work on the transformation. But the dad has always been a DIY enthusiast and reckons his interest has payed of in the final result. The children were there to help too. My son and eldest daughter carried bricks out from the original floor to be recycled into a new patio outside.  And a few friends also helped get the concrete in to make the new concrete slab for the floor. Adam says that he has always been a DIY enthusiast and used his existing skills to complete the project. However, he has also learnt some new techniques such as how to source materials for as little as possible because he admits that he is usually one to just buy without looking at the price.  His frugal approach and DIY ethos means he has saved money and in turn created a space his family can enjoy. The move has saved him and his we money on babysitters as they donapost need to leave their home four outside entertainment. Adam said: The bar has given us a brilliant family room where we have already enjoyed numerous birthday parties, film nights, game nights and family quizzes without even leaving the house.  It also saves on the babysitters because when the children are in bed and asleep, it allows us to continue the night with family and friends knowing that the children are safe. My son, Joseph, had part of his birthday party down there last week and Ruth, my we, had hers in there over Christmas with about  guests down in there at the same time!. news uk-news kate-middletons-sassy-response-told-"Kate Middleton and Prince William visit BelizeByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsRoyal fans have swooned over several moments of PDA by the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge on their Caribbean tour. The couple has been married for almost  years and royal wellwishers have been delighted with their hand-holding and dancing together. They have known each other since they were at university together and with Prince William a future king, he reportedly had no shortage of attention from girls. And when he settled down with Kate, many thought she was one very lucky lady. But when one of the now-Duchessaposs friends put this point to her, she reportedly had a brilliant response.  During their university days at St Andrews, a friend told Kate how lucky she was to be going out with William. And according to Claudia Joseph, author of Kate Middleton: Princess in Waiting, Smiling, Kate simply replied: Heaposs lucky to have me. Today marks the last day of William and Kateaposs Caribbean tour and they have several engagements lined up in the Bahamas before they fly home.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up . When they arrive home, they will be reunited with their three children Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis. The youngsters have been tracking their parentaposs progress on the tour - and it appears George is in charge of it. William explained that George has been sticking pins in a world map of each of the destinations his parents have visited and then sharing the information with both Charlotte and Louis.  He said: We let them know where we are and he finds us on the map and puts a pin in it and shares with the others. Theyaposll also be reunited with their kids on Motheraposs Day - and no doubt the little ones will want to show Kate their appreciation. So will she be in line for a lovely present  Or maybe a cake like last year  Last Motheraposs Day, Louis, George and Charlotte created the delicious treat in honour of both Kate and her mum Carole Middleton.  A heartwarming post on the Duke and Duchess of Cambridgeaposs Twitter page showed a picture of what appeared to be a Victoria Sponge next to a snap of Kate holding her mumaposs hand as a child. The photograph of the cake, which was adorned in hearts, was also shared on the Kensington Royal Instagram page.In their social media posts, the couple said: Celebrating two other special mothers today. Made by George, Charlotte and Louis. title: kate says shes more adventurous
story: Kate says shes more adventurous than William as she tries Viagra delicacy in BahamasThe Duchess of Cambridge said she was a little bit more adventurous than William as she tried the Bahamas local delicacy â€˜conch pistolâ€™, which is said to have the same effect as viagraKate tried out conch pistol during a trip to a fish fry in the Bahamas Image: Samir Hussein WireimageByRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge visited a fish fry today with Kate, in a pink Rixo dress, trying local delicacy â€˜conch pistolâ€™ â€“ said to have the same effect as viagra. She held up the strip of flesh, which comes from the inside of the conch and is commonly said to be the conchâ€™s male genitalia, before putting it in her mouth to applause from the crowds. Kate said: Iâ€™m a little bit more adventurous than William is. As the pair joked around, he said: I can handle it. She added that she had already tried conch fritters but had yet to try conch salad.  She then got hold of a kne and helped stall owner Jade â€˜Kowâ€™ Adderley, , who owns the â€˜Kow Conch Stallâ€™. They were offered conch salad. William said: Ladies first, before Kate tried it and said: Delicious. Mr Adderley said: She was a good helper. Iâ€™d like her to stay and help me at the stall. William then made an impromptu stop at a bar.  He slapped the bar top and said: This is my stop! William was offered a Gullywash â€“ coconut juice with condensed milk. He seemed to enjoy it and joked: You guys talk amongst yourself Iâ€™m staying here. They moved on to stalls by the beach where vendors were selling handbags and homemade honey. While talking to stall owner Kimberly Roberts, , of Abaco Ceramics, William looked at the honey for sale in jars on the table then pointed to Kate and said: Catherine has bees at home.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter They then tried some lobster salad at the Island Fusion street food stall before moving on to a walkabout to greet local people. The Duke and Duchess shook hands with well wishers and spoke to people about the effects of the hurricane.William turned down the chance to hold a baby but agreed to pose next to it. They also met Stephen Gardiner, a Bahamian m Olympic champion. title: mum who lost unborn baby
story: Exclusive: Mum who lost unborn baby turned tragedy into hope by becoming a surrogateNatalie Newman was inspired by TV drama The Nest to become a surrogate parent for another family after having three miscarriages and two of her own children Image: Jon RowleyByKelly JenkinsMatthew Barbour:,  Mar |comments A mum whose baby died in the womb at  weeks turned her tragedy into hope â€“ by becoming a surrogate for another couple. Natalie Newman suffered three miscarriages in all before having two children and completing her own dream family.Then, inspired by a TV drama about a childless couple, she felt an urge to help others experience the joy of becoming parents. And in November, she delivered beautul baby boy Bobby, joyfully passing him over to parents Andy Kenny and Gareth Mole. Natalie said: â€œWhen I saw the look on their faces, the sheer joy, I realised Iâ€™d done an amazing thing. â€œIt meant the world to me to be able to do this for them, after what Iâ€™d been through myself. â€œWeâ€™ve become such good friends, so to know they are now a family because of what I did is heartwarming to see.â€What a wonderful story - tell us your thoughts in the comment section  Natalie, , and husband Jack longed for children, but she suffered an ectopic pregnancy that resulted in miscarriage when she was . She lost a second baby at the age of .â€œLosing any child is devastating, but we never gave up, said Natalie. Then her dreams came true, when she had son Alfie in . â€œHaving Alfie was the most precious thing imaginable for us,â€ she added. â€œHeâ€™s such a sweet, loving boy â€“ I had never felt so happy.â€ Natalie, from Bath, Somerset, fell pregnant again in . It was a girl and Alfie helped picked her name â€“ Sophie. They were blissful days. Natalie recalled: â€œWe were so happy, we painted her nursery pink and got everything ready for her arrival. Alfie was so excited to meet his little sister. â€œThe weekend I thought she might arrive, the same point that Alfie came along, I packed my bag, put the car seat in the car and made the pram ready.â€  But heartbreak was to come as scans showed Sophie had stopped breathing. Natalie said: â€œThe midwe couldnâ€™t find a heartbeat. That was  weeks, four days into the pregnancy, the exact point when Iâ€™d given birth to Alfie. â€œNothing prepares you for that moment, your future as a family ripped out of your hands. I was absolutely devastated. Scans showed the baby hadnâ€™t suffered any distress. She simply stopped breathing and died.â€Natalie was induced and delivered Sophie on March ,  â€“ a date she will never forget. She said: â€œHolding her in my hands, tears streaming down my face, I didnâ€™t know how I could carry on, but I swore to Sophie sheâ€™d never be forgotten. I posted a photo on Facebook of a pink balloon and a pink rose.I explained what happened, that our baby girl had passed away. That rose became a symbol of Sophie and whenever we want to remind people about her, when we have a family gathering, or itâ€™s her birthday, we get a pink rose.â€ Get the stories you want straight to your inbox.toone of the Mirroraposs newslettersThe couple created a memory box with Sophieâ€™s blanket and teddy, her hand and foot prints and a card from a nurse detailing the birth. Natalie added: â€œAlfie had been distraught and looking through that box helped him take this in. â€œWe closed the door on Sophieâ€™s room and, over the coming weeks, grieved our girl. But we were determined not to give up on our dream of completing the family weâ€™d dreamed of for so long.â€ That dream became reality when Natalie found out she was pregnant just four months later. And baby Lily was born in March . Natalie said: â€œShe weighed lbs oz, the same as Sophie had weighed, and I just hugged her so tight, thinking after so many years of heartache and pain, our dreams had finally been answered. â€œHolding Lily in my arms, with Alfie and Jack beside me, I felt so completely blessed.â€Another le-changing event was to come â€“ triggered when Natalie and Jack watched TV drama The Nest, starring Joanne Froggatt and Martin Compston as a couple who use a surrogate to carry their child. â€œIt detailed the pain and anguish couples experienced not being able to have children,â€ said Natalie. â€œIt made me think how wonderful it would be to help make that dream come true for someone .â€ She and Jack talked things through and decided it was right for the family. Natalie said: â€œJack gave me a massive hug and said heâ€™d fully support me, he understood how this would help me heal after losing Sophie and the other two babies.â€ Marketing manager Jack, , said: â€œAfter getting over the surprise, I really liked the idea. Itâ€™s such a lovely thing. Natalie is a very selfless, caring and naturally maternal person. â€œShe gets personal satisfaction from caring for others and always puts others before herself.â€ After joining surrogacy group Missing Pieces on Facebook, Natalie met Andy, , an embroiderer from London, who had suffered two surrogacy miscarriages with his husband Gareth, , a professional dancer. â€œInstinct told us they would make lovely parents. They were full of le and love, and I knew this felt right,â€ Natalie said. She formed a firm friendship with Andy and, after several meetings, agreed to be a surrogate. Natalie said: â€œI told him all about Sophie, how I was doing this for her, and he completely got that.â€ The embryo â€“ from Andyâ€™s sperm and an egg from Garethâ€™s sister Rebecca, a mum of two â€“ was implanted in March last year. Natalieâ€™s friendship with Andy and Gareth blossomed. And at five months pregnant â€“ and a healthy baby bump â€“ she, Jack and Alfie attended the coupleâ€™s wedding in Bethnal Green, east London. Natalie said: â€œThere were several references in the speeches to me and their baby. To be part of their lives and given so many compliments by their friends and family, couldnâ€™t have been more perfect.â€ The pregnancy ran smoothly and little Bobby was born last November â€“ after a rapid delivery. Natalie revealed: â€œMy whole labour was  minutes, then a couple of pushes and he was out. â€œAndy and Gareth had to run to the delivery room â€“ it was like something out of a film. But they got there just as Bobby cried for the first time. â€œI passed him over to Andy, who held him to his chest so they could have that initial skin-to-skin bonding. He was still attached to me by the umbilical cord, it was such a special moment. To me, it felt like holding a friendâ€™s baby, then passing him back to his parents. He was with who he was always supposed to be with. â€œI couldnâ€™t sleep that night because I was on top of the world. â€œNow, when Alfie and I go and open Sophieâ€™s memory box, we tell her about Bobby, about what we did. â€œI know sheâ€™d be so proud. I just feel so incredibly blessed with my own family, but also having helped another couple create their own in her memory. Andy and Gareth send me updates and we have visited Bobby. We have a very special friendship. It took a lot of people to create Bobby â€“ and now there is a lot of love to go around for him.â€ Overjoyed Andy said: â€œNatalie is amazing, she gave us the most special thing anyone can give you. â€œThat moment in the delivery room was overwhelming. Our little baby was there and it was love at first sight. â€œMeeting this little person weâ€™d hoped and prayed for. â€œI was expecting it all to be more medical, but with the five of us there, holding Bobby, it was actually very calm and special. â€œHe is five months old now and full of smiles and giggles. I can barely put it into words, what Natalie has done for us. We will be forever grateful.â€ Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesPregnancyMiscarriageSurrogacySunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: only fools horses coin makes
story: Only Fools and Horses coin makes a mint as fans of Del Boy snap it up for Â£.Souvenir coin celebrates the th anniversary of hit sitcom Only Fools and Horses, about wheeler dealer brothers Del Boy and Rodney and starring Sir David JasonThe Only Fools and Horses coin features an images of the Trotters car and their catchphraseByStephen Hayward:,  Mar |commentsThose plonkers Del Boy and Rodney are finally coining it in. A souvenir has been minted to mark the th anniversary of Only Fools and Horses â€“ and costs almost  nicker. The show about the wheeler-dealer Trotter brothers and their pals in Peckham, south London, is regularly voted TVâ€™s top sitcom of all time. The limited edition Â£. medal features Delâ€™s iconic three-wheel van on one side and his catchphrase â€œThis time next year weâ€™ll be millionaires!â€ on the other. And some of Delâ€™s best-known dodgy deals, including the launch of Peckham Spring Water and attempts to sell Alpine ski suits in Peckham market, are featured in an illustrated information card.  Only Fools and Horses, starring Sir David Jason and Nicholas Lyndhurst, was first screened in September  and ran for  episodes, until Christmas Day . The programme, centred on Del and Rodneyâ€™s madcap get-rich schemes, holds the record as the most-watched comedy with .million viewers in . The cushty souvenir coin can be bought through the Royal Mint website â€“ and fans will be keen to say â€œBonjourâ€ to one.Tim Keevill, who owns a Robin Reliant just like Delâ€™s, says his telly hero would have welcomed the medal as a money-making opportunity. The -year-old, of Bridgend, south Wales, joked: â€œHeâ€™d be down the market with his uncle Albert selling them as genuine wartime medals.â€ But it wonâ€™t be legal tender â€“ even at Delâ€™s beloved Nagâ€™s Head.
