title: schools-asked-teach-32-5-hours-week
story: Schools will be asked to ensure their week is at least . hours long by September  in the forthcoming White Paper, it has been revealed.The Schools White Paper, published in full on Monday, will detail how school weeks should runÂ for at least -and-a-half hours, from for example .am to .pm Monday to Friday.While most school weeks across primary and secondary schools in England cover thisof time, the Department for Education said there are some â€œdiscrepanciesâ€ which could see a pupil who receives  minutesâ€™ less teaching time per day lose out on around two weeks of schooling per year.As one of several measures set out in the White Paper, the DfE said the change aimed to build upon the Governmentâ€™s Levelling Up mission for schools, which aims for % of pupils leaving primary school to have reached expected standards in numeracy and literacy.On Tuesday, the long-awaited Special Educational Needs and DisabilityReview will also be published.â€œThe Send and alternative provision green paper will build on education support and change the culture and practice in mainstream schools to be more inclusive, helping the workforce to adapt to every pupilâ€™s needs,â€ the DfE said.The Labour Partyâ€™s shadow education secretary, Bridget Phillipson, said that the proposals amounted to telling most schools to â€œcarry on as normalâ€.She said that after two years of â€œpandemic chaosâ€ the plan would leave parents, teachers and pupils â€œwondering where the ambition for childrenâ€™s futures isâ€.â€œFor almost eight in  schools, the Education Secretaryâ€™s big idea is to carry on as normal,â€ she said.â€œHundreds of thousands of primary children live in an area with no â€˜goodâ€™ schools, the gap in learning between the most and least well-off pupils has widened during Covid, four in  young people leave education without the skills they need and young people are experiencing a mental health crisis. Yet the government has no answers,â€ Ms Phillipson said..removeLabour pointed out that % of schools had days that met the averageof between six hours  minutes and six hours  minutes.Headteachers have also said they are â€œunconvincedâ€ of the benefits of a minimum expectation for theof the school week.Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: â€œWe are unconvinced by the benefits of introducing a minimum expectation on theof the school week of . hours.â€He said that the vast majority of schools already met this expectation or came â€œvery closeâ€ to meeting it, and that it was important to understand the factors that might lead to a shorter week in some schools.â€œFor example, it may be the case in some rural schools that start and finish times are affected by transport arrangements,â€ he said.â€œAdding time on to the school week may sound straightforward, but there are many issues which need to be considered in inidual schools, and we would encourage the government not to rush any changes.â€â€œWe look forward to seeing the full details of the schools white paper and the SEND and alternative provision green paper,â€ he added.And Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leadersâ€™ union NAHT, said: â€œWe hope that during the year before these proposals are implemented, there can be a review of the evidence supporting this plan.â€â€œSimply adding five or ten minutes to a day is unlikely to bring much,any, benefit. The government says it will be guided by evidence â€“ they need to meet that undertaking,â€ he said.Kevin Courtney, joint general secretary of the NEU teaching union, said that the education sector was â€œcrying outâ€ for a Schools White Paper and Send Green Paper that addressed â€œthe huge challenges that battered and bruised schools face to support all their pupils during and beyond a pandemicâ€.â€œThe expectation of a . hour week for pupils is a classic example of Government trying to hit a target but missing the point,â€ he said.â€œThe vast majority of schoolsâ€™ days are of thisor a little more or less. We are looking for much more sophisticated change.â€â€œWhere is the multaceted recovery plan  What should happen in the extra - mins some pupils will now spend in school  How will pupil wellbeing and education staff workloads be improved to ensure their time together is as impactful as both want and deserve â€ he added.â€œChildren, parents and those that teach and support them need more from a government policy  than easy headlines like this.â€Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said: â€œEvery child deserves support from excellent teachers, who in turn deserve to be backed by a supportive and inclusive school, whether they live in Doncaster or Dartmouth, whether they plan to study T-levels or A-levels, whatever their background.â€œOver my time as Education Secretary, my guiding focus has been creating opportunity for all, with strong schools and great teachers for every child. Every plan and policy I will set out in next weekâ€™s Schools White Paper works towards this goal.â€œThe Schools White Paper, closely followed by the Send Green Paper, will demonstrate levelling up in action, delivering fairness for every child and making sure nobody is left behind.â€.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Schools asked to teach for . hours a week or more

title: leader march 4 2022
story: Ukraine may be fighting one of the biggest and most powerful countries on earth, but it has the strength of the world behind it.The conflict has been described as a #David versus Goliath# war, with Ukraine battling to hold off the armies of its vast neighbour.Despite everything the country is going through, Ukraine#s leaders, military personnel and civilians have proved themselves to be tenacious, resilient, brave â€“ and humorous!Videos showing Ukrainian soldiers dancing to pop music have gone viral on social media, with their ability to live in the moment earning them fans around the globe.Just last year, Ukraine celebrated  years of independence and now its sovereignty is being threatened in the worst way.The preservation of human le should come before all , and any military intervention by NATO countries would undoubtedly increase the death toll exponentially by turning the situation into a global conflict.Will the rest of the continent sit back indefinitely and do nothing but send weapons and impose sanctions while a European country battles for its existence

title: leader march 11 2022
story: One of the five tenets of taekwon-do is indomitable spirit.That is something which has been displayed in abundance in the last two weeks, since Russian forces invaded Ukraine.Despite all they are currently facing, Ukrainian soldiers took time on Tuesday, on International Women#s Day, to hand flowers to women they stopped at checkpoints.Viral videos of off-duty Ukrainian soldiers dancing in their unorms continue to flood social media.And, amid leading the fight against Russian invaders and holding meetings with world leaders, the country#s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, welcomed the start of spring in an outdoors video, ending the broadcast with a wink to the camera.The strength of spirit Ukrainians continue to show, from the bottom to the very top, should be an inspiration to us all.Kintyre has already shown incredible community spirit in its response to the crisis â€“ well done to every person who contributed.And, although it might not effect change on a global scale, SG Taekwon-Do#s display of support for Ukraine shows that there are people in every corner of the world willing to stand up for democracy and what they believe is right.

title: letters march 11 2022
story: The Campbeltown Courier printed a story in February  about a painting, Village in the Valley, by H Shapiro.A reader then wrote to you, letting you know that the painting was by Hyman Shapiro and informed you that he had three children.I am one of Hyman Shapiro#s granddaughters. He had five children, not three.Before he was married to Gretl, the potter mentioned in the reader#s letter, he had two daughters, Gladys and Ruth, by his first we, Margaret, who died of tuberculosis.My mother Ruth, like her father, is a talented artist who has exhibited paintings.My we had to call the emergency services for me last Friday night at .am and,  minutes later, an ambulance arrived and the two paramedics provided me with great care and attention before transporting me to Campbeltown Hospital.I would like to thank them for the care and attention given to me.They do not receive as much gratitude from the public as they should and I would like to put on record my heartfelt thanks for their dedication and help in a very stressful period.Do the people of Campbeltown and her surrounding South Kintyre communities truly believe local frustrations are being heard in Kilmory Or have our three sitting councillors been napping this past decade, resting on their laurels, in the belief they are unaccountable to voters.It has been  years since the people of South Kintyre have voted in a local election. If you want to continue having the same conversations, raising the same issues, exasperated with the same results, thenthe same trio at the polls on May  and expect the same for the next five years.As a young man, I made a commitment to serve my country as a Royal Marines Commando now, I am prepared to make that same commitment to my community.I promise to proudly serve the people of South Kintyre to the best of my ability and present a strong new Conservative Unionist voice.If we do not meet on the doorstep in the coming months, can I encourage you to make your mark, on May , for a positive change to South Kintyre#s immediate future.I write after thousands of pounds worth of educational books were thrown in the bin in Oban.It is essential that our council#s leadership makes sure that hard-pressed council taxpayers are being provided with value for money. This in my opinion is a prime example of a failure to do so.The council leader talks a great deal about environmentalism but how is this environmental This is particularly saddening given the fact that so many teachers often struggle for ample educational booklets.My constituents are asking why our council taxes are having to go up when mountains of perfectly good books are being thrown in the skip It is beyond belief that this can be allowed to happen. These expensive books could be put to much better use than this.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022
story: Who am I  What am I  Where am I  How am I  â€“ questions of identity and some of the questions I was left asking when I left a recent meeting.That meeting was part of a world-wide movement â€“ a movement that calls the peoples of the world to pray.Similar questions of identity were raised when I was asked to write â€˜a pieceâ€™ for this newspaper. The questions werenâ€™t so much about me but you â€“ who are you  What are you  Where are you  And how are you I can answer the questions about â€˜meâ€™ relatively easily, knowing that others might disagree. But I cannot so easily answer such questions about you for I donâ€™t really know who reads this column.Identity, human identity, all of us wrestle with questions of identity â€“ from the inidual to a community to a nation or a race.Who are the Scots  Who are the Ukrainians  Who are the Russians  Where do you come from The answers are never as simple as we think they might be or would like them to be.Humanity is such a erse and multi-faceted part of creation.In recent weeks, many have tried to understand why the world finds itself on the potential tipping point of another large-scale war.In part, it is to do with identity â€“ a simplication, I know â€“ and a greed for power, land and wealth.Doomsters will shake their heads and wring their hands in despair, offering little hope.Politicians will talk and negotiate and may God bless them as they do!What will you do Your response will reflect something of your identity.Will you identy with a world-wide movement and pray for the well-being of the world

title: bowlers at twos and threes in the clubhouse
story: Members have been warming up for the outdoor season with a iety of carpet bowls competitions in the comfort of their own clubhouse.On February  the first winter competition was held for the Archie Morans Triples Cup and this was won by Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard.On Saturday the final of the Gilchrist Joiners sponsored Open Pairs was contested and after a competitive three nights two father-and-son pairings progressed to vie for the title.The pairings of Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.The final was closely contested with Jimmy and Craig coming out winners.Organisers congratulated Jimmy and Craig who proved worthy winners and thanked everyone who took part over the week along withÂ new sponsor Gilchrist Joiners.Pic caps: Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard lted the Archie Morans Triples Cup.
