story: Since the beginning of lockdown Jane has been going out and about with her Galaxy Tablet collecting scenic shots from all over the island. What#s more there are no filters or any tampering whatsoever in her photographs.Just the natural beauty of the West Coast.

title: dogged display on the dunaverty course
story: In the first group out Katharine Hardman played a steady game, despite an unaccompanied dog joining the group on the th green and temporarily pinching her ball.Even with the best endeavours of the dog to disrupt the next couple of holes and increasing wind, Katharine carded a respectable and took the lead.The second group also had to contend with the dog for a couple of holes but this did not deter Eleanor Hawkins who also matched Katharine#s score, but as she had a better inward half took first place.Result: , Eleanor Hawkins #  , Katharine Hardman # , Katie Cappello # .

title: from our files friday march 18
story: Friday March  Gigha was alive yesterday, Thursday, as people travelled to join in the celebrations for its th anniversary of community ownership.Campbeltown Junior Pipe Band piped the children from the local primary school down the main road to the hotel to emphasise the change in the number of children on the island.The children donned their new unorms to mark the occasion, carrying the Gigha flag.Fundraising has been ongoing over a period of time to raise cash towards the celebrations.To date more than Â£, has been raised, and events have included a race night, celebrations at New Year, and a quiz night.Last night islanders gathered for the ceilidh to bring the celebrations to a close.TWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOFriday March  Argyllâ€™s newest nursing home was officially opened in Campbeltown.The Â£, Kintyre Nursing Home, which is situated in Hall Street overlooking Campbeltown Loch, was formally opened by Councillor George McMillan.Speaking during the opening of the new home, Mr McMillan said thatthe care in the home was as good as the building itself, no one would have anything to worry about.He went on to explain that getting the home build have not always been an easy task.â€˜There were some dficulties about the site because of the ground conditions but there were also other problems with the planners about this site because itâ€™s a very prominent site and itâ€™s next door to some very fine buildings on the left-hand side.â€˜It was a problem getting the plan is to agree to the ious shapes and types of materials that were to be used, but we overcame all these things and got the go-ahead.â€™FIFTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Popular local turf accountant, Mr Hugh McKellar, has won a holiday for two in Majorca in a raffle organised by Tarbert Football Club.Mr McKellar did not even know he had won the prize. For he threw away the tickets he had bought, thinking that the dance at which the winning ticket was to be drawn had been held.But, unbeknown to him, the fuel crisis meant that thewas postponed for a week.When told he had won the prize, Mr McKellar was flabbergasted.â€˜It was the biggest surprise of my le. And Iâ€™ve had a few,â€™ he told a Courier man later.Mr McKellar and his we, Christine, both bought tickets. They are still arguing over who won the prize!Mr and Mrs McKellar live with their family at  Ralston Road Campbeltown.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Refloated by Campbeltown LeboatAfter the tow-rope had parted in one attempt, the crew of the Campbeltown leboat, City of Glasgow were lucky in the third venture, when, on a two-and-a-half hour ebb tide, they pulled off the  tons Glasgow coaster Saint Kentigern, which had run aground, bow on, on a ledge of rock on the notorious Patersonâ€™s reef, off the island of Sanda, Mull of Kintyre, in dense fog, on Monday night.The leboat put to see at : pm in response to news from Mr John Macintyre, Lady Mary Row, a member of the leboat crew, who, listening on the short wave, picked up a radio message from the distressed coaster that she was in dficulties and required leboat assistance.The fog had come down suddenly in the late evening and conditions were very thick when the leboat nosed out of Campbeltown Loch and around Davaar.There was a slight breeze and the sea was almost comparatively calm.Standing by, just over six cables away from the coaster, was the Ardchattan of  tons, also belonging to Mrs J and a Gardner and Company,  Clyde Street, Glasgow.Near at hand was the Burns-Laird cargo steamer, Lairdsdale, which had erted course while en-route to Londonderry, to stand-by. Also standing by was the steamer Brora, which was bund for Belfast.The conditions were so bad from the point of view of visibility that the leboat had to receive bearings from the Brora and other ships by means of the Aldis signal lamps while shipsâ€™ searchlights assisted them in getting into position. For a time the ships could only see each other on the radar screen.Coxswain Duncan Newlands, who knows this dreaded part of the estuary like the back of his hand, edged his leboat in astern of the coaster and proceeded to begin operations, but at .am came this dramatic message over the leboatâ€™s radio: â€˜Arrived alongside casualty at .hours got rope aboard and commenced towing at . hours.â€˜Rope now parted. Returning alongside St Kentigern for further instructions.â€™There was a lull in the activities while the leboat resumed its operations. They tried again- without success.Then came the news at . hours â€“ â€˜St Kentigern Refloated.â€™The leboat has succeeded in its third attempt, against odds.The St Kentigern then proceeded to Campbeltown under her own power, while the leboat escorted her, but first it took in tow the coasterâ€™s own leboat, which it had earlier lowered over the port side in case of an emergency.The Ardchattern also accompanied the Saint Kentigern to Campbeltown.Meantime, the two remaining ships, Lairdsdale and Brora, seeing their attendance was no longer required, sent a parting signal of good-luck to the coaster and continued on their respective passages to towards the Irish Coast.

title: leader march 11 2022 2
story: So the Scottish Government remains adamant in its decision to ban creelers from the Clyde for the next two months or so.We#re not talking North Sea trawlers here that can go where in the interim. We#re talking about small family businesses whose livelihoods depend on them setting their creels in the Clyde.Many have invested heavily in their boats and equipment and have no other options available to them but to sit it out.Many employees of Dawnfresh Seafoods were brought to their knees recently after being denied a week#s wages. Our creel fishermen are having to survive  weeks.Financial compensation is a must and government ministers should now make it a priority to offer this. Before irreversible harm is done.Much has already been said about the rallying of our community to come to the aid of the people fleeing their homes in war-torn Ukraine.But we will keep on saying it.This week it was the efforts from our youngest inhabitants that shone through. From collecting donations to making, drawing and writing messages of hope to their European peers.Keep up the good work, everyone.

title: letters march 11 2022 2
story: With some fishermen enduring three weeks of no income and a further eight weeks until the current ban on fishing in the Clyde Recovery Box comes to an end, it was fantastic to see that Argyll and Bute MSP Jenni Minto has lobbied the Minister for Rural Affairs Mairi Gougeon to get financial assistance to help the fishers through this dficult time.Not surprisingly, the Scottish Government have still refused any assistance.At a meeting of the Rural Affairs, Island and Natural Environment Committee on Wednesday March  a vote was taken on whether to annul the ban on fishing in the recovery box.Sadly the MSP for Argyll and Bute decided to look after her own pay packet, political career and tow the line with her Nationalist colleagues to support the ban on fishing in the area.This caused fellow committee member Scottish Conservative Rachel Hamilton to suggest backbenchers, with reference to Ms Minto, are #spineless#.Having deserted the local fishermen, their families and supporting businesses Ms Minto has shown yet another example of Nationalist MSPs being afraid to rock the boat in Holyrood.The Scottish Government has banned creel fishing in parts of the Clyde as part of a plan to protect cod.It was pointed out to our MSP Jenny Minto that:.Â Â Â Â The bodies campaigning for this ban did NOT want or need creel fishermen included for the protection of baby cod..Â Â Â Â The scientic advice was modied to exclude creel fishing. Baby young cod are not caught in prawn creels. The scientists at the Rural Affairs Committee meeting on March  said that there was zero evidence for creels to be included in the ban, and that the previous evidence cited on the Scottish Government website had now been removed.Our MSP represented to the creel fishermen in Campbeltown that she would:.Â Â Â Â Seek a relaxation of the ban to enable the creel fishermen to continue to work as per the scientic evidence advice..Â Â Â Â Seek compensation for the creel fishermen for almost three months loss of income.However, in the event she VOTED.Â Â Â Â To keep the ban in place.Â Â Â Â Against compensation.This is absolutely duplicitous. Duplicity#s original meaning in English has to do with a kind of deception in which true feelings or intentions are hidden behind  words or actions.I wouldnâ€™t blame the children of South Sudanthey just gave up.One third are suffering chronic malnutrition. Half are missing school. Millions are displaced. And none of them have ever known anything but war.One of my colleagues there, a -year-old man, tells me he has never seen peace in his letime. But he has seen hope. He has witnessed the hope our colourful bowls full of maize and beans bring to some of the poorest children on earth.Maryâ€™s Meals feeds more than two million children every school day in  of the worldâ€™s poorest countries.Our nutritious meals attract little ones into the classroom, where they can gain an education that gives them hope for the future.We are already reaching around , hungry children in South Sudan, and â€“ with the support of your readers â€“ we can serve our le-changing meals in even more schools. Please visitÂ marysmeals.org.ukÂ to find out more about our appeal.The children of South Sudan arenâ€™t giving up. And nor are we. We know that no child on this earth is unreachable.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2
story: As our planet continues its journey around the sun we notice that theIt is not so dark in the morning and the daylight is extending in the evening. In other words, we are leaving winter behind and spring is around the corner.Although winter brings dark days it also has wonderful surprises on clear nights when the stars seem to dance in the sky and with planets making appearances from time to time.However we must focus on spring. That is where we are just now. This isTrusting from previous years we plant seeds in the knowledge that they will probably germinate and grow into plants before too long. Itâ€™s all an amazing process as new le forms.Are the churches still living in dark days or are there signs of new le  Alas in so many places it looks like the former with declining membership rolls and constant struggles to keep going. Given the right conditions however, growth is virtually unstoppable. We see that from the way the grass grows week after week.So what are the churches doing to prevent growth  Are they ploughing the same furrow over and over again or are they looking for fresh ways to cultivate interest Itâ€™s not easy butwe resist change itâ€™s going to become even harder.Springtime invites us to take a fresh look at things and sharpen up our prospects for the future. We shouldnâ€™t be afraid to look at things afresh.Thatâ€™s when we discover new ideas. New ideas bring new le. Letâ€™s be positive about the future.

title: susan to the four on the campbeltown carpet
story: The club held its Ladies# Open Singles on Wednesday March  and, after some great knockout bowls, the semi-finals were decided with Susan Gilchrist playing Fiona Middleton and Jean Miller taking on Roberta Lafferty.The final was contested by Jean and Susan, with Susan coming out on top for the fourth year running with only Covid managing to interrupt her winning run.#Well done to all entrants and congratulations to Susan,# said a club spokesperson.The club will open its green officially on Saturday April . All members old and new are welcome to attend.

title: liveargyll invite to bring along a mum for mothers day
story: liveArgyll leisure members can claim a member guest pass online and bring along a loved one for free, to celebrate a happy and healthy Mother#s Day together.The member guest pass allows any liveArgyll leisure member to invite a guest to enjoy a free gym or swim session, or even a fitness class.It should be noted those wishing to go to a fitness class together will need to phone Aqualibrium on   to book in advance.Robert Judge, liveArgyll area operations manager for Kintyre and Islay, said: â€˜This Mother#s Day, liveArgyll wants to help you thank the important women in your le and encourage you to spend time together, all while boosting your health and fitness.â€˜If youâ€™re not a member, thereâ€™s still plenty of ways you can join in the fun. We will be running public swimming sessions over the weekend, including our popular Family Fun session â€“ floor raised â€“ on Sunday from .pm to .pm, or you could book yourselves in for one of our fitness classes.#However you decide to celebrate, we wish you a happy Mother#s Day and look forward to seeing you.â€™Visit liveargyll mothers-day-guest-pass to request your member guest pass.

title: anglers back in action
story: The fishers kicked things off on Saturday with their usual annual opening day competition.Conditions were described as #less than ideal#, with a strong easterly wind, high water levels and bright sunshine.Although there was no overall winner on the day, there will be more competitions and opportunities throughout the season for the anglers to make their mark.

title: jake at the double
story: The early pace was set by Stuart MacBrayne, playing his first competition for some time, with a creditable nett .This was equalled in the very next match by Willie Ralston, who coped well with the conditions but couldn#t match the inward half of Stuart to sit second.The early pace-setters were soon to be joined at the top by young Jake MacMillan as he managed to produce a great run in the last five holes to pip Stuart by the better inward half and take his second title in a row.#Well done to all who played and huge thanks to head greenkeeper Jonathan Barbour and assistant Campbell MacBrayne for turning the course out in immaculate condition for the time of year,# said a club spokesperson.Result:  Jake MacMillan - ,  Stuart MacBrayne - ,  Willie Ralston -,  Lee Mathieson - ,  Stevie Garrett -,  Jim Williamson - .Lowest gross score on the day went to Lee Mathieson with a cracking .

title: major milestone in crossaig powerline project
story: SSEN Transmission has installed the first two of  steel towers for the replacement overhead line which will span across  kilometres between Port Ann and Crossaig Substation.Teams have also made great progress with the installation of  kilometres of access track and  of the tower foundations as part of the ongoing project.This is the second phase in the wider Inveraray to Crossaig powerline upgrade, with the first phase â€“ Inveraray to Port Ann â€“ energised in July .The new powerline will replace the existing infrastructure in the area, which was originally built in the s and is now reaching the end of its operating le.SSEN Transmission says the new replacement powerline will provide a new robust and reliable transmission network across the region and will serve as one of the transmission networkâ€™s main arteries in the west of Scotland.The energy company added that was one of the most signicant electricity network investments in the region in decades.Once complete, the powerline will operate at kV, with the capacity to be upgraded to kV in the future, forming a part of SSEN Transmissionâ€™s Argyll kV strategy.This will see the electricity transmission network in the region reinforced to enable the connection of more than  MW of new renewable generation, helping in the transition to net zero emissions and the fight against the climate emergency.#This is a major milestone in our ongoing project between Port Ann and Crossaig, and Iâ€™m delighted to see the first of  towers installed as part of this highly complex engineering project,# said David Auld, project manager for SSEN Transmission.#Once complete, it will not only provide a more resilient transmission network in Argyll, but also provide increased capacity to allow more renewable electricity generation to be connected to the grid â€“ allowing clean energy to be transported to where it is needed most and assist in the fight against the climate emergency.#As a stakeholder-led business, weâ€™ve been working closely with the local community and stakeholders to share information with them about the project and to help mitigate the impacts of our activities, and we thank them for their continued patience and understanding as we deliver this critical national infrastructure which will serve the region for many decades to come.#For more information on the project, visit the SSEN Transmission website at www.ssen-transmission projects inveraray-crossaig

title: blowing away cobwebs on charity westport walk
story: As well as facing a strong breeze, there were many areas of stones and gravel on the shore which challenged the participants during Saturday afternoon#s charity walk.Thankfully, members of Campbeltown Coastguard were in attendanceÂ to ensure all walkers# safety.Despite the challenging conditions, there was also welcome sunshine and the #amazing scenery and company# helped most people complete the five-mile walk in one-and-a-half hours.They then tucked in to some well-earned refreshments at Machrihanish Village Hall, including home-baked goods made by members of the Mairi Semple Cancer Fund committee.Argyll Bakeries also donated some baking and sausage rolls which were gratefully received and enjoyed by all.The hall hire was free of charge, a gesture for which the Mairi Semple Cancer Fund committee is very thankful to the Machrihanish Village Hall committee.The final total was still being counted as the Courier went to press but, between entry fees, sponsorships, donations and a raffle, the event raised more than Â£, which will help the charity to continue financially supporting people from Kintyre affected by cancer.#The committee continues to be amazed by the generosity of the community, raising over Â£, in one afternoon,# said Jane Millar, the fund#s company secretary.#We were pleased to see so many people participate in the walk and help raise awareness of the fund.#We have a few more fundraising events planned for this year, including a football fun day and a golf competition at Dunaverty, so keep an eye on our Facebook page and local notice boards for posters advertising these events.#

title: campbeltown brass scottish champions 2
story: The band was judged to be the #clear winner# in the second section at last weekend#s Scottish Brass Band Association#s Scottish Regional Championships at Perth Concert Hall, one of the first major competitions to be held since the beginning of the Covid pandemic.The band#s soprano cornet player also won the championship#s best instrumentalist award.This means Campbeltown Brass, which has players as young as , will represent Scotland at the National Brass Band Championships of Great Britain finals at Cheltenham in September and is now eligible for promotion to the first section.Adjudicator John Doyle said the band#s performance on Saturday #had everything#, adding that it was #very simple# but #the devil was in the detail#.Much of the band#s success has been attributed to conductor Stephanie Kennedy â€“ formerly Mitchell â€“ for her dedication to helping the band maintain its high standards.#I am absolutely delighted with the bandâ€™s result,# said Mrs Kennedy. #I was so proud of everyone as I could feel the enjoyment coming from all the players when we were on stage.#It was such an overwhelming feeling when we were named the winning band as there has been so much hard work and effort put in by everyone.#Band member Katrina Barr said: #All credit to Stephanie, her level of commitment to Campbeltown Brass is amazing.#She added: #Everyone in the band is really proud of one another, and the work that we put in.#Itâ€™s not just one player who makes the band, it really was a team effort on the day, on one of the most challenging stages any of us has ever played.#All bands have faced a particularly challenging couple of years, with Covid restrictions having a huge impact on their ability to practise and perform together.Mrs Kennedy was quick to set up virtual banding early in the pandemic, when performers were not permitted to meet physically. This proved so successful that she was approached by other bands asking for advice on organising their own virtual sessions.When restrictions relaxed, band members were then allowed to meet, providing they maintained a two-metre distance.And although distancing has now been scrapped for some activities including sports, musicians still have to maintain a one-metre distance, even during competitions, adding another level of dficulty and making Campbeltown Brass#s success even more impressive.The band is now gearing up for a busy year of fundraising to raise the estimated Â£, required for the trip to Cheltenham. With a round-trip of almost , miles, Campbeltown Brass will be the furthest travelled band at the competition.Keep an eye out for more information on the upcoming events, including a concert,Â a raffle, a silent disco and ious pancake teas and coffee mornings.

title: district news march 25 2022
story: Some of West Kintyre#s best plants, baking and art was proudly displayed at Whitehouse, Clachan, Largieside and Bellochantuy Scottish Women#s Institutes# annual joint bulb show.Hosted by Whitehouse SWI, this year#s event was held at Whitehouse Village Hall on Wednesday March .The show consists of three main sections: bulbs, plants and floral art, which had  entries arts and handcrafts, which had  entries baking and preserves, which had  entries, plus sundries.A vast array of plants and flowers made for a wonderful display, with an accompanying heady perfume from the hyacinths.The high degree of skills, expertise and imagination in the arts and handcrafts section showed off the many creative talents of institute members.In the baking section, the most popular competitions were the soda bread and the cherry cake, while the marzipan fruits, in the sundries class, were exquisitely made and very realistic in appearance.The show was judged by Jen Ronald, Margaret Bakes and Mary Cameron, three SWI members from the Southend institute.The inidual winners of each section were: Floral Cup: Adrienne Bradley, Largieside SWI Baking Cup: Zoe Weir, Clachan SWI Liz Dale Trophy for Arts and Crafts: Linda Bryce, Bellochantuy SWI.The MacGregor-Smith Trophy for best exhibit in show was awarded to Agnes Sillars of Whitehouse SWI, for the impressive amaryllis she had grown and nurtured.The overall winning institute with the most total points was Clachan SWI. The inidual entrant with most points was Zoe Weir of Clachan SWI.The judges gave high praise for the work and effort put into all the show entries and said they enjoyed judging and congratulated competitors for making it a wonderful show.#All who attended the show commented that it had been a great success and an enjoyable social event,# said an event spokesperson.#It was an opportunity to show the community that the Rural â€“ as it was once known â€“ is fun and that members are interested in a iety of skills, making new friends and meeting up with â€˜oldâ€™ friends!#

title: from our files march 11 2022 2
story: Work will begin next week on Campbeltownâ€™s long-awaited all-weather sports pitch.The final confirmation of the project at Kinloch Green next to Aqualibrium has beenSpecialist contractors AP Thompson based in Oxfordshire will move its workers in onAfter  years of campaigning, the start of the work would be a proud moment forHe added: â€˜After a dignied campaign by the community over the last  years, itâ€™sâ€˜We look forward to working with the council to maximise use for our local sportsLast weekendâ€™s Pupils game was called off, and club secretary Campbell RobertsonHe said: â€˜At the moment the boys have to travel up to Tarbert over winter to train.Alex McKinven, chairman of the Campbeltown Community Football Group, said:â€˜Itâ€™s going to give kids an opportunity to play the game at any time of day, on a properTWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOThe problem of looking for that more unusual, yet special, gt could be a thing of theCampbeltown Pottery, based at Hazelburn Business Park, not only sells genuineCampbeltown Pottery is owned and run by a potter with more than  yearsâ€™ experience in the trade. Simon Rochford moved to the town earlier this year after working in the pottery on Mull for over a decade.After deciding to set up business on his own and scouring Scotland for the idealSince arriving in the town, Simon has been busy producing items for sale ready forTo mark the launch of his sophisticated designs, much of which are based on themesSimonâ€™s work will also be on sale in the Oystercatcher after the launch along withAlternatively for a chance to see Simonâ€™s beautul designs, the pottery workshop atFIFTY YEARS AGOA coach load of Campbeltown Orangemen from LOL district number  joined theAn estimated , marchers including  bands took part in the parade fromThe Campbeltown contingent received a special welcome and was thanked for making the long journey.Many members were pleased to meet up with a Campbeltonian who has gone to theMrs Ranachan, who has visited â€˜the wee toonâ€™ with city deputations in past years, is aSEVENTY YEARS AGOMr Dugald Semple gave a lantern lecture on â€˜With Camp, Caravan and Cameraâ€™ lastThere was a large attendance of members and visitors from other districts. Mr CK Brown of Ifferdale presided.Before showing his slides, Mr Semple spoke about his open-air experiences in a bellThousands of people came to see the supposed hermit, who at that time was working as a draughtsman in an engineering shop.He later moved to Bridge of Weir where he lived in a caravan for nine years, givingAfterwards he went to London to lecture on food economy at the Imperial Exhibitions in the Peopleâ€™s Palace.Returning to Kilmacolm he acted as lecturer to the Scottish Food League, and alsoMr Semple told also about his ious experiences as a land worker at his hill croftOver  beautul slides were shown on the screen, depicting camp le, a trip to theMr R Lamont MA proposed a hearty vote of thanks to the lecturer and also to Mr JR

title: leader march 25 2022
story: With Campbeltown Brass#s continued success in competitions throughout many years, it would be easy to take it for granted.But it is thanks to nothing but an incredible amount of hard work and dedication that it was voted the best band in the second section â€“ just two shy of the championship section â€“ at last weekend#s Scottish Brass Band Associationâ€™s Scottish Regional Championships.Adjudicators described Campbeltown Brass as the #clear winner# an amazing achievement made even more spectacular given the band has players as young as , the youngest performing musicians in the entire section.It takes a lot of dedication to attend weekly practices at the best of times but for the band#s members to maintain their high performance level despite all the challenges of the Covid pandemic, is outstanding.We should be so proud that the best second section band in Scotland bears the name Campbeltown, so let#s get behind the band and support its fundraising efforts ahead of its trip to the National Brass Band Championships of Great Britain finals at Cheltenham in September.

title: letters march 11 2022 2 2
story: I would like to take this opportunity to clary my position regarding the forthcoming council election.After  years in office, my position has somewhat changed, as was well documented in the Campbeltown Courier in October .Despite myself and numerous constituents querying the decision taken, a satisfactory explanation has still not been provided.As readers will know, I always stand up for my local community at every turn and put South Kintyre first, rather than toeing the party line, when council decisions are made.I am of the opinion that this is the reason for the decision that was taken last year. I fully believe that local elections should not be about party politics and I have not and will not ever be a puppet for any political party.I am therefore standing at this election as an independent candidate.I have worked tirelessly to support and advocate for the community of South Kintyre over the last  years.I would like to thank everyone who has supported me in the past and respectfully request that you consider voting for me on May  so that I may have the opportunity to continue to represent you to the very best of my ability.Please note, due to current widespread and high level of Covid- affecting our community, I have taken the decision not to carry out door-to-door canvassing in the upcoming election.I have canvassed door-to-door in every election since , however, on this occasion, I feel it would be irresponsible to do so given the current situation.As always, please feel free to contact me should you wish any further information. Email: Donald.kelly@argyll-bute.gov.uk. Mobile:  .In the council elections on May  I will be seeking re-election to the council as your independent candidate for the Kintyre and the Islands ward.It is my firm belief that party politics at local level should not be important. What is important is having a strong local councillor who will help out his constituents and work day-in and day-out for our local area.With your support, I hope to continue to represent the Kintyre and the Islands ward.I am an Islay resident and have lived there my whole le with my family, many of whom work locally in the NHS and in farming, crofting, fishing and distillery sectors.I will always put my local constituents first, above any political party or special interest group. I have spent the past five years working for every corner of the Kintyre and the Islands ward.If you have a problem that you need help with, no matterit#s a big or small issue, then please don#t hesitate to contact me.I give the people of the Kintyre and the Islands ward my promise that I will work day-in and day-out for you.

title: parents unite against school cluster plans
story: A public consultation on Argyll and Bute Council#s proposed Collective Leadership Model closes on Thursday March  â€“ and can be found at the empoweringoureducators website.Introducing its plans, Argyll and Bute Council argues: #Our school population is falling and, when it comes to recruitment, there is a shortage of experienced teachers.#A series of signicant national education reforms are also just around the corner. We believe we must take positive action now to tackle these and other challenges by helping schools to work more effectively together.#By making these changes, we believe we will protect our schools, enhance the education of our pupils and build a stronger team of educators.#But this view is challenged by parent councils across the region â€“ and they also question the process.The council is consulting on a #proposal in principle#, and this worries parent councils representing schools in Mid Argyll and Kintyre.In a joint statement, they said: #Parents and communities need to be clear that the proposal in principle does not carry any technical detail. This will only be worked out once the decision has been made to progress the model â€“ all subject to change.#Not only can [the education authority] give us no evidence of this model working but it has not provided us with any risk assessments or proof that this will do no harm.#To make valid feedback, we have to hear both sides of the story.#The statement added that when the plan was first presented to the council#s community services committee in June , it was already clear that parents opposed school clusters.#It is extraordinary that the education authority has now spent time and money using a marketing company to #sell# the same model to parents rather than thinking it worthwhile to engage parents with possible alternative models for discussion,# the statement continued.Suggestions have recently been made that the issue should be make-or-break for candidates in May#s council elections.Islay community councillor Calum Murray, a former teacher, said: #My feeling is to nip this in the bud, that with the elections coming up very soon in May, we should ensure that not one councillor is re-elected that would support this measure.#

title: pupils u13s in football action
story: Campbeltown Pupils stravelled to Clydebank to play BSC Glasgowon Sunday March , looking to follow-up on their draw with Busby the previous week.After a promising start, the Pupils found themselves - down at half-time, through a combination of poor defending, and also some good play from the BSC attackers.The young Campbeltown team rallied in the second half, and with a much better all-round performance, capped off with goals from Ryan Johnston and Ben Cunningham.Finnart #s The young Pupils# second away game in a row saw them travel on Sunday to play league leaders Finnart.The first  minutes saw the Pupils put in one of their best performances of the season, competing in every position, and they were rewarded midway through the half with a brilliant -yard strike from Ryan Johnston that found the top corner.The pace and strength of the league leaders# attackers started to cause problems, however, and two quick-fire goals gave Finnart the lead.The crucial goal came with the last kick of the half, with slack defending from the Pupils allowing Finnart to go into the break - ahead.The second half was a very even affair. The Pupils were unlucky to see a free kick from Johnston go wide, and an effort from Jack Green slip just by the post, but it was Finnart who put the game beyond reach with two goals in the last  minutes â€“ goals that were very much preventable from the Pupils# perspective.This Sunday, the s will play a home match against BSC Glasgow , the first of three home games in a row.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2 2
story: If I had to ask you the question #are you tired # How would you answer We live in a culture that is becoming preoccupied with busy-ness and our daysDespite the noticeable signs of struggle in trying to keep up with the pace ofI have taken immense strength and support from two verses in scripture thatPsalm  v  says: Be still and know that I am God.Rest can be found when we stop and take time out of our busy schedules andMatthew  v  says: Come to me all who are weary and heavy laden and IJesus invites us to find rest in Him because He knows our human tiredness. He Himself experienced exhaustion, loneliness, weariness, anxiety, and stress.Are you perhaps feeling weary, burdened, tired, and run down  I would encourage you in the busy-ness of le to seek rest in the presence of God.

title: way to work is just the job for employers and candidates
story: .Jobcentre Plus has a long and successful track record of matching quality employers with quality candidates. Now, many highly-skilled people have found themselves unemployed for the first time, and are considering new roles in new sectors. Jobcentre Plus can quickly put companies in touch with candidates who can make a real dference to their businesses.We talk to employers and employees about how they have benefited from working with Jobcentre Plus.â€˜Working with Jobcentre Plus is a no brainerâ€™: Jordan, Contracts Manager, Elite Scaffolding, YeovilElite Scaffolding â€“ a family-owned business that is part of the Denholm Group, reached out to Jobcentre Plus in a bid to reach younger potential employees looking for an apprenticeship.#We initially approached the jobcentre, simply for advice and to askthey could place an ad on their system. We did not expect the extremely positive and proactive response we received from the jobcentre. The team was very helpful,# said Jordan.The support Elite got from the jobcentre was invaluable in streamlining and accelerating its recruitment process which would take up to five weeks.#Now, the jobcentre advertises our vacancies viaÂ a sector-based work academy.#Candidates attend a two-week course at Weston College, Yeovil, to gain their Scaffolding Operative Training Scheme and Health  Safety Certications, as well as to prepare for an interview. Now when we interview candidates, they already have a scaffold labourer trainee card and the basic knowledge and understanding of the scaffolding industry. Whatâ€™s more, all this support via the jobcentre comes without the additional fees of private agencies.#Out of seven candidates, six were offered jobs and five have remained with Elite which has  qualied operatives.#The process was seamless and effective, providing quality candidates who were keen to learn.#Working with the jobcentre is a no brainer! As well as alleviating the burden of interviews that donâ€™t progress into jobs, the savings in cost and time to get candidates suitably qualied are a bonus. It takes the pressure off our own resources and provides top quality candidates in the process.#â€˜Delightedâ€™: Simon, Employer Adviser, Yeovil JobCentreSimon joined the Department of Work and Pensions as a work coach two years ago after  years in sales and marketing in the private sector. He became an employer adviser a year ago.Once approached by Elite Scaffolding, also based in Yeovil, he set up a meeting with one of its office managers and worked out a bespoke recruitment package.As part of the programme, he contacted the local Weston College and together they â€œbuiltâ€ the course content.#I arranged for the employerâ€™s contracts manager to present to the class through an online  so they could explain what the business could offer them and what they we were looking for.#At the end of the two-week course, six candidates were offered a place on the apprenticeship scheme at a starting salary of Â£,.#Elite had exhausted all other channels to recruit and were delighted with the outcome#, he said.Moreover Elite referred other local employers to the jobcentre and Simon is running anotherÂ sector-based work academy with a local roofing company.#If youâ€™re looking to fill a vacancy, Jobcentre Plus can offer you a named employer adviser in your local jobcentre that knows the local geography for both employers and those looking for work.#The jobcentre has an incredible pool of talent. One of my Elite Scaffolders said itâ€™s not just about finding me a job but changing my leâ€¦You certainly canâ€™t ask for better than that.#Simon, Employer Advisorâ€˜Welcomeâ€™: Samuel, JD Sports Apprentice, RochdaleSamuelâ€™s career got off to a flying start with a six-month placement through Jobcentre Plus at JD Sports.â€œI left college in January . I didnâ€™t finish my A-levels because I wanted a change. I knew I would be good in a computer-based job because itâ€™s something that Iâ€™ve gravitated towards.â€œI saw JD Sports was advertising and I thought Iâ€™d go for it because it was an administration role in a big company. Everything went through really quickly.#Continued the  year-old: â€œMy team at JD were great from day one. They made me feel welcome and supported me. I spent six months on the placement and I got paid, too. Itâ€™s a proper job which was exactly what I needed. Day to day, Iâ€™d look after anything from HR queries and issuing contracts to payroll and pension questions. It gave me a whole picture of what itâ€™s like to work in HR and Iâ€™ve been doing it ever since.â€œAfter six months, there was the option to stay on and Iâ€™m now doing an apprenticeship with JD. Once Iâ€™d finished with the placement I got started on a qualication â€“ CIPD level three in HR support. It was another perfect step for me and Iâ€™ve now been there for a year. Now Iâ€™m learning about dferent parts of HR, building on what I was doing on the placement. Jobcentre Plus helped me and now Iâ€™ll just keep going.â€Samuel, ApprenticeJobseeker  Right now, a Jobcentre Plus work coach is ready to match you to your next job* â€“ find out more at gov.uk way to workÂ gdpr_consentltd " https:jobhelp.campaign.gov.uk way-to-work Employer  Is your business recruiting  With thousands of quality candidates gdpr_consentltd "Jobcentre PlusÂ  can help fill your vacancies now*.*Eligibility criteria apply

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as â€œa real dream come trueâ€.She said: â€œWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.â€Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk â€“ The Cheese Lady â€“ has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: â€œWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.â€œWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.â€œAlso, Iâ€™m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.â€Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: â€œWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatâ€™s fantastic.â€œAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.â€Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: â€œI think we are in a good place.â€œWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!â€

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than Â£,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: â€œWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.â€œMary has raised a fantastic Â£, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.â€Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised Â£, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanâ€™s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: â€œThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.â€œIâ€™m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!â€People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: record-number-school-leavers-east-lothian-going-higher-education
story: East Lothian Council saw its â€˜positive destinationâ€™ figures for students leaving schools rise to . per cent, above the national average of . per cent.But while the percentage of school leavers going into jobs remained well above the national average, with more than  per cent in work compared to . per cent nationally, it was the increase in those going into higher education which stood out.In  to , it was reported thatÂ  per cent of students went on to university from East Lothian schools however, last year the figure rose to . per cent, bringing it in line with the Scottish average.The number of care-experienced leavers reachingÂ a positive destination after leaving school last year was also above the national average, with nearly  per cent in the county compared to  per cent nationally.The Scottish Government describes a positive destination as â€œhigher education and further education, training, voluntary work, employment and activity agreementsâ€.More than  per cent of care-experienced school leavers went into further education â€“ compared to just . per centÂ two years earlier.The county also saw the number of leavers with additional support needs finding a positive destination reach  per cent â€“ one per cent above the national average.A report to the councilâ€™s education committee earlier this week highlighted the work done through foundation apprenticeships provided through East Lothian Works with business partners and schoolsA range of initiatives and changes introduced to support young people,Â including a common school day to allow inter school co-operationÂ  and key worker support for apprentices, continued to support them.A spokesperson for education told a virtual meeting of the committee that working with partners to continue apprenticeshipÂ programmes had continued throughout the Covid- crisis.He said: â€œEven during the pandemic, because these were our foundation apprenticeships with our providers, miraculously, we were able to provide work placements digitally.â€œOur pupils on those exciting pathways graduated and got those qualications.â€Nicola McDowell, the councils head of education, welcomed the positive destination performance.She said: â€œThe last few years have been challenging from anÂ economic and educational perspective due to Covid-, which is why I am so pleased to see theÂ data confirm that East Lothianâ€™s young people are being well supported to make positive stepsÂ into the world of work, education and training.â€œWorking with our partners and schools, East Lothian Works has transformed how we operate toÂ respond in a way that meets the needs of our learners and school leavers, giving them the toolsÂ and opportunities that they need to succeed.â€œWe will continue to develop programmes andÂ initiatives that make sure all of our learners have access to the support that they need during their time in school and beyond.â€

title: musselburgh-businessman-sponsors-county-snooker-star-ross-muir---hopes-inspire-love-sport
story: Former boxer Alex Brown, of High Street-based Ideal Flooring Solutions, is delighted to support the former Musselburgh Grammar School pupil with funds for his travel and other overheads.Ross, , who lives on the townâ€™s Edinburgh Road, said that it would be â€œa long-termâ€ partnership, with the hope they might get involved in community-based activities in the future.In the first round of the BetVictor Gibraltar Open today , Ross will play Mark Williams, the Welsh snooker player and three-times world champion, at pm.Alex said: â€œThis match for Ross against Mark Williams will be shown on Eurosport and itâ€™s a great opportunity for Ross, who is the only professional snooker player Iâ€™m aware of from East Lothian, to show off his skills.â€œI feel a win for Ross against Mark Williams, a three-time world champion, would be a brilliant achievement and inspire young people from East Lothian to take up the sport.â€Alex is also sponsoring Ross in his quest to qualy for the World Snooker Championship next month.Three qualying rounds will be held at the English Institute of Sport in Sheffield, with the championship being staged at the Crucible Theatre.Alex said: â€œAll of us at Ideal Flooring Solutions wish Ross all the best for both tournaments.â€Ross said: â€œIt is absolutely fantastic to have Alex onboard.â€œHe is someone who is very passionate about sport and the local community. He is a great guy.â€He paid tribute to Alexâ€™s fundraising, including his most recent appeal to help people in war-torn Ukraine.Ross is looking forward to meeting Mark Williams, whom he described as â€œone of the legends of the sportâ€, at the BetVictor Gibraltar Open.He said: â€œMark was my very first match as a professional when I was  and is a fantastic player.â€œIâ€™ve not played him for a few years.â€Ross said he was working hard with his coach and on the practice table, with qualying for the World Snooker Championship his goal.He highlighted the popularity of snooker in East Lothian with a well-attended exhibition match between two snooker greats â€“ Stephen Hendry and Jimmy White â€“ at The Brunton in Musselburgh last week.A question-and-answer session was also enjoyed.â€œIt was fantastic â€“ everyone loved it,â€ Ross said, adding that it was hoped that something similar could be organised in the community in the future.Alex is raising Â£, to support people from Ukraine and has match-funded the first Â£ himself.Musselburgh resident Jim Cranston, who owns Portobello-based builder Acorn Services, pledged Â£ to help Alex reach his JustGiving target of Â£,, which, along with Â£ in Gt Aid, will go to the Ukraine Humanitarian Appeal.Alex said: â€œIt is very dficult to raise funds, with so many people raising funds, but Iâ€™ve managed this with the amazing help of Jimmy Cranston and his we Pauline, my son-in-law Ashley Jones, who gave very generous donations, and many other amazing people who have supported my fundraising for many years.â€œI feel very strongly about whatâ€™s happening in the Ukraine and itâ€™s heartbreaking to watch.â€œI have thanked every single person directly for each donation.â€Go to justgiving crowdfunding monica-brown to support Mr Brownâ€™s appeal.

title: tranent-asda-employee-praised-rushing-aid-unwell-customer
story: Lynette Thomson, who works at the supermarkets Tranent branch, went above and beyond to care for a customer who became suddenly unwell in store while shopping.Lynette rushed to the assistance of the shopper, who had a bad coughing fit, bringing her a chair and a glass of water in a bid to help the pensioner get her breath back.The kind Asda colleague reassured the woman and made her comfortable before continuing with her job once she had been assured that the lady was feeling better.Lynette, who has been working as a front-end colleague in the store since it opened in , said: "I could hear that the woman was unwell and appreciate how uncomfortable it is for anyone during the pandemic to suffer from a coughing fit."I went straight over to seeI could help her and check that she was OK."I am glad that I was able to help."She was very grateful and all she needed was someone to look after her for a wee bit, I was happy to do so."Louise Mercer, Asda service section leader, said: "Lynette is one of the friendliest people I know."She is always willing to help our colleagues and customers."I was not surprised when the customer came to commend Lynette â€“ she is a real star and an asset to our team."

title: pear-tree-nursery-gets-approval-changes-west-road-premises
story: The Pear Tree Nursery, on Haddingtonâ€™s West Road, was given approval for advertisements at the front of the Category B listed building.The business was also given the green light to create a toilet which could be accessed at the rear of the building.The Architectural Heritage Society of Scotland claimed the height and positioning of the signage meant it â€œvisually intrudes on the main faÃ§ade of the listed building and the wider conservation areaâ€.The group also felt the works had â€œno architectural merit and are not in keeping with the listed buildingâ€.However, East Lothian Councilâ€™s planning department granted permission with the condition that the advertising consent expires in March .

title: chance-boost-fitness-levels-couch-5k
story: The initiative starts on Wednesday, April , with a gentle introduction by trained jog leaders.It is aimed at people who want to try running for the first time, others who might want to take it up again after injury or illness, or those who simply want to get more exercise.Charles Stable, the clubâ€™s vice-chairman, said: â€œThe programme has been made possible with the support of East Lothian Sports Hub, who have assisted greatly with the funding for training our jog leaders.â€He added: â€œMany of the runners who start with the Couch to k programme gain confidence to keep on running and take on and achieve many personal running challenges.â€œThe -week course culminated in completing a local parkrun supported by members of Musselburgh and District Athletics Club.â€A drop-in information event will be held at Fisherrow Yacht Club in New Street, Musselburgh, on Wednesday, March , when anyone interested in getting involved can meet the jog leaders from .pm to .pm.For more information, visit musselburghac jogscotland-musselburgh

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-march-24-28-1997-1972-1922
story: â€˜BOSNIANS say thank you for helpâ€™, reported the East Lothian Courier on March , .A group of Bosnians , who found safety in East Lothian after escaping the civil war in the former Yugoslavia, have shown their appreciation of the man who brought them to Scotland and helped them build a new le.Eddie Carmichael, formerly of the Bosnian Project Team, was presented with an engraved wrist watch as a â€˜thank youâ€™ for his help, from a group of Bosnians living in Haddington and Dunbar.Jasmin Kilic, one of those forced to leave the country, spoke of his gratitude to Mr Carmichael.â€œWe came to Scotland from Croatia in March  and Eddie was our co-ordinator and helped us find homes, schools and also brought together a lot of families that had been split up by the war,â€ he said....and  years agoâ€˜COUNCIL objects to strip shows in pubsâ€™ was a headline in the East Lothian Courier of March , .An objection to striptease shows being held in licensed premises was made by Cockenzie and Port Seton Town Council to East Lothian Licensing Court on Tuesday.In a letter to the court, the Town Clerk, Mr T. Walker said: â€œI have been instructed by my Council to write objecting to the striptease show which my Council understand was held recently in the Port Seton Hotel.â€œIt is understood this was a private show and that admittance was by ticket only. Nevertheless my Council are very strongly of the opinion that this is not the type of show which should be held on licensed premises and I have been asked to request the court to consider this matter when dealing with the renewal of the certicate for the hotel.â€...and  years agoA DISTURBANCE by a soldier in East Linton was described by The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .On Monday, in Haddington Sherf Court, James Michael Collins, private in the H.L.I., East Fortune, pleaded guilty to having, on Saturday, committed a breach of the peace at the Red Lion Hotel, East Linton, and on the public road, and subsequently broken a pane of glass in a window in the police station.It was stated that the accused and another soldier had been refused a drink at the hotel, owing to their intoxicated condition.They ed, and, on again being refused, committed a disturbance.

title: tims-tales-proud-tree-hugger
story: Itâ€™s a heartening experience, as we discovered during last yearâ€™s event, to be part of something so positive for nature. For me, itâ€™s not just about doing something on the issue of climate change, important as that is. Itâ€™s also about extending and caring for a wood, which for me is a sacred place.Butterdean isnâ€™t actually a remnant of ancient woodland, but parts of it have that atmosphere. Itâ€™s a planted wood but has been in existence for hundreds of years. There are references to it from the th century and earlier.It has changed over this time because parts of it have been felled and replanted, and some of the trees look like they have been coppiced. It has clearly been a woodland resource for many centuries.Its survival in itself is part of its remarkable story, of which I have previously written. But the dferent phases of management of the wood have left it with a fascinating character. Dferent parts of Butterdean Wood have dferent types of trees and atmosphere.In some areas, native deciduous trees dominate, such as silver birch, oak, hazel, ash and rowan. In others, there is a preponderance of tall non-native coners, although all over the wood there are also some wonderful examples of native Scots pine. There are also many towering beech trees, the queen of the forest. The undergrowth is lush in the deciduous sections, while the tall coners create a forest floor perfect for kids to play. Iâ€™ve met people in the wood who are lost, as there are around km of pathways crisscrossing each other.One of the special features of the wood are the old trees which can be discovered everywhere. Itâ€™s asthey had been forgotten or overlooked when their siblings were felled, or have grown quietly and unnoticed by the tree-fellers and somehow survived. We have our favourite old oak tree, for example, hidden in a corner of the wood, and the beech which still has been our umbrella for family picnics since my grown-up kids were toddlers. And now, with the careful management of the Woodland Trust, the wood is regenerating itself into an increasingly important native natural habitat.In this weekâ€™s sunny weather and lighter evenings, we were all finally able to have a weekday afternoon walk, a perfect way to unwind after a day in school. It was actually warm, with rays of sunshine streaming through the still-leafless but budding branches of the trees spring has well and truly arrived. I love such days, relish such moments in a wood.I have been called a tree hugger by some, and it is a label I accept and take as a compliment. The term may have its origins in India. In , the ruler of the Jodhpur area wanted to build a new palace, so he sent his soldiers to cut down the forest which was close to a village named Khejarli.The villagers regarded the forest as sacred because of their Bishnoi faith, but also because of what the forest gave them. They defended the trees by literally hugging them. The protest was initially led by a local woman called Amrita Devi, but hundreds of poor villagers were part of the tree-hugging protest.It was an act of incredible bravery, for Amrita, as well as  fellow villagers, were brutally killed as they hugged the trees, trying to protect them. Three of Amritaâ€™s daughters were among the martyrs.This protest became the inspiration for the later Chipko movement in the s, when women in Uttar Pradesh likewise hugged trees to protect them from felling Chipko means â€˜to embraceâ€™.So I am proud to call myself a tree hugger, although I fear I would not have the courage or dedication to protect my sacred trees in the way Amrita and her fellow villagers did. Yet many of those currently protesting the destruction of forests and woodland all over the world, and indeed much closer to home, often have their spirit. We need many more modern-day tree huggers.But all we need to do on Saturday is head off regardless of the weather, be prepared to get a bit muddy and help plant some native trees. In doing so, we honour the dedication of those early tree huggers, in our own way, and make a dference. If you want to be part of the tree planting, please book by emailing kirstyduncan@woodlandtrust.org.ukIt will likely be busy, so please park at Alba Trees nursery rather than the usual car park. Bring a spade and glovesyou can.Happy tree planting.

title: haddington-farmers-market-returns-town-saturday
story: Stallholders will offer everything from flowers and printed cards to gin, liqueurs and a range of continental gateaux.Entertainment will be provided by Haddington Pipe Band and Haddington Folk Club, who are seeking donations to aid Ukrainian refugees.Yes Haddington and District will also have a gazebo as they look for donations to East Lothian Foodbank, which reported its busiest ever month in December.The farmersâ€™ market runs from am to pm on Court Street.

title: free-event-held-north-berwick-help-people-live-sustainably
story: The community group works with iniduals and groups to find a workable, sustainable lestyle, reducing the human impact on the planet by â€œthinking globally and acting locallyâ€.The meeting will host a iety of experts from ious fields, who will be able to provide advice and assistance to locals interested in a sustainable lestyle.Ruth Hunter Pepper, chairperson of Sustaining North Berwick, said: â€œPeople are thinking about these things and the awareness level is good.â€œI think what our role really is is to help support people in making changes that are positive changes.â€œItâ€™s giving them a bit more information, so they come and speak to people one-on-one and just find out a little bit more.â€The meeting will provide people with a iety of sustainable options such as effective home insulation, moving heating systems away from fossil fuels, buying and using less plastic, and a better understanding of how to recycle.Ruth said: â€œOur role is to offer people the opportunity, free, to come along and speak to experts in an area that interests them.â€œItâ€™s just talking to real people about stuff that can make a real dference.â€â€˜Living Betterâ€™ will be at St Andrew Blackadder Church on Saturday, from pm to .pm.

title: east-lothians-public-toilets-set-fully-reopen
story: A number of facilities in the county have closed for periods of time throughout the coronavirus pandemic.East Lothian Council had struggled for staff to keep the toilets open and clean.However, Councillor Norman Hampshire, leader of the local authority, gave good news to Dunbar Community Council on Monday evening.He said: â€œWe have been opening the toilets gradually and will get them all open again. I got an email from Tom Reid [head of infrastructure] that all toilets will be available from next weekend.â€œThis is all subject toCovid rates were to go really high and lots and lots of staff were off but, as we stand, they will be open.â€A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed the intention was for the toilets to be open next weekend.She said: â€œThe public toilets are planned for full reopening from next Saturday [April ] and not this forthcoming weekend but weâ€™re also conscious that continued Covid infections may impact on this aspiration.â€

title: cadburys-gift-hundreds-easter-eggs-east-lothian-foodbank
story: East Lothian Foodbank, based on Civic Square, announced that Cadbury had donated  Dairy Milk chocolate eggs ahead of Easter Sunday next month.A foodbank spokesperson said: â€œWe would like to say a huge thank you to Cadbury for their very generous donation.â€The Easter treats will distributed to those in need.

title: susan-wood-retires-dunbar-grammar-school
story: Susan Wood finished up at the secondary school last Friday after  yearsâ€™ service, initially as a PE teacher and then as a member of the guidance team.Mrs Wood previously worked at Preston Lodge High School and Edinburghâ€™s Craigmount High School before joining Dunbar Grammar Schoolâ€™s staff in .She said: â€œI knew then I had come home and was going to stay.â€œWe have a couple of other members of staff who went to school here that I actually taught. I donâ€™t think they look like going anywhere either â€“ maybe I have started a trend!â€Mrs Wood, who still lives in Dunbar, initially started at the secondary school as a physical education teacher before combining the role as a member of the schoolâ€™s guidance department in .The -year-old took the role vacated by her former physical education teacher when she moved on and has been at the school ever since.She said: â€œDunbar has just grown so much.â€œWhen I started, we had a school roll of just over .â€œNow, it is over ,, two extensions later and is just so much more of a erse community.â€œWhen I first started it was all really local people and now we have folk that have come from everywhere.â€Last Friday marked Mrs Woodâ€™s last day at school and she was full of praise for pupils and staff for the send-off they gave her.An event took place at lunchtime in the school before staff got together following the end of the working day.The mum-of-two, whose children also attended the secondary school, told the Courier she had no grand plans yet for her retirement.She was going to adjust to her days not being â€œdictated by bellsâ€ and added: â€œIâ€™ve kept myself busy and tried to ignore the countdown clock on my desk.â€œMy job is busy so I have not had a great deal of time to think about what happens next.â€œThe staff and pupils have been superb, though, absolutely superb.â€œThey have made a big effort for me today and it is really appreciated.â€Claire Slowther, headteacher at Dunbar Grammar, paid tribute to her former colleague.She said: â€œIt is hard to imagine a version of Dunbar Grammar School without Susan Wood.â€œShe is so integral to our school community.â€œSusan has inspired, cared for and supported generations of students at Dunbar Grammar School.â€œHer wisdom, insight, expertise and friendship has been immense. I hope she enjoys a long, healthy and fun-filled retirement.â€œWe will miss her sorely.â€

title: three-candidates-announced-east-lothian-council-election---conservatives-confirm-seven
story: Among them is a long-standing community councillor and childrens entertainer who is looking to make the step-up to East Lothian Council after being confirmed as the Conservatives final candidate for the election.The Conservatives have named a total of seven candidates â€“ three fewer than Labour and SNP, and one more than the Greens â€“ ahead of May .Donna Collinsjoins George McGuireand Judy Lockhart-Hunterin hoping to be elected for the first time, while Katie Mackie , Lachlan Bruce , Gordon Mackettand Jeremy Findlayare seeking re-election.The Conservatives have announced their seven candidates for Mays local authority elections. Pictured with Stephen Kerr MSPand retiring councillor Craig Hoy MSPareKatie Mackie , George McGuire , Judy Lockhart-Hunter , Donna Collinsand Lachlan Bruce . Pictured inset areJeremy FindlayandGordon Mackett Anthony Stodart. chairman of East Lothian Conservative and Unionist Association, said: â€œIâ€™m delighted that we have been able to put together such a strong team of candidates, all of whom are passionate about their local areas and East Lothian as a whole.â€œAll live within their respective wards, are well aware of what the local issues are, and are keen to ensure their constituents views are well represented in the councilâ€™s decision-making process.â€The selection of Mrs Collins confirms that three of the partyâ€™s existing councillors â€“ Jane Henderson, Craig Hoy and Sue Kempson, who were all elected in  â€“ will be standing down.Mrs Collinshas represented Innerwick on East Lammermuir Community Council for the last  years.She runs the family farm at Thorntonloch, as well as having been an entertainer travelling all over the UK for the past  years, performing as Gladys Chucklebutty.The candidate plays an active role in the local and wider community as a trained volunteer first responder and has been a member of the Lothianâ€™s x response team for over a decade.Standing in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward is Mr McGuire, who lives in Haddington with his we.The former civil servant works as a part-time driver with the blood transfusion service, transporting the Scottish Organ Retrieval Team.A keen football fan, Mr McGuire is a former FIFA linesman and Grade  football referee, alongside being an enthusiastic motorcyclist and organiser of the annual Thunder in the Glens motorcycle rally in Aviemore.Completing the new trio is Mrs Lockhart-Hunter, chairperson of North Berwick Community Council.The former Law Primary and North Berwick High School pupil studied economics and law at the University of Northampton.Now, she works in financial services, audit and compliance, and for the last five years has played an active part in thSuperuser e local community.As well as chairing the community council, she is a member of North Berwick Harbour Trust and the Coastal Communities Museum.Mr Bruce, leader of the Conservative Group on the council, said â€œWe have put together a fantastic selection of candidates.â€œEach will be a great local representative of their communities on East Lothian Council, and I look forward to campaigning with each of them in the run-up to the election on May .â€Meanwhile, two other parties have confirmed further candidates for the elections.East Lothian SNP members have announced that Liz Allanwill be their candidate for the North Berwick Coastal ward.Liz is standing for election after a career in international education, as well as time spent as a carer.Originally from Manchester, Liz moved to East Lothian to care for her father before making her home here.She said: â€œI am passionate about many things: healthcare, support for those needing care, and education and youth services.â€œIf elected, I will work with councillors of all parties to push the UK Government to increase support for the people of Ukraine, as well as dedicating myself to improving le chances.â€œMy immediate priorities will be representing the community as we seek to ensure the reopening of the Edington as soon as is feasibly possible, and holding developers to account to provide housing and infrastructure that suits our communitiesâ€™ needs.â€In addition, former councillor Jacquie Bell Â is attempting to become a councillor again.Jacquie, who represented the Dunbar and East Linton ward from  to , is standing for the East Lothian Liberal Democrats in the ward in Mayâ€™s council elections.Jacquie, who has lived in Belhaven for more than  years, said: â€œI am delighted to again have the opportunity to represent the community I care for.â€œI want to be a councillor who listens to the views of local residents, not just in Dunbar but also in the smaller villages and rural areas, and advocates for them on important matters.â€œAlso, I want to continue my work in maintaining and improving our towns and villages through partnership with East Lothian Council officers and other agencies.â€A retired hospital social worker, Jacquie is secretary of Dunbar Community Council and chairperson of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership.Candidates so far confirmed as standing at the East Lothian Council election on May , are:

title: first-look-puffins-returning-east-lothian
story: The birds were spotted by the Seabird Centres Craigleith camera, off North Berwick, as they prepare for the upcoming breeding season.The red-listed Atlantic puffin usually breeds from March to July with many gathering at the islands of Fidra and Craigleith.They nest in large numbers in areas called puffinries which are usually burrows on grassy clf tops.The birds will stay at their nesting sites until the end of August when theyto the sea for winter.

title: travelodge-ranks-top-10-uk-landmarks-visit-spring---see
story: The hotel chain has been gearing up for the Easter break by slashing the prices of its rooms and rounding up the best spots you can visit on your Spring staycation."When we think of places wed love to visit in our letime, our mind often wanders to faraway places across the globe. Its easy to forget that we have an abundance of incredible landmarks right here in the UK," Travelodge said.The company added: "We have handpicked a selection that we think should be on your list to visit this spring, from castles to cathedrals and everything in between!"York Minster. Credit: PA Here are the top ten UK landmarks that should be on your to-visit list this Spring, according to Travelodge.Shop the best deals to stayÂ nearby these popular touristÂ spots this year via the Travelodge website.:Â TripAdvisor reveals the top British Spring destinations :Â Tripadvisor reveals best international destinations for Spring - See the top Blackpool Tower. Credit: PA It is nowÂ easier than ever toÂ plan your ultimate EasterÂ staycationÂ without blowing the budget.The hotel chainÂ has slashed the price of , rooms across its  locations.You canÂ access the Â£ room dealÂ now on stays between Friday, April  and Sunday, April , .The offerÂ is subject to some terms and conditions including that allÂ rates are subject to availability at the time of booking.It may also not be available at every hotel, every night.If youreÂ booking a stayÂ for a family of fourÂ  a Â£ room works out at just Â£ per person.A night awayÂ is already working out cheaper than a trip to your local cinema and could open doors to a spot youve not explored together before.See all theÂ terms and conditionsÂ andÂ book your bargain stayÂ via theÂ Travelodge website.

title: wordle-277-march-23-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If youâ€™re still trying to save your streak, then donâ€™t scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Todayâ€™s word starts with the letter PÂ and ends with the letter E.It has two vowels.It means to rid of an unwanted quality, condition or feeling.What is todayâ€™s Wordle answer, Wednesday, March  If you have given up on todayâ€™s game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.Â The Wordle for March Â is PURGE.Â The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: â€œSince launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.â€œThe game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .â€œIt has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me â€“ from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.â€œOn the flip side, Iâ€™d be lyingI said this hasnâ€™t been overwhelming.â€œAfter all, I am just one person, and it is important to me that, as Wordle grows, it continues to provide a great experience to everyone.â€œGiven this, I am incredibly pleased to announce that Iâ€™ve reached an agreement with The New York Times for them to take over running Wordle going forward.â€
