story: The plant-based cocktail creator went into the Den asking forÂ Â£, in exchange for % of his company.Locals have been able to enjoy Vegan Panther M*lk for years atÂ a secret bar in Mitchell Lane not to mentionÂ Bananamoon on Great Western Road too.Â Crawford, who owned Glasgows iconic Sub Club at the time, discovered the recipe, which has roots in s Spain,Â at a music festival in Barcelona.Paul accepts @DeborahMeadenâ€™s terms and leaves the Den with investment from the queen of green! #dragonsden pic BXKZCkKHe brought the idea back to Glasgow and created hisÂ own version of the Leche De Pantera.The Dragons were ided with Sara Davies unsure about the taste and Steven Bartlett raising concerns over his marketing strategy.However, the Dens sustainable investor Deborah Meaden was blown away by the cocktail company and made Paul an offer.Meaden commented: "I think you are spot on...I think the name is great and I think this is very exciting."That first sip always hits dferent, right @ToukerSuleyman  #dragonsden pic bHXHHRNxFuShe agreed to give the Vegan Panther M*lk the full amount but in exchange for % of the business.Following a tense back-and-forth, they reached an agreement on % which was considerably more than Crawford originally wanted to give away.As the creator turned to leave the Den, Sara Davies said: "Mate she might just make you a millionaire."Following his pitch, the Panther Milk founder described his experience as "an absolute rollercoaster" and while he gave away more of his company than he would have liked, he "liked Deborahs vibe".Find out more about Panther M*lk and shop their products via their website.Dragons Den airs on Thursdays at pm on BBC One.

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationsÂ with signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.Â From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just Â£ for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialÂ organisationsÂ were left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Â Analysis of Scottish Government ministersâ€™Â engagements in Â shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andÂ companiesÂ awarded multi-million poundÂ UK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Â Â Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Â ScotlandÂ is home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Â Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energyÂ companiesÂ following analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.Â The FerretÂ categorisedÂ Â organisationsÂ that lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Â Read the full exclusive analysis here.BigÂ businessÂ including oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersâ€™ meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.Â Â Â We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forÂ Scotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Â Â Â Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofÂ companiesÂ registered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Â Analysis of Scottish GovernmentÂ dataÂ by The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over Â£bn.Â Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandâ€™s biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.Â Â An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedÂ outwithÂ Scotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Â Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned byÂ companiesÂ outside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandâ€™s richest man.Â The Ferret can reveal that of the Â Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Â Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used theÂ lawÂ to avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyÂ hereÂ Five privateÂ companiesÂ who employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandâ€™s arms industry had thousands ofÂ closed doorÂ meetings with the UK Government between  and .Â As part of TheÂ Ferretâ€™sÂ Who Runs ScotlandÂ investigation we looked atÂ  firmsÂ operating in Scotlandâ€™sÂ defenceÂ industry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Â Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over Â£m in total last year, leading to â€œexcessive pay gapsâ€ between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.Â Â In the course of ourÂ researchÂ we looked at the salaries â€“ before bonuses or pension tops-up â€“ of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentÂ public andÂ healthÂ bodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Â Â Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandâ€™s public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Â Â Â Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Â Â Read the full story here.Influential bankers,Â retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandâ€™s quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandâ€™s public bodies.Â Â Some roles are unpaid, and manyÂ workÂ extra hours inÂ theirÂ devotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Â Scottish Government public board positionsÂ has also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Â Â Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatâ€™s been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldâ€™s week-long investigation.Along the way weâ€™ve examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers â€“ and who doesnâ€™t.Find out the top Â most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandâ€™s biggest private landowner has been attacked as â€œmanipulativeâ€ and â€œundemocraticâ€ after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.Â Â Â A letter released under freedom of informationÂ lawÂ shows thatÂ Wildland LimitedÂ â€” which runs three large estates acrossÂ ScotlandÂ for Danish billionaire,Â Anders Holch PovlsenÂ â€” warned the former ruralÂ economyÂ minister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Â Read the full story here.ScotlandÂ needs a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation â€“ Who Runs Scotland â€“ claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.Â In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.Weâ€™ve enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.Â Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: river-city-lenny-murdoch-faces-sins-past-special-episode-tv-drama
story: River City.Tell me more.Good news: we will be swinging by Shieldinch twice this week. A two-part special will see resident gangster Lenny Murdoch â€“ played by Frank Gallagher â€“ face up to the sins of his past.Consumed with his obsession over missing-and-presumed dead we Lydia, he begins to chase down other ghosts in the hope of righting some of his many dark deeds over the years.:Â River City actor Jordan Young on his wild student days and how Edinburgh won his heartÂ How so Lenny recalls explosive showdowns with arch enemies and the ruthless acts of revenge that placed loved ones in peril.It features archive scenes with co-stars past and present, including Sandy Morton, Carmen Pieraccini, Jordan Young, Ann Louise Ross and Tam Dean Burn.Â The second part follows next week.Ann Louise Ross, Frank Gallagher and Jordan Young in River City. Picture: Alan Peebles BBC Anything  It is all go in our regular River City instalment as Caitlinfears shes pregnant, putting Elliessurrogacy baby plans in jeopardy.Elsewhere, Mikeysurprises a heartbroken Gillianon her birthday and opens up about his own familys past, while Bernieuncovers the truth about Suzieslove le.:Â River City star Joyce Falconer shares a magicalÂ beauty spot right on Aberdeens doorstepWhen can I watch The first Lenny Murdoch special airs on BBC Scotland, Monday, pm .Tune in to the regular River City episode on BBC Scotland, Wednesday, pm .

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessÂ as we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive Â£ for two months offer here.Â From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectÂ ground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content â€“ as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just Â£ for two monthsÂ here.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as â€œunsatisfactoryâ€ on pollution, according to data from the ScottishÂ EnvironmentÂ Protection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilÂ companies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as â€œvery poorâ€ in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as â€œpoorâ€.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandâ€™s fish farms have been rated as â€œunsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentâ€™s environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, weÂ can today reveal.The ScottishÂ EnvironmentÂ Protection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either â€œvery poorâ€, â€œpoorâ€ or â€œat riskâ€ because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesÂ acrossÂ Scotland that have been officiallyÂ deemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.Â The ScottishÂ EnvironmentÂ Protection AgencydamnedÂ the performance of more than  sitesÂ including Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationâ€™s protected sites have been damaged byÂ climate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inÂ ScotlandÂ are in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byÂ climate change, we canÂ reveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandâ€™s wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inÂ ScotlandÂ are in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinÂ climate changeÂ and wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandâ€™s natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandâ€™s streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.â€¯Â The â€œappalling findingsâ€ show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles â€“ known as particulate matter andâ€¯largely due to traffic pollution â€“ increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .Â View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation â€“ the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.Â EnvironmentÂ Standards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for â€œover a decadeâ€ would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Â Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.â€¯â€¯Â For years this city street â€“â€¯with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes â€“â€¯has been amongst Scotlandâ€™s most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandâ€™s biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofÂ healthÂ conditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.â€¯Â Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadingÂ healthÂ professionals â€“ including consultants, GPs and medical academics â€“ are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Â Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publicÂ transportÂ and green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandâ€™s rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.Â New assessment methods used by the ScottishÂ EnvironmentÂ Protection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as â€œbadâ€ between  and . There are â€œsignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures,â€ Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandâ€™s most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Â Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are â€œpoorâ€, â€œvery poorâ€ or â€œat riskâ€, according to Scotlandâ€™s environmental watchdog.Â Almost all these â€œunsatisfactoryâ€ sites are considered to be among Scotlandâ€™s critical national infrastructure â€“ operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Â Â Read the full story here.Â Â Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a â€œdisappointing picture of widespread failureâ€ on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.Â The Scottish Government must take â€œradical actionâ€ on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. â€“ SC Registered Office: Hellâ€™s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: facemask use to continue until april as first minister sets out covid transition plans
story: Face coverings are to continue to be worn on public transport and most indoor public settings until at least early April, after the Scottish Government rowed back on plans to lt the legal restrictions on mask wearing.However, the remaining legal requirements for businesses and those in hospitality to collect customer details for contract tracing, and to have regard to and take reasonable measures set out in COVID guidance, will end as planned on Monday, March .The delay to the lting of legal restrictions on face masks comes as a result of a spike in COVID case numbers, both nationally and in Orkney, which has one of the highest infection rates in the UK.The latest data shows that ,. cases per , were in Orkney, putting a widespread and signicant strain on a number of services, notably schools, nurseries, and health and care settings.Nicola Sturgeon said the legal restrictions to mask wearing will be reviewed again in two weeks, where it is likely to be converted to guidance by April .The First Minister also confirmed that people without COVID- symptoms will no longer be asked to take regular lateral flow tests from April .The change forms part of the Test and Protect Transition Plan, which sets out how testing will become more targeted, with the aim of reducing serious harm from COVID-.The changes to Test and Protect mean that from April :People who have symptoms of COVID- will still be able to book PCR tests in the usual way until April .From that date, test sites will close and people with symptoms will no longer be advised that they need to seek a test.The public health advice for people who feel unwell will be to stay at home until they feel better, to reduce the risk of infecting other people.The First Minister said on Tuesday that her announcement â€œmarks a further decisive sht away from controlling COVID through legal restrictions, and towards relying instead on advice and guidance.â€She said she knew that retaining facemasks for at least two weeks more than planned would beÂ  â€œdisappointingâ€ for businesses and service providers.Ms Sturgeon said: â€œHowever, ensuring maximum continued use of face coverings will provide some additional protection â€” particularly for the most vulnerable â€” at a time when the risk of infection is very high, and it may help us get over this spike more quickly.â€œWe will review it again in two weeks â€” before the Easter recess â€” and our expectation now is that this regulation will convert to guidance in early April.â€She continued: â€œChanges in Test and Protect will be phased between now and the end of April. After Easter â€” from April  â€” we will stop recommending that people who donâ€™t have symptoms, should test for COVID.â€œThis change will apply across the population â€” including in most workplaces and in early years centres, schools, universities and colleges.â€œThen, at the end of April, routine testing will end â€” even for people who have symptoms.â€œAt that time, physical test sites will close â€” although some mobile testing units and capacity will be retained for possible future use. Contact tracing will also end.â€œFree testing will not generally be available to the wider population. Instead, our advice will be thatyou have symptoms of COVID â€” or indeed symptoms of the flu, or any other infectious illness â€” you should stay at home in order to aid your recovery.â€copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: flagstone repairs progress through stromness
story: newsFlagstone repairs progress through StromnessMarch ,  at : amThe section of Alfred Street in Stromness spanning Hellihole to Mayburn Court will reopen on Monday, Orkney Islands Councilhas confirmed.This part of the street has been closed due to ongoing flagstone repair work in the town.Works will move to South End from Monday, meaning access to MayburnÂ Court will be from theÂ Hellihole Road Alfred Street junction end. The road will continue to be closed, from Hellihole Road Alfred Street junction to NessÂ Road, with no through vehicular access.This section of the works are expected to take two to three weeks to complete, weather dependent.Where required, repaired areas will be covered temporarily to allow them to fully cure. These areas will remain closed while this takes place.According to OIC, pedestrian access will be maintained throughout.This flagstone repair work is being carried out byÂ BDS Surfacing Ltd on behalf of the council. The contractorâ€™s working hours will generally be am to .pm, Monday to Friday, with occasional Saturday working.The council has thanked drivers for their ongoing patience, and apologises for the inconvenience these works may cause.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic among lowest spending local authorities on maintenance for social housing
story: newsOIC among lowest-spending local authorities on maintenance for social housingMarch ,  at : pmAmong all the local authorities in the UK, Orkney Islands Councilspends among the least on the maintenance of social housing. The spend is almost four and a half times less than the national average.This is according to a new study conducted by MyJobQuote, which has compiled data using responses from a Freedom of Information survey.According to the authors, the survey asked councils across the UK how many tenanted and leasehold properties they had on their books. They were also asked how much they spent in   on #responsive repairs and maintenance .#Of the  UK councils, at Â£ per property in -, OIC ranked as the bottom fourth for how much it spent on maintenance. The UK average is Â£.In response to recent concerns raised about the state of some social housing properties in the county, OIC previously explained that properties are run from a ring-fenced budget.The council has said it has to balance spending against rent rises and that, as the landlord for many people with income dficulties, it wants to keep rent as low as possible.The council have been approached for comment on the recent figures.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: urgent assurance sought over stromness bank of scotland branch closure
story: news#Urgent assurance# sought over Stromness Bank of Scotland branch closureMarch ,  at : pm vw, px"  Bank of Scotland has confirmed that it is to permanently close its Stromness branch.The closure, scheduled for August, comes after an #in-depth review# published by the bank.A number of factors are behind the decision, according to the bank, including declining #in-branch transactions# by customers, with this falling by  per cent for personal customers in the last year alone, and by three per cent for business customers.According to Bank of Scotland, only  of its customers regularly used the branch in the past  months.But Orkney parliamentarians have today sought #urgent assurance# over the closure, which is due to take effect on August  and is one of  across Scotland.#We need an absolute assurance from Bank of Scotland that jobs and services will not be undermined and that Stromness will continue to get the level of banking access it deserves.#In its review, the bank states: #Our customersâ€™ needs are changing.#Almost  million people now bank with us through Internet Banking and over  million use Mobile Banking. Branches will remain vital in meeting customersâ€™ needs but we must continually review our network to make sure we have branches in locations where customers need and use them the most.#As a result, we#ve made the dficult decision to close this branch because customers are using it less often. In addition the majority of customers are also using alternative ways to bank.#Explaining what the closure will mean for Bank of Scotland customers signed up to the Stromness branch, the bank adds: #You can use any of our branches and our nearest alternative is the Kirkwall branch.#You can also use a Post Office for your everyday banking.#Weâ€™re still here to support you, and thereâ€™s a number of ways you can bank with us. Read on to find out more, and for a summary of our review.#A second review of the branch is also due to take place, based on community feedback to the closure announcement.The bank states: #Following engagement with the local community, an overview of the feedback we receive will be given in our Closing Branch Review Part .#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. â€“ SC Registered Office: Hellâ€™s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: schools-asked-teach-32-5-hours-week
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Schools will be asked to ensure their week is at least . hours long by September  in the forthcoming White Paper, it has been revealed.The Schools White Paper, published in full on Monday, will detail how school weeks should runÂ for at least -and-a-half hours, from for example .am to .pm Monday to Friday.While most school weeks across primary and secondary schools in England cover thisof time, the Department for Education said there are some â€œdiscrepanciesâ€ which could see a pupil who receives  minutesâ€™ less teaching time per day lose out on around two weeks of schooling per year.As one of several measures set out in the White Paper, the DfE said the change aimed to build upon the Governmentâ€™s Levelling Up mission for schools, which aims for % of pupils leaving primary school to have reached expected standards in numeracy and literacy.On Tuesday, the long-awaited Special Educational Needs and DisabilityReview will also be published.â€œThe Send and alternative provision green paper will build on education support and change the culture and practice in mainstream schools to be more inclusive, helping the workforce to adapt to every pupilâ€™s needs,â€ the DfE said.The Labour Partyâ€™s shadow education secretary, Bridget Phillipson, said that the proposals amounted to telling most schools to â€œcarry on as normalâ€.She said that after two years of â€œpandemic chaosâ€ the plan would leave parents, teachers and pupils â€œwondering where the ambition for childrenâ€™s futures isâ€.â€œFor almost eight in  schools, the Education Secretaryâ€™s big idea is to carry on as normal,â€ she said.â€œHundreds of thousands of primary children live in an area with no â€˜goodâ€™ schools, the gap in learning between the most and least well-off pupils has widened during Covid, four in  young people leave education without the skills they need and young people are experiencing a mental health crisis. Yet the government has no answers,â€ Ms Phillipson said.Labour pointed out that % of schools had days that met the averageof between six hours  minutes and six hours  minutes.Headteachers have also said they are â€œunconvincedâ€ of the benefits of a minimum expectation for theof the school week.Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: â€œWe are unconvinced by the benefits of introducing a minimum expectation on theof the school week of . hours.â€He said that the vast majority of schools already met this expectation or came â€œvery closeâ€ to meeting it, and that it was important to understand the factors that might lead to a shorter week in some schools.â€œFor example, it may be the case in some rural schools that start and finish times are affected by transport arrangements,â€ he said.â€œAdding time on to the school week may sound straightforward, but there are many issues which need to be considered in inidual schools, and we would encourage the government not to rush any changes.â€â€œWe look forward to seeing the full details of the schools white paper and the SEND and alternative provision green paper,â€ he added.And Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leadersâ€™ union NAHT, said: â€œWe hope that during the year before these proposals are implemented, there can be a review of the evidence supporting this plan.â€â€œSimply adding five or ten minutes to a day is unlikely to bring much,any, benefit. The government says it will be guided by evidence â€“ they need to meet that undertaking,â€ he said.Kevin Courtney, joint general secretary of the NEU teaching union, said that the education sector was â€œcrying outâ€ for a Schools White Paper and Send Green Paper that addressed â€œthe huge challenges that battered and bruised schools face to support all their pupils during and beyond a pandemicâ€.â€œThe expectation of a . hour week for pupils is a classic example of Government trying to hit a target but missing the point,â€ he said.â€œThe vast majority of schoolsâ€™ days are of thisor a little more or less. We are looking for much more sophisticated change.â€â€œWhere is the multaceted recovery plan  What should happen in the extra - mins some pupils will now spend in school  How will pupil wellbeing and education staff workloads be improved to ensure their time together is as impactful as both want and deserve â€ he added.â€œChildren, parents and those that teach and support them need more from a government policy  than easy headlines like this.â€Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said: â€œEvery child deserves support from excellent teachers, who in turn deserve to be backed by a supportive and inclusive school, whether they live in Doncaster or Dartmouth, whether they plan to study T-levels or A-levels, whatever their background.â€œOver my time as Education Secretary, my guiding focus has been creating opportunity for all, with strong schools and great teachers for every child. Every plan and policy I will set out in next weekâ€™s Schools White Paper works towards this goal.â€œThe Schools White Paper, closely followed by the Send Green Paper, will demonstrate levelling up in action, delivering fairness for every child and making sure nobody is left behind.â€

title: joe-biden-calls-regime-change-moscow-likens-invasion-ww2-horrors
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Joe Biden directly appealed to the Russian people with comparisons between the invasion of Ukraine and the horrors of the Second World War as he called for Vladimir Putin to go.â€œFor Godâ€™s sake this man cannot remain in power,â€ the US president said, apparently calling for regime change in Moscow at the end of a speech from Poland on Saturday.He said â€œ youâ€™re able to listen: you, the Russian people, are not our enemyâ€ before evoking the Naziâ€™s siege of Leningrad and likening it to the atrocities in Ukraine.â€œThese are not the actions of a great nation,â€ Mr Biden said, in front of the Royal Castle, a landmark in Warsaw that was badly damaged during Adolf Hitlerâ€™s war.â€œOf all people, you the Russian people, as well as all people across Europe still have the memory of being in a similar situation in the s and s, the situation of World War Two, still fresh in the mind of many grandparents in the region.â€â€œWhatever your generation experienced, whether it experienced the siege of Leningrad, or heard about it from your parents and grandparents, train stations overflowing with terried families fleeing their homes, nights sheltering in basements and cellars, mornings sting through the rubble in your home â€“ these are not memories of the past â€“ not any more, itâ€™s exactly what the Russian army is doing in Ukraine right now.â€Multiple rockets struck the western Ukrainian city of Lviv near the Polish border during Mr Bidenâ€™s visit, which came as Russia faced the prospect of further setbacks in the war.The US president said Moscowâ€™s troops have â€œmet their match with brave and stf Ukrainian resistanceâ€ and have strengthened the resolve and unity of both the defending forces and the West.â€œRussia wanted less of a Nato presence on his border but now he has a stronger presence, a larger presence,â€ he said.Mr Biden said , Russians had left their country in a single month in a â€œremarkable brain drainâ€ as Mr Putin, who he earlier called a â€œbutcherâ€, had â€œstrangled democracyâ€.Addressing the thousand-strong audience that included refugees who have fled the war, he told Ukrainians â€œwe stand with you â€“ periodâ€ as he defended the nationâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelensky.â€œPutin has the gall to say heâ€™s denazying Ukraine. Itâ€™s a lie, itâ€™s just cynical â€“ he knows that,â€ Mr Biden said.â€œAnd itâ€™s also obscene. President Zelensky was democratically elected, heâ€™s Jewish, his fatherâ€™s family was wiped out in the Nazi holocaust and Putin has the audacity â€“ like all autocrats before him â€“ to believe that might will make right.â€The brave Ukrainian resistance is a front in a larger fight: for the essential democratic principles that unite all free people.These principles are essential for a free society, but have always been embattled.Every generation has had to defeat democracyâ€™s mortal foes.â€” President BidenMarch , But as he made an impassioned defence of democracy, he reminded European nations they must end â€œdependence on Russian fossil fuelsâ€.Sanctions, he said, have been sapping Russiaâ€™s strength and have reduced the rouble â€œto rubbleâ€.But Mr Biden warned: â€œThis battle will not be won in days, or months either. We need to steel ourselves for the long fight ahead.â€Despite clearly calling for Mr Putin to go at the end of his speech, a White House official tried to argue that the US Presidentâ€™s point was that the Russian leader â€œcannot be allowed to exercise power over his neighbours or the regionâ€.â€œHe was not discussing Putinâ€™s power in Russia, or regime change,â€ the official added, before reports in the US suggested the remarks in question had not been scripted.Unwise comment:Itâ€™s for the Russian people to draw thisconclusion.Putin  Xiwill now read â€˜regime changeâ€™ as POTUSâ€™ wider objective â€“ beyond supporting Ukraine.Putin will spin this, dig in and fight harder. pic GEbcAaLâ€” Tobias Ellwood MPMarch , Tobias Ellwood, the Conservative MP who chairs the Commons Defence Committee, said Mr Bidenâ€™s comment was â€œunwiseâ€.He warned the Russian president will now see regime change as Mr Bidenâ€™s wider objective, adding: â€œPutin will spin this, dig in and fight harder.â€Mr Biden stopped at RAF Mildenhall, a base in Suffolk that supports US military operations, on his way back to Washington so that his Air Force One jet could refuel.Moscow has gave an indication it could scale back its offensive to focus on what it claimed was the â€œmain goal, liberation of Donbasâ€, the region bordering Russia in the east of Ukraine.Mr Zelenskyâ€™s forces were regaining ground around the capital of Kyiv and the UK Ministry of Defencesaid Russians are â€œproving reluctant to engage in large scale urban infantry operationsâ€.Instead, the MoD said, they were preferring the â€œindiscriminate use of air and artillery bombardments in an attempt to demoralise defending forcesâ€. vw,vw,px, px"A Ukrainian soldier on top of his APC on the front line position near Kharkiv, Ukraine However, there were fresh signs it was Mr Putinâ€™s troops who were struggling with morale, as Western intelligence suggested a Russian brigade commander, Colonel Medvechek, was deliberately run down and possibly killed by his own troops.An adviser to the Ukrainian ministry of defence, Markian Lubkivskyi, predicted troops could on Saturday take back Kherson, the first major city that the Kremlinâ€™s forces seized.He was sceptical that the Russian Presidentâ€™s aims had truly changed away from trying to take the whole nation, but said it does appear â€œthe enemy is focused on the eastern part of Ukraineâ€.The port city Kherson, in the south east, fell to the Russians early this month in their first major gain.But Mr Lubkivskyi told BBC Radio â€™s Today programme: â€œI believe that today the city will be fully under the control of Ukrainian armed forces.â€œWe have finished in the last two days the operation in the Kyiv region so other armed forces are now focused on the southern part trying to get free Kherson and some other Ukrainian cities.â€

title: russian-sanctions-lifted-invading-forces-withdrawn-truss-says
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Sanctions against Russian oligarchs, banks and businesses could be ltedVladimir Putin ends his invasion of Ukraine and commits to â€œno further aggressionâ€, Liz Truss has said.The Foreign Secretary said in an interview published on Sunday that the threat of â€œsnapback sanctionsâ€ would be retainedthe Russian president did attack again.Ms Truss told the Sundaythat a â€œnegotiations unitâ€ had been established in the Foreign Office to aid possible peace talks.With the Kremlinâ€™s troops struggling, her comments will be seen as a possible incentive for Mr Putin to cut his losses and broker a deal with Ukraine.Moscow has given indications after a month of war that it might scale back its ambitions to fight for control of the Donbas region in the east of Ukraine.But Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky warned he would not give up territory in peace talks as he noted that his troops have delivered â€œpowerful blowsâ€ to invading forces.Boris Johnson said that western allies are looking to â€œsteadily ratchet upâ€ the sanctions that have sought to punish Mr Putin and those who prop up his regime.Ms Truss said: â€œThose sanctions should only come off with a full ceasefire and withdrawal, but also commitments that there will be no further aggression.â€œAnd also, thereâ€™s the opportunity to have snapback sanctionsthere is further aggression in future. That is a real lever that I think can be used.â€Her remarks fit with those of her US counterpart Antony Blinken, who has said the travel bans and asset freezes are â€œnot designed to be permanentâ€.The secretary of state said the sanctions could â€œgo awayâ€ in the event of an â€œin effect, irreversibleâ€ withdrawal of Russian troops.

title: lace to compete at crufts for fifth time
story: A Sandwick woman and her seven-year-old dog will compete at Crufts in a Scottish team this week # for the fth time together.Sally Sanford and Lace, her Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever, will take part in the rally event on Thursday at the NEC in Birmingham.The pair are part of a Scotland team who will face Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regional teams in the inter-regional rally competition.The rally course sees dog and handler work as a pair to navigate a course of between  and  dferent exercises.Ms Sanford said the competition was always #a step-up#.#You#re asking the dogs to do stuff that isn#t that complicated for them, but it#s the handlers who need to be able to multi-task, to concentrate in the moment and navigate their way around the course.#You need your head in the game.#But she said that was one of Lace#s strengths, and said he had finished second in his event previously.The pair are hoping for another strong showing, but with Crufts taking place for the first time since March , she said there were some uncertainties.#None of us know how busy Crufts is going to be this year,# she said.#I would be lyingI said there wasn#t a degree of trepidation.#She said that she was excited for theof the #enormous# event, though, and hopes Lace will be able to inspire Scotland to better their previous best performance of third...Pet pooches are being given the chance to test their agility and obedience without even having to leave their own gardens â€“ proving that lockdownSandwick resident Sally Sanford will be appearing at the Crufts dog show this week as part of the Scottish rally team with her Nova ScotiaA dog lover from Bigton says that making the final in the Kennel Clubâ€™s Eukanuba Friends for Le competition at Crufts  would mean the#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: thousands of sheep now treated after positive scab case
story: Over , sheep in the isles have been treated for sheep scab since an imported ram was first identied as having tested positive a month ago.The treatment program for sheep scab is now said to have been completed, with a total of , sheep having been treated for sheep scab by dipping.The work was carried out by a mainland contractor with a mobile dipping facility who worked around the isles for  days with the help of a local assistant. All flocks which had potentially direct contact with the imported ram will now either have been treated or have begun a programme of testing.The emphasis will now be on surveillance.Farmers and crofters are asked to be especially vigilant and report any signs of sheep scab in their flocks to Shetland Vets.The early signs of sheep scab are rubbing, scratching, biting at flanks and tags of fleece pulled out.This can very much resemble lice infections. In more advanced cases, areas of bare and raw red skin or scabs become visible and there is also weight loss.Sheep that have been treated with a pour-on product for lice or keds but still remain itchy, should also be investigated.Further surveillance using blood testing will be available during the summer.Veterinary advisor for the council Hilary Burgess said: â€œI would like to thank the Shetland farming community for their help and co-operation with the sheep scab control operation, and most especially to thank those farmers that have gathered their sheep for testing and treatments.#I would also like to thank our contracted sheep dipping teamfor their hard work.â€œAs a precaution, we continue to advise that sharing of equipment between flocks should be kept to a minimum and equipment should be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected between holdings.â€œThe use of separate protective clothing is also strongly recommended when working on dferent flocks or, at the very least, careful cleaning and disinfection of clothing between flocks.â€œWith vigilance, care with biosecurity, and working together as a community we can look towards being clear of sheep scab once again.â€..Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.A ram imported from the mainland into a Shetland flock has tested positive for sheep scab, with the infection spreading into other animals on the#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: cecil smith to seek re election in may
story: Lerwick councillor Cecil Smith is to seek re-election on th May.Mr Smith, who has been member for Lerwick South since May , says it has been #a privilege and honour# to have represented the area.#I am standing for re-election as I feel that I still have a great deal to offer this ward and the community of Shetland,# he said.He added the next council would have #many challenges and dficult decisions to make#.#Firstly, they must get the finances in order. They cannot continue to draw on reserves to balance the books. We have been constantly told thatthis continues the reserves will become unsustainable.#He added: #Shetland is a busy place right now with some huge projects taking place and a number of large projects in the early stages of development. It is important that the council is involved in all of this to ensure the best outcome for Shetland is achieved.#Mr Smith listed education as #extremely important# # adding the council must #never lose sight of this#. #Care for our elderly and vulnerable is equally important. With the Scottish government proposal to introduce a National Care Service the council must be involved at an early stage to again ensure the best outcome for those who will be affected.#He described fixed links as #a priority# along with discussions on external ferry services.But he warned the dangers of climate change needed to be recognised.#Serious consideration has to be given to climate change # and the consequenceignored. #There has to be emphasis on the use of greener energy but there has to be a transition period allowing for sensible dialogue and employment retention.community. #All members need to work together as a team and each members voice must be heard. #This is essential to allow the Council to operate in the democratic way which the community expect.#..Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.North Isles councillor Ryan Thomson says work on fixed links should begin in the next council term.A scaled-down Remembrance Sunday ceremony was held at the Lerwick War Memorial.The political leader of Shetland Islands Council has announced he is standing down from the role. title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An TÃ¬r, An CÃ nan, â€˜S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An TÃ¬r, An CÃ nan, â€˜S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a personâ€™s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary â€“ not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection â€œa genuine product of the pastâ€ with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., â€˜blood is thicker than waterâ€™, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance â€“ strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly â€“ we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex GÃ idhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much â€“not more â€“ influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the GÃ idhealtachd connecting with the cultural â€˜myceliumâ€™ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream â€“ the carrying stream â€“ slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220324newspcr testing to come to an end for most people from next month
story: Testing will continue to play a vital role in Northern Irelandâ€™s response to the COVID- pandemic over the coming months, Health Minister Robin Swann has emphasised. The Minister announced that a more targeted approach to testing will be introduced on a phased basis from next month, with the focus on supporting and protecting those at highest risk of serious illness. Testing will continue to be available for those eligible for COVID- treatments. Under the new policy, PCR testing will cease for most people with symptoms from  April - however free lateral flow tests will continue to be available to the public to use should they develop symptoms of COVID-. Lateral flow tests will also continue to be available free of charge to support those living in, working in or visiting a higher risk setting such as a care home until the end of June, with further review then. The policy covers testing and contact tracing and takes effect from  April. No changes will be introduced until that date. The policy will be kept under review during the period of transition up until the end of June. The Health Minister stated: â€œThe new policy reflects the new realities of the pandemic. While the prevalence of the virus remains at a high level, the risk of serious illness has been signicantly reduced - thanks in no small measure to our vaccination programme and the use of innovative COVID- treatments. â€œThe risk posed by the virus at the present time does not justy testing and isolating large swathes of the population at the levels that we have seen to date in the past two years. Test and trace will continue to have a key role and will be used in a more focused and targeted way to support and protect our most vulnerable. This will be kept under very close review and we will have contingency plans in place so that we can scale up should it be required.â€ A range of changes will take effect from the  April: PCR testing will no longer be recommended or available for most people with symptoms. It will still be available to support the small group for whom it is recommended for clinical reasons. The PCR home ordering service will remain available for the general public to support those for whom PCR is recommended.Publicly accessible COVID- testing sites will close. Local Health and Social Care Trusts will continue to provide PCR testing to support clinical care.Those with symptoms will be advised to use lateral flow devicesto test instead of booking a PCR. This will be kept under review and could remain in place up to the end of June depending on disease trajectory.Routine asymptomatic testingwill continue to be advised for those living, working and visiting health and social care settings including hospitals and care homes and other high risk settings in line with public health advice. This will be kept under review.Asymptomatic LFD testing for the wider population will cease. Access to free LFDs for this purpose will cease.Routine asymptomatic workplace testing will cease.Routine asymptomatic testing in most educational settingswill cease at the Easter break.Asymptomatic testing in special schools will continue after Easter and will be kept under review. It may continue until the end of June .Routine population contact tracing will be phased out between mid-April and the end of June.  Chief Medical Officer Professor Sir Michael McBride said: â€œWe will continue throughout the transition phase to support and protect our most vulnerable. After these changes are introduced from  April, I would urge people to check on NI Directtesting remains recommended for them - for examplethey are eligible for new treatments. In the coming weeks, the Department will also be working to provide advice and support to those eligible for treatments. It is particularly important that those who are at higher risk of serious illness follow the guidance on getting tested.â€ The Chief Medical Officer added: â€œThe tools at our disposal to protect people who are at higher risk from COVID- have advanced considerably since the early days of the pandemic. Alongside the vaccine and booster programme, new COVID- treatments continue to be used by patients in Northern Ireland and new treatments are in development. â€œAs the amount of testing across society reduces, our behaviour and actions have an even more important role in preventing transmission and keeping others safe. I urge everyone to continue to follow the public health guidance including continuing to wear a face covering in enclosed settings like public transport and when visiting hospitals and care homes.â€ The changes do not take effect until  April, and current testing provision will continue until then. Please keep following the latest public health advice as set out on NI Direct.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220325newsrecommendation for post primary pupils to wear facemasks to be scrapped after easter
story: It will no longer be recommended that post-primary pupils wear a face covering in corridors or confined communal areas following the Easter break. This will result in post-primary pupils no longer being recommended to wear a face covering on school premises. The news was confirmed by Education Minister Michelle McIlveen.She said, As was the case with the change relating to the use of face coverings in classrooms, this further change takes place in the context of a broadly improving epidemiological landscape in schools. Nonetheless, COVID continues to circulate in our communities and in our schools and we should continue to reduce the risks of COVID in our schools through the range of other mitigating measures that remain in place to protect all pupils and staff.  It is for this reason thatany inidual wishes to continue to use a face covering anywhere at school, I would encourage them to do so. At this point pupils will still be recommended to wear a face covering when using public or school transport. This position will be kept under review.  A guidance note will issue to schools on this issue later today and my Departmentâ€™s COVID guidance will be updated to reflect this position.

FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueLaurence Belland his brother James at a Tyrone game. Laurence passed away last year.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailLAURENCE Bell, from the village of Coagh, was a huge fan of the Tyrone gaelic football team.For most of his adult le, he travelled to see theÂ team play, be it rain or shine, League or Championship.His brother James was always by his side. They were known by fans and ground staffÂ as they rarely missed a game.On February ,  â€“Â the same day as his we Kathleenâ€™s birthday â€“Â Laurence was admitted to hospital with coronavirus. Exactly a fortnight later, he passed away.His daughter, Cathy Costello, said theÂ hardest thing was not having people he knew and loved with him in hospital.Cathyâ€™s brother â€“ Laurenceâ€™s son Declan â€“Â died seven months earlier from a heart attack. Restricted numbers were permittedÂ at the wake and funeral.Laurence was  years old, but fit and strong for his age.His daughter Cathy believes â€œ he hadnâ€™t gotÂ Covid, heâ€™d be doing well â€“Â he had a good few years ahead of himâ€.It was bittersweet for her family when Tyrone won theÂ All-Ireland title last September.James, who said he had considered â€œnot going back to footballâ€ when Laurence passed, was persuaded to go to the final that day with a friend, but it was an emotional event for all.Laurenceâ€™s other son, Conleth, has a poignant memory of his dad being at Tyroneâ€™s winning All-Ireland final in .â€œAfter the game was over, he gave me a hug but there was a couple in front of us from Kerry with a young lad of about eight years old, and he was balling and crying.â€œMy father leaned over and he said, â€˜Listen, you will win many more. I might never see another oneâ€™.â€And sadly, he never did.Read Moreâ€˜Iâ€™ve found the whole perception over death from Covid disrespectful â€“ Basil was my brother, people have been so dismissive of title: the doctors couldnt believe daddy was going into icu because he was doing so well
story: Maureen McPartlandÂ spoke of her devastation over not being able to hold a funeral for her father, Tony MitchellExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseTony Mitchell passed away three weeks after testing positive for Covid. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTony Mitchell passed away three weeks after testing positive for Covid.Ralph HewittTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTONY MITCHELLpassed away at Craigavon Area Hospital, Co Armagh, on April , , after testing positive for Covid- three weeks earlier.â€œDaddy caught it at the start of the pandemic and was very unlucky,â€ said his daughter Maureen McParland . â€œIf he had caught it now he would have been fine, as weâ€™ve been told.â€œEverything has changed and people with Covid have had funerals and wakes, and everything that goes with the passing of loved one, whereas we have not.â€œOur family is trying to come to terms with that. When you hear about Boris Johnson partying four weeks after daddy had died,Â I just didn#t believe it.â€Mr Mitchell made a living by travelling the country to carry out building work. His daughter said he was an â€œall-rounderâ€ and could put his hand to anything.He was also a successful darts player in the s and competed against famous players such as Bobby George, John Lowe and Jocky Wilson.â€œMy daddy worked right up to the day he went into hospital,â€ said Ms McParland. â€œHe was fit and healthy. The doctors couldn#t believe that he was going into ICU because he was doing so well.â€œPeople think you have to be old or have underlying conditions but it doesn#t matter, the virus still took them.â€œItâ€™s just very, very unfair. We do all need to get back to normal but we just need to be careful.â€Mr Mitchell is survived by daughters Ann, Celia, Philomena and Maureen. He was predeceased by his we Marie.Read MoreMarried for  years, Norman and Winnie Wilkinson both succumbed to Covid within five days of each otherMost ReadMark Sykesâ€™ â€˜no-brainerâ€™ decision to title: when the ambulance drove off little did we know there would be no contact with her again
story: When Jemima George died from Covid, her daughter Roberta could not attend the funeral as she too was battling the virusExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her family FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her familyLisa SmythTwitterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJEMIMA George was the heart and soul of her family.Covid- robbed them of a beloved great grandmother. It even snatched away their chance to say a proper goodbye to her.The depth of her familyâ€™s grief made headlines earlier this year. Her son-in-law, DUP MP Jim Shannon, challenged Boris Johnson over the lockdown parties at  Downing Street which took place at the same time Ms George , from Newtownards, Co Down, lost her le to the virus in October .â€œShe was so devoted to her family, she lived for her family,â€ said Mr Shannon.â€œBirthdays, anniversaries, she never forgot any of them. Christmas was particularly special, and even though she and my father-in-law Robert were pensioners, all their savings would go to the family.â€œShe would have saved up all her coppers, silvers and pounds in a jar and there would be money for everyone at Christmas.Ms George was moved from the emergency department at the Ulster Hospital on the outskirts of east Belfast to a ward where her daughter, Roberta, was also being treated for Covid.Mr Shannon continued: â€œRoberta couldnâ€™t even go and see her mum even though they were in the same ward.â€œShe was admitted to the hospital on Monday and died on Friday.â€œIt was the horrible and cruel way that she was taken away from us [that hurt so much]. When the ambulance drove off, little did we know there would be no contact with her again.â€œRoberta couldnâ€™t even go to the funeral because she was still in hospital fighting for her le.â€œSandra was left to organise everything because Roberta was so sick. She had to even choose what family and friends could attend the funeral because we were only allowed to have  people there.â€œThat is one thing that has grieved me greatly â€“ how do you draw up a guest list for a funeral â€Read MoreSamantha Willispassed away shortly after giving birth to her fourth childMost ReadMark Sykesâ€™ â€˜no-brainerâ€™ decision to play for Republic of Ireland as dad
