Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium LucidTalk boss defends election polling as a sign of Northern Ireland becoming â€˜a normal societyâ€™LucidTalk boss says criticism of political surveys is unfairExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseA woman entering a polling station in east BelfastArlene Foster. Credit: Liam McBurneyLucidTalkâ€™s Bill White FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA woman entering a polling station in east BelfastSuzanne BreenTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWhether you come to praise or bury opinion polls, there is no doubting the central position they are starting to occupy on the political landscape here.A LucidTalk survey for the Belfastlast February showed DUP support had fallen to % â€” the lowest in two decades. It spooked the party, a leadership challenge followed, and three months later Arlene Foster was gone.Polls increasingly appear to set the agenda. The TUVâ€™s ratings rise has arguably led the DUP to harden its protocol stance and to collapse the Executive.The UUPâ€™s strong showing in successive surveys since Doug Beattie took over has surely strengthened his hand with conservative elements in the party who otherwise might have publicly aired opposition to his liberal direction.Lacklustre ratings for the SDLP in both LucidTalk and a recent Irish News University of Liverpool poll â€” putting it on just % â€” cast a shadow over the party as it prepares for Mayâ€™s Assembly election.â€œI think too much attention is given to polls in Northern Ireland,â€ Colum Eastwood said recently. Thatâ€™s an entirely understandable complaint from his viewpoint.Thereâ€™s a danger for the party that the polls become a self-fulfilling prophecy â€” the â€˜loserâ€™ label is fixed in the public mind before a single vote is cast.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up A key debate has long been whether polls simply measure public opinion or influence it.Some believe that the â€˜bandwagon effectâ€™ makes polls positively dangerous. Negative ratings are fatal as peopleâ€™s preferences sht to whoever is ahead.Rather than making informed choices, voters conform to majority opinion. The subconscious desire to join the crowd, to be on the winning side, leads them to support parties with a high level of support.Some argue that rather than being just a tool to discover the wishes of the public, polls disrupt the democratic process. Critics claim that pollsters are too powerful.Bill White, who runs LucidTalk, robustly challenges that argument. â€œDid the DUP dump Arlene Foster on the basis of last Februaryâ€™s LucidTalk poll  No,â€ he said.â€œI would be very worriedI thought that seasoned political figures made decisions based purely on a poll. It may have been a spark that led to moves against her but that would have been because it chimed with what DUP people were already hearing on the ground.â€œHad it not matched what they were being told on doorsteps it wouldnâ€™t have been taken seriously. Polls have to feel right.â€There are numerous large polling organisations in Britain. LucidTalk and Social Market Research, which conducted the Irish News University of Liverpool poll, are two Belfast-based companies carrying out political polling here.White, who worked in market research and IT in London and Dublin, set up LucidTalk in .â€œOnline polling came to London in the late s. About a decade later, I thought it was a good thing to start here,â€ he said.White was â€œgreatly encouragedâ€ by Liam Clarke, the late and highly respected political editor of the Belfast : â€œLiam would conduct his own informal polling at party conferences, asking delegates for their views on a range of topical issues.â€œHe was very data-driven and thought online polling with a really good sample size would be a big step forward.â€œBy , nearly everybody had a computer or laptop and an email address. The great thing about online polling was its confidentiality and thatâ€™s so important in a place like Northern Ireland.â€œYou do it in your own home, and you do it directly. You remove all human interaction. When you vote somebody hands you a ballot, but you mark it in the privacy of a polling booth.â€œNobody knows your views unless you choose to tell them. Polling benefits when the same approach applies.â€While occasional opinion polls were carried out in Northern Ireland during the Troubles, White says regular and political polling would have been impossible for a local company as the conflict raged.â€œSomebody would have threatened to blow your head offthey didnâ€™t like the results, particularlyit concerned a contentious and emotional an issue like the borderâ€ he said..â€œI get a bit of grief on social media nowadays. Somebody recently told me: â€˜Be careful you donâ€™t get a knock on the doorâ€™.â€œImagine what a pollster would have endured in the Seventies and Eighties here â€œIt would have been only a small minority getting upset, but it would have been a very dangerous minority.â€White says many other problems would have plagued pollsters during the Troubles: â€œWith no internet, face-to-face polling would have been necessary.â€œIt would have been challenging for interviewers to go into republican or loyalist areas, knock on doors, and ask people who they were planning to vote for. A lot of doors would have been slammed in a lot of faces.â€œIn other cases, people would have been reluctant to tell the truth about who they were voting for because they wouldnâ€™t want to offend the interviewer.â€œThey would have been reserved for fear of hurting the feelings of the questioner. Other folk would just have been genuinely nervous about opening up.â€œItâ€™s a sign of how Northern Ireland is progressing to a normal society, how the situation is calmer and more settled, that we actually can conduct regular polling on political issues.â€The few polls that were carried out during the conflict, and in the decade after the ceasefires, often signicantly under-estimated support for the DUP, and particularly Sinn Fein.A survey just before the  Westminster election put Sinn Fein on %. It secured a % vote.A poll ahead of the  Assembly election put the DUP and Sinn Fein both on %. They secured % and % respectively.The existence of the â€˜shyâ€™ Sinn Fein or DUP voter â€” reluctant to say they voted for a party considered extreme â€” skewed many polls.In Britain, politicians have made fatal mistakes based on polling.Theresa May opted for an early election in April  when the Toriesâ€™ average poll lead over Labour was % points. Fty days later, a general election resulted in a hung Parliament.White believes much criticism of polling is unfair: â€œPollsters donâ€™t have super powers, we donâ€™t predict the future.â€œA poll is only a snapshot in time. You treat a poll like the weather forecast.â€œIt says â€˜Showers in North Downâ€™, so you take an umbrella, but you donâ€™t knowitâ€™s actually going to be raining at precisely .pm when youâ€™re visiting Aunt Mabel in Bangor. Polls are about identying trends.â€White warns that polls struggle much more with the outcome of referenda than elections.â€œA referendum campaign is entirely dferent to an election campaign,â€ he added.â€œItâ€™s big and unknown. Youâ€™re spinning the roulette wheel. In Scotland the pro-independence campaign started on % â€” it was neck-and-neck near the end of the campaign. If a border poll was called here nobody knows how it would go. There are countless factors that could influence how it developed. So many people who never voted in elections would likely turn out.â€Related topicsLucidTalk pollArlene FosterTraditional Unionist VoiceNI ProtocolThe Executive OfficeUlster Unionist PartyDoug Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumUnionism remains as ided in  as it was in , now it might be too late to do things dferentlyAlex KaneFty years on from the closing of Northern Irelandâ€™s House of Commons and the problems look much the same for unionism, writes Alex KaneExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePicture taken during the last sitting NI House of Commons. Faulkner and other Cabinet ministers address a mass rally of Vanguard supporters from the balcony of StormontThe Prime Minister Brian Faulkner with members of his cabinet in . Credit: Charles CockcroftStormont. Credit: Kevin Scott   Belfast  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePicture taken during the last sitting NI House of Commons. Faulkner and other Cabinet ministers address a mass rally of Vanguard supporters from the balcony of StormontMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAt .pm, on March , , Northern Irelandâ€™s House of Commons adjourned. It was never to meet again. Two days later the NI Temporary Provisions Act became law, introducing direct rule, ending  years of unionist government, bringing devolution to a stop and shutting down NIâ€™s Parliament. It was the biggest crisis for unionism since the  Home Rule Bill.At lunchtime on March , Brian Faulkner, destined to be NIâ€™s last Prime Minister, led his Cabinet onto the balcony to address the enormous crowdwhich had gathered in the grounds. He had only a loudspeaker.â€œPeople of Ulster, I am speaking to you still as Prime Minister of Northern Ireland. I want to say, not just on my own behalf, but on behalf of every one of my colleagues in the Government and the Parliamentary Party here at Stormont, that we understand absolutely the feelings which have persuaded you to come out to Parliament Buildings todayâ€¦ we share the resentment that you feel. We have tremendous power.â€œOur power is the power of our numbers our power is the justice of our cause our power is the responsibility of our conduct. Let us never play the game of the murderers of the IRA. Let us show the world that, so far as we are concerned, violence and intimidation are out. British we are and British we remain!â€The previous day Faulkner had addressed an emergency meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council, informing it that his government had lost confidence in Edward Heathâ€™s administration.By his own admission it was an angry meeting seething at what was regarded as a betrayal and surrender to unionismâ€™s enemies. But he also warned them to shun violent responses and rely, instead, on the â€˜Unionist vetoâ€™ which lay in the strength of their numbers.Exactly  years later, on Monday March , the present Assembly will be dissolved in preparation for an election on May . There are many within the unionist community who believe that, like its predecessor on March , , this institution will not meet again.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Political unionism is again seething with anger, believing that another Conservative government has betrayed it and rolled over to the demands of those who want Northern Ireland removed from the United Kingdom. Indeed, they would argue that the process of removal has been advanced by a protocol which traps Northern Ireland in some sort of constitutional halfway house between Great Britain, the Republic of Ireland and the European Union.When Brian Faulkner spoke of unionism relying on the strength of its numbers it was at a time when the combined pro-Union vote hovered around two-thirds of the overall vote.At the election for the first post-NI Parliament Assembly, in June , the pro-Union votewas %. In the  Assembly election that votehad reduced to .%.That election also saw unionism reduced to a minority within an NI Parliament and Assembly: and there is now a possibility, come May , that unionism wonâ€™t even have the numbers to qualy for the position of First Minister.And yet unionism remains as ided now as it was back in . The narrowing of the demographic gap between unionism and nationalism, along with an ongoing reluctance by successive British governments to be seen to be what might be described as pro-active on behalf of unionism, hasnâ€™t pushed it in the direction of prioritising a coherent, collective, long-term strategy for survival.Even the thundering hammer-blows rained down on the DUP by Boris Johnson continue to be greeted with fairly mild responses from the party leadership.Speaking on Monday evening Jeffrey Donaldson acknowledged the problem: â€œItâ€™s not a question of throwing the DUP under the bus. The Prime Minister threw Northern Ireland under the bus and the harm that this protocol has done to Northern Ireland is, I think, something the Prime Minister now recognises. But we need him to do something about it.â€The problem, of course, is that Donaldson has been saying this since September last yearand Johnson has done nothing. Heâ€™ll continue to do nothing until May : and, in all likelihood, will do nothing after that, either.In March  Brian Faulkner and the UUP decided to risk the collapse of the NI Parliament rather than allow control of security to pass from the NI government to Westminster.A few days before Stormont was prorogued Faulkner had written to Edward Heath: â€˜We wish to point out with a sense of the heavy responsibility involved that the imposition of this proposal, involving as it will the resignation of the Government of Northern Ireland as a whole, may have the gravest consequences, the full extent of which cannot now be foreseen.â€™We now know the primary consequence of the resignation and subsequent prorogation: the end of majority rule, the introduction of mandatory power-sharingand the sapping of unionist confidence that their future position within the United Kingdom was, to all intents and purposes, secure.What Faulkner did â€” although I fully understand why he had to do it â€” was hand over the political negotiating process to a British government which was determined to build an entirely dferent relationship with its Irish counterpart.In his biography, Memoirs of a Statesman , Faulkner hinted at regrets: â€œ... when unionists of vision tried to stimulate new thinking and broaden the appeal of unionism in the s s I did not come out and support them. I did not think they were achieving anything useful...but we should have spent more time watering the roots of tolerance.â€œWe did not take the initiative in reforming our society until events forced change on us. By  we were reacting to events rather than controlling them and one was always conscious of running very fast merely to make up lost ground.â€™Since then, a number of other unionist loyalist leaders have voiced fairly similar regrets. Sometimes about their own personal lack of foresight and sometimes about opportunities which unionism may have missed over the decades.Yet as Faulkner noted, there was always a sense that unionism was a few steps behind the thinking of others when it came to mapping out Northern Irelandâ€™s post- future. Or, as former UUP leader Reg Empey put it, â€œevery time unionism walks from the table it inevitably and iniably s to another table with a weaker handâ€.In the early s a Minister of State based in the NIO told me: â€œThe problem with unionism â€” and itâ€™s a particular problem for those outside Northern Ireland who try to understand it â€” is that there are far too many ieties. They spend as much time complaining about their unionist rivals as they do complaining about their more specic political and constitutional opponents.â€From until the collapse of Stormont in  the isions could mostly be controlled by the mantra â€” â€˜United we stand. Divided we fall.â€™ But once the fall came there was nothing to hold unionism together and it splintered and continues to splinter.Faulkner and power-sharing were destroyed by the United Ulster Unionist Council in . Shortly afterwards the ious members of the UUUC â€” who couldnâ€™t come up with an agreed alternative to the Sunningdale deal â€” turned on themselves.The UUP descended into civil war between -. The loyalist paramilitary groups, essential to the â€˜sellingâ€™ of the Good Friday Agreement, have now withdrawn support for it. The DUP has had a horrible  months and is still beset with internal dficulties.A growing element of younger loyalism is pushing its anti-protocol campaigning towards prioritising the final collapse of the GFA institutions. And Jeffrey Donaldson and Jim Allisterhave laid down pre-election preconditions on both the protocol and the eventuality of a Sinn Fein First Minister.Change a few names and organisations and we could be talking about that period from March  to May  â€” when unionism and loyalism were struggling to find a route map from the crisis forced on them by widespread political societal instability and British governments which were determined to impose change upon them.But hereâ€™s the reality:the strategies and policies adopted by unionists didnâ€™t work back then, why does anyone think terribly similar strategies and policies would work today: particularly when the constitutional crisis is worse now than then and the shadow of a border poll is hanging over every aspect of the coming election.A British state paper released in  had this assessment of the  Assembly election: â€˜Mr Faulknerâ€™s position is undoubtedly dficult. He will have less than half of the Protestant vote behind him, as Dr Paisley and others will no doubt vocerously remind him,and when he makes an effort to work the new system.â€œIt was always to be anticipated that the Protestant vote would be fragmentedâ€¦ but the outcome has left the potential accepters weaker and the â€˜wreckersâ€™ stronger than expected.â€™Something very similar happened to David Trimble in , allowing his internal and external opponents to destroy him. Might the same thing be about to happen to Jeffrey Donaldson  Between  and  the DUP vote represented a majority of unionist votes cast â€” but even then, the party had to temper a lot of decisions and steer away from potential compromises and concessions. If the DUP doesnâ€™t represent the majority of unionist votes cast and seats won in the Assembly on May  it will make it very dficult for Donaldson to reboot the executive.We seem to be on â€˜the more things change, the more they stay the sameâ€™ territory for unionism. Again. But there is one dference. I was in that crowd in the grounds of Stormont on March , , a few months short of my th birthday.I recognised the scale of the shock: but I also recognised something , a new opportunity for unionism to do things dferently. My big fear today â€” and Iâ€™m very pessimistic, by the way, about a rebooted Assemblyâ€” is that unionism may have left it too late to do things dferently.Related topicsIRAAlliance PartyBoris
