title: ben lowry the weather has been almost as good as it can be for here
story: UVF in frame for north Belfast bomb hoax chaos where hijack victim was made to fear for his family   Bryson dubs Simon Coveney a â€˜meddling aggressorâ€™ saying the Dublin government â€˜swans around NI asthey own the placeâ€™NewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionBen Lowry: The weather has been almost as good as it can be for hereThe weather this week has been almost as good as it can be on the island of Ireland, as in the picture above.By The NewsroomSaturday, th March , : pmUpdated Saturday, th March , : pm  "       "  The fine weather across Britain and Ireland was enjoyed by these women, taking it in turns to jump off of the rocks at the Forty foot in South Dublin on Thursday. Photo: Damien Storan PA WireWhile it can of course get much hotter in summer than it was over the last few days, there is an extra joy to fine weather at this point in the calendar and at this latitude.We are now seeing the days not merely en, but begin to stretch in what seems like strides. Suddenly you will experience the rays of the sun coming down at an angle, and with a force, which you have not seen since well before the winter.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The clocks change tonight which mean that the nights will be even brighter and longer.And so we are just at the beginning of that phase of the year where in Northern Ireland we benefit from being so far north. Expats from here always seem to remember our super long May and June evenings. â€¢ Ben Lowryis News Letter editorâ€¢ Ben Lowry main column: It has been another week that highlighted the legacy scandalhttps:www.newsletter news opinion columnists ben-lowry-it-has-been-another-week-that-highlighted-the-legacy-scandal-

title: big interview jay osmond on his new stage show the osmonds a new musical coming to the grand opera house
story: It is wrong to put the Republic of Irelandâ€™s founders on display at Stormont   â€˜Savage and unprovoked sectarian attackâ€™ on -year-old boy condemnedNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleBig Interview: Jay Osmond on his new stage show, The Osmonds: A New Musical coming to the Grand Opera HouseA new musical about vocal harmony group, the Osmonds, will be staged at the Grand Opera House next month. HELEN MCGURK talks to its creator, Jay OsmondBy Helen McGurkFriday, th March , : pm  "       "  Jay Osmond in Belfast for the launch of The Osmonds: A New Musical at the Grand Opera Houseâ€œOur song Crazy Horses was banned in South Africa because they thought it was about drugs. I said, â€˜Really  Câ€™mon, weâ€™re The Osmonds.â€ laughs Jay Osmond, flashing that famous toothsome megawatt Osmonds smile.The fourth youngest of the nine-strong Osmond family, sees the absurdity of the accusation because as everyone knows, the Mormon minstrels were a famously squeaky-clean band of brothers, eschewing rock and rollâ€™s twin evils of drink and drugs, to produce wholesome, harmony-drenched pop tunes.Jay Osmond, , is in Belfast to talk about his upcoming show The Osmonds: A New Musical at the Grand Opera House.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.He describes it as a â€œliving memoirâ€, which tells the true story of how the five brothers from Utah were pushed into the spotlight as children and went on to achieve superstardom, selling over  million records and winning  gold and platinum awards in the process.â€œIt has taken me five years to put it together,â€ says Jay. â€œCondensing more than  years into a two-hour show, with almost  songs, was the hard part. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s so fast-paced.â€œItâ€™s not a concert or a tribute band show, or even a juke box musical. I take people on a musical journey through what it was like from my point of view. Itâ€™s about the ups and downs, the highs and lows, the good times, the bad times. So much happens.â€ALL THE HITS The musical features a chart-topping list of anthems including Love Me For A Reason, Let Me In, Puppy Love, One Bad Apple, Long Haired Lover From Liverpool, Paper Roses and many more, taking audiences back to relive the s, s and s.â€œItâ€™s like a time machine. People say it makes them feel like  again,â€ he says. Jay was the drummer for the family quintet. He also shared lead vocals on the hard rock, musically ergent, Crazy Horses, which was about gas-guzzling cars, rather than narcotics. According to Jay, his father George, a World War II veteran, was the â€œbackboneâ€ of the group and he wishes he, and his mother Olive, were still alive to see the musical.â€œThe hardest part of this show is how to portray my father. Mother was pretty easy because she was always positive and very upbeat.â€œMy father was an army sergeant and he was a good disciplinarian, but he wasnâ€™t abusive in any way. He was very strong and tender at the same time. My father was a great man. Heâ€™s been the most dficult one to cast for.â€George Osmond instilled a firm set of values in his children - faith, family and career - in that order. â€œWhenever we were up against anything it was always in that priority system. And we had a voting system and a way of working out problems.â€There are scenes in the musical which Jay still gets emotional watching. â€œA lot of people donâ€™t know what we were up against as a family. Thereâ€™s one scene where we have a family meeting - and without giving too much away, itâ€™s really tough... you can hear a pin drop, itâ€™s so quiet when the audience is listening.â€œYou wouldnâ€™t believe some of the obstacles we overcame as a family. It would have broken most families in a normal situation.â€ CLEAN-LIVING The Osmondsâ€™ vocal harmonising is technically on the same level as the Beach Boys and the Beatles . Unfortunately, they werenâ€™t take as seriously as those bands. Did their devout faith prevent them being a credible musical force â€œWe were up against nightmare stuff. We were told even back in the s that we would never make it in rock n roll because we didnâ€™t smoke or drink or take drugs,â€ says Jay. â€œBut, my father said persistence and determination are the two keys that make success and thatâ€™s we did, we persisted and were determined. This musical shows how hard we worked.â€ His brothers Donny and Merrill have seen clips of the show and have given it their seal of approval. â€œI received an email the other day from Donny and he said â€˜I am blown away - especially with the reviewsâ€™. He said â€˜I knew you could to itâ€™.â€œThen I got one about a month go from Merill saying â€˜Proud of you, Jayâ€™.â€œFive years ago when the producer came to me with the ideaI went to my brother Merrill and said I think this is really amazing, we have a great opportunity to tell our story, but he couldnâ€™t because of a project he was working on, but he said â€˜I know you can do itâ€™.â€œAt first I was a little depressed about it because I never thought I could do this on my own, I always had a brother to do things with me, but itâ€™s amazing how itâ€™s come out. â€œAfter five years of seeing it on paper, and then to see your le acted out on stage, how surreal that was to me, and still is.â€The whole process, he says, has been a kind of â€œtherapyâ€ for him. â€œAnd thank goodness for my journals. My mother was adamant about us writing in journals.â€Itâ€™s been a long road to get the musical from concept to stage, but Jay is clearly chuffed with the result. â€œI think of all the projects I have ever done, this is the one I am most pleased with,â€ he says, that signature Osmond smile lighting up the room.The Osmonds: A New Musical, opens at the Grand Opera House, on April . Ticket Booking: https:www.goh whats-on the-osmonds-a-new-musical  A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.With the coronavirus lockdowns having had a major impact on many of our advertisers â€” and consequently the revenue we receive â€” we are more reliant than ever on you taking out a digital subscription.Subscribe to newsletter and enjoy unlimited access to the best Northern Ireland and UK news and information online and on our app. With a digital subscription, you canthan  articles, see fewer ads, enjoy faster load times, and get access to exclusive newsletters and content. Visit https:www.newsletter subscriptionsnow to sign up.Our journalism costs money and we rely on advertising, print and digital revenues to help to support them. By supporting us, we are able to support you in providing trusted, fact-checked content for this website.Ben Lowry, Editor

title: marissa callaghan supporting mums in sport on mothers day
story: It is wrong to put the Republic of Irelandâ€™s founders on display at Stormont   â€˜Savage and unprovoked sectarian attackâ€™ on -year-old boy condemnedNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleMarissa Callaghan supporting mums in sport on Motherâ€™s DayAs many mothers enjoy breakfast in bed this weekend Marissa Callaghan will be preparing for the biggest sporting challenge of her career.By Helen McGurkFriday, th March , : pm  "       "  Marissa Callaghan and her son QuinnWhen Marissa Callaghan ties her football boots tomorrow sheâ€™ll be lasered focused on the training session at hand. Such dedication is a hallmark of the Northern Ireland football captainâ€™s career and has led her to making history with her squad as they head to the Womenâ€™s Euro  finals. But ahead of Motherâ€™s Day she also has an inspiring, important message for the next generation of female sporting stars - being both mother and top athlete is possible.Marissa said: â€œItâ€™s so important for women in sport to know thatthey want to have kids it can happen. That women do believe it is possible to have kids and have a career in sport.â€   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Marissa Callaghan, partner Paula and son QuinnShe added: â€œThere are women of all ages who have gone away and had babies and come back. On our team we have Sarah McFadden, and she has a wee girl Harper, . She came back and played an international match three months after she gave birth. â€œItâ€™s raising the awareness and telling the stories that it is possible so we can inspire the next generation of women in sport.â€Growing up in west Belfast in a time when an international womenâ€™s football side wasnâ€™t even in existence, never mind a possibility, itâ€™s little wonder the passionate player has become a role model for women in sport and for the next generation of female athletes.â€œI do take pride in inspiring the next generation of girls coming up,â€ said Marissa.â€œFootball has given me so much in my journey, I love to show young girls that itâ€™s a great sport to be in. But not just football but any sport â€“ the le lessons you learn â€“ you canâ€™t put a price on it. â€œFootballâ€™s my passion and I just want to let young girls know that football is great for your mental and physical health. I donâ€™t know where I would be without it.â€However, despite great strides being made in sport the statistics show there is still work to do. A signicant gap between men and women taking part in sport still exists, with women less likely to have taken part in sport at least once within the last year, %, than men, %. Unfortunately, according to Sport NI figures this gap gets wider on our sidelines with women representing just .% of the overall sports coaching workforce in Northern Ireland and this dropping to just % for those who coach our World, Olympic or Paralympic medallists.To help close this gap Sport NI recently launched their Women In Sport Panel that sees women from dferent sporting backgrounds offering their expertise on how to overcome barriers and create more opportunities for women and girls at all levels of sport.Marissa believes that listening to women and funding in sport are key factors in closing the gap.â€œItâ€™s so important to listen to women from all levels of sport to be able to improve experiences and see what we can do better. This  also gives visibility to women who are in sport, coaching, leadership, and governance levels. That is so very important for females to see these real-le scenarios and see that itâ€™s possible to achieve these roles.â€Marissa points to Angela Platt, Irish Football AssociationDirector of Womenâ€™s Football and Women In Sport Panel member, as an inspiring example.â€œIt is very powerful to have a female in the directorâ€™s role and to have that role created for the first time, especially as football is still very male dominated,â€ she said.The Cltonville player coach, who is mum to Quinn, , seems to have found the enviable balance between family le and her job on the pitch. Sheâ€™s quick to credit her supportive partner Paula and the recent funding from the IFA, sponsors, and the Department for Communitiesfor helping make that work â€“ le balance happen.â€œIn January we got fully funded to train professionally. So those who were working fulltime got put on secondment and are training up at Newforgefulltime,â€ she explained.It means that Marissaâ€™s job as the IFAâ€™s Girlsâ€™ Participation Officer has been put on hold until September, after the World Cup qualiers next month and the Euros in July. â€œThat has been a massive gamechanger for me.â€Not only is it allowing Marissa, and the rest of the womenâ€™s international team to concentrate on their game, but for the captain sheâ€™s getting precious time with her little boy.â€œIâ€™m able to drop him off and pick him up at creche. We get home, make dinner and have normal family le. Whereas before we got the investment to go fulltime you were working in your day job and were out most evenings. My partner was doing an awful lot whereas now itâ€™s nice to have that family time. â€œIâ€™m fortunate to have a supportive partner there who understands what it means to play at this level. Obviously, we go away a lot so that can be tough. â€œBut at the same time, I know that I do it for the love of the game â€“ itâ€™s my thing. For our Quinn, I just think it will be amazing for him to look back on. I know heâ€™s only two now but at least Iâ€™ll have a great story to tell him. Itâ€™s better for him to believe he can do anything.â€œWe as the womenâ€™s international team have made our dreams come true in what we have achieved. I think itâ€™s important for him to see his mum achieve what we have achieved and hopefully that will inspire him when heâ€™s older.â€As Quinn chats away in the background Marissa reveals heâ€™s already showing some promise with his feet.â€œQuinn loves football. We have footballs of all sizes and shapes here. Heâ€™s â€˜mama footballâ€™ and we play away. He does associate football with me so when football is on TV, heâ€™s â€˜mama, mama.â€™â€As for now Marissa is the first to admit sheâ€™s â€œliving the dreamâ€.She has the Euros to look forward to and the World Cup qualiers coming up against Austria, April , and England, April .â€œWeâ€™re solely focused on getting into that squad and getting the squad prepared for those big games. Theyâ€™re two unbelievable sides and two massive games so we have to make sure weâ€™re fully ready for it,â€ she added.â€œThe momentum weâ€™ve built here within the womenâ€™s game here is incredible. If you look back three years ago, we would have had maybe  people watching us play. Obviously off the back of our success and qualying for the Euros there are over , tickets sold for the England game at Windsor. â€œItâ€™s really hard to believe. I definitely think itâ€™ll be an emotional day when weâ€™re there at Windsor with that many fans.â€œThereâ€™s a lot to look forward to.â€A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: meet conor burns the north belfast catholic unionist in the northern ireland office
story: UVF in frame for north Belfast bomb hoax chaos where hijack victim was made to fear for his family   Bryson dubs Simon Coveney a â€˜meddling aggressorâ€™ saying the Dublin government â€˜swans around NI asthey own the placeâ€™NewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleMeet Conor Burns â€“ the north Belfast Catholic unionist in the Northern Ireland OfficeMinister of State for Northern Ireland and Belfast native Conor Burns talks to HENRY McDONALD on the ambition of changing the Protocol as well as the governmentâ€™s plans for dealing with Legacy issues:By Henry McDonaldSaturday, th March , : pm  "       "  Pacemaker Press --: Tory MP Conor Burns pictured in Castle Gardens in north Belfast where they used to live. Picture By: Arthur Allison Pacemaker Press.For Conor Burns his native Belfast to him is still as constitutionally British as his Bournemouth parliamentary constituency.Catholic, Northern Irish, unionist and gay, the Minister of State for Northern Ireland says he is as opposed to the potential annexation of the Province by the EU as he would bethe English south coast resort unilaterally fell under Brusselsâ€™ control.In an interview with the News Letter, Mr Burns was askedhe understood unionist anger over how the Protocol is exercising increasing influence over Northern Ireland.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.--: Conor Burns, Minister of State for Northern Ireland, pictured with Henry McDonald at the News Letter offices in Belfast. Picture By: Arthur Allison Pacemaker Pressâ€œCan I say to you and through you to your readers that absolutely I feel that, the Secretary of State feels that, the Foreign Secretary feels that, the Prime Minister feels that and that is why we why we have set out the ambition of coming to a negotiated change in the Protocol, to make it something that does reflect the unique circumstances of this island â€“ which has two territorial jurisdictions, one in the European Union, one not. â€œAnd while there is the legitimate aspiration of the European Union to protect their Single Market we elevate the core validity of protecting the Single Market of the United Kingdom. So, when you ask meI get itI didnâ€™t get it we would not have set the ambition of changing the Protocol,â€ he said.Speaking just  hours before a loyalist paramilitary bomb scare forced Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney to abandon a speech in north Belfast and be whisked away by police to a secure location, Mr Burns condemned any moves to violently resist the Protocol.â€œThis society has not thrived when threats of violence are used to achieve a political objective.â€On the continued existence of the Protocol in its present form where more than  EU rules now govern Northern Irelandâ€™s economic and commercial le, Mr Burns said: â€œI have to say that we cannot go on indefinitely and one of the things that everyone who is engaged with the European Commission and the EU member states on this has been clear - the Protocol is not currently commanding cross-community support here in Northern Ireland. â€œAnd when something is not broadly accepted by both traditions here it is rarely a good thing for Northern Ireland. A change there has to be and we have also been incredibly clear, the Secretary of Statehas made this clear, the PM has made this clear, Liz Truss has made it clear that we have been very concerned that the application of the Protocol was having a de-stabilising effect on the governance and the stability here in Northern Ireland, and there needs to be change.â€The Minister of State said he knows that the EUâ€™s chief negotiator on the Protocol Maros Sefcovic has been warned about this de-stabilisation during his visits to the Province.He denied that the Governmentâ€™s eyes were off the Protocol ball now that it is dealing with the war in Ukraine and its consequences for European and global security. Mr Burns also insisted that the Government was still prepared to trigger Article  which could put a temporary stop to the Protocol and its outworkings.A close ally of Boris Johnson, the Minister said: â€œThe Prime Minister wants the EU to undertand that we did not use Article  as an act of good faith to show we want to get a sustainable and lasting solution. I hope the EU are hearing us. The Prime Minister is very clear about this that there is nothing that is off the table.â€Mr Burns defended the Northern Ireland Secretaryâ€™s plans for dealing with Legacy issues related to the Troubles including shting from investigations into the conflict from criminal inquiries into a truth recovery scheme.â€œYou know the easiest thing to do on Legacy would be to do nothing and I actually think the Secretary of State and the Prime Minister deserve credit for seeking to enter this space and find a way to help this society especially for some of those most affected by the Troubles.â€Reflecting on Legacy Mr Burns casts his mind back to August  and the Real IRA Omagh bomb massacre which occured during one of his visits to his relations.â€œI remember being in my grandmaâ€™s living room on the day of the Omagh bombing and finding out that one of my cousinâ€™s children was in Omagh that day. There was this absolutely overwhelming sense of fear especially when all the lines to Omagh went down as we tried to get through.â€He still sees most of his family the majority of whom are very comfortable with their Catholic cousin being a British minister arguing for the merits of the Union. Only two relations who are republicans have made it clear they do not wish to see him, Mr Burns said.â€œLetâ€™s just say they are not paid up members of the Tory No Turning Back group,â€ he added.A past pupil of the Christian Brothers run Park Lodge Primary School on Belfastâ€™s Antrim Road, he revealed that he once considered entering the priesthood.He cited the late Pope John Paul II alongside Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan as both his heroes and his reason to join the Tory Party even before he turned  because of their â€œdefence of the values of inidual freedomâ€ against the Soviet Union during the Cold War.Mr Burns came out as gay in his mid s and acknowledges that it was Tony Blair and New Labour who â€œturbo charged social changeâ€ to in turn liberalise attitudes towards gay people in the Conservative Party.He describes himself as having a â€œmulti-facted identity. I am a Catholic, I am gay, I support the Union, I am a Conservative, I would still call myself a Thatcherite, I am Northern Irish, I am Irish, I am British.â€ More from the News Letter:Click here: Detectives call for information to help crack notorious murder case which saw Protestant minister beaten with nail-studded bats  years agoClick here: Protest at Belfast factory over â€˜ludicrous nature of arms tradeâ€™ with equipment built by Thales being used by both Ukraine AND RussiaClick here: Plan unveiled for huge expansion of Co Antrim village bringing hundreds of new residentsClick here:Joe Biden tells St Patrickâ€™s Day gathering: I may be Irish but Iâ€™m not stupidâ€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: pcr testing to end for most people in northern ireland next month
story: Great news as busy Belfast route is reopened after ongoing incident   Detectives call for information to help crack notorious murder case which saw Protestant minister beaten with nail-studded bats  years agoNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeoplePCR testing to end for most people in Northern Ireland next monthPCR testing for most people with Covid- symptoms will stop in Northern Ireland from April .By Jonathan McCambridgeThursday, th March , : pmUpdated Thursday, th March , : pm  "       "  Health Minister Robin Swann has announced a number of changes to policy, which will include the closure of publicly accessible Covid testing sites.Mr Swann said a â€œmore targeted approachâ€ to testing will be introduced on a phased basis from next month, with the focus on supporting and protecting those at highest risk of serious illness.He added that testing will continue to be available for those eligible for Covid treatments.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.A health worker gets a swab sample from a man for a PCR test for Covid- detectionUnder the new policy, PCR testing will cease for most people with symptoms from April , although free lateral flow tests will continue to be available to the public to use should they develop symptoms.Lateral flow tests will also continue to be available free of charge to support those living in, working in or visiting a higher risk setting such as a care home until the end of June, with a further review then.The minister said: â€œThe new policy reflects the new realities of the pandemic.â€œWhile the prevalence of the virus remains at a high level, the risk of serious illness has been signicantly reduced â€“ thanks in no small measure to our vaccination programme and the use of innovative Covid- treatments.â€œThe risk posed by the virus at the present time does not justy testing and isolating large swathes of the population at the levels that we have seen to date in the past two years.â€œTest and trace will continue to have a key role and will be used in a more focused and targeted way to support and protect our most vulnerable.â€œThis will be kept under very close review and we will have contingency plans in place so that we can scale up should it be required.â€The changes include:â€“ PCR testing will no longer be recommended or available for most people with symptoms. It will still be available to support the small group for whom it is recommended for clinical reasons. The PCR home ordering service will remain available for the general public to support those for whom PCR is recommended.â€“ Publicly accessible Covid- testing sites will close. Local health and social care trusts will continue to provide PCR testing to support clinical care.â€“ Those with symptoms will be advised to use lateral flow devicesto test instead of booking a PCR.â€“ Routine asymptomatic testing will continue to be advised for those living, working and visiting health and social care settings, including hospitals and care homes and other high risk settings.â€“ Asymptomatic LFD testing for the wider population will cease. Access to free LFDs for this purpose will cease.â€“ Routine asymptomatic workplace testing will cease.â€“ Routine asymptomatic testing in most educational settingswill cease at the Easter break.â€“ Asymptomatic testing in special schools will continue after Easter and will be kept under review. It may continue until the end of June.â€“ Routine population contact tracing will be phased out between mid-April and the end of June.Chief Medical Officer Sir Michael McBride said: â€œWe will continue throughout the transition phase to support and protect our most vulnerable.â€œAfter these changes are introduced from April , I would urge people to check on NI Directtesting remains recommended for them â€“ for examplethey are eligible for new treatments.â€œIn the coming weeks, the department will also be working to provide advice and support to those eligible for treatments. It is particularly important that those who are at higher risk of serious illness follow the guidance on getting tested.â€œThe tools at our disposal to protect people who are at higher risk from Covid- have advanced considerably since the early days of the pandemic.â€œAlongside the vaccine and booster programme, new Covid- treatments continue to be used by patients in Northern Ireland and new treatments are in development.â€œAs the amount of testing across society reduces, our behaviour and actions have an even more important role in preventing transmission and keeping others safe.â€œI urge everyone to continue to follow the public health guidance, including continuing to wear a face covering in enclosed settings like public transport and when visiting hospitals and care homes.â€Robin SwannNorthern IrelandPCR  "       "  Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a daily public interest bulletin to deliver all the updates and vital information to your story: It is wrong to put the Republic of Irelandâ€™s founders on display at Stormont   â€˜Savage and unprovoked sectarian attackâ€™ on -year-old boy condemnedNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsNI could yet make pitch for role in joint Euro  bidStormont officials are continuing to work towards supporting Northern Irelandâ€™s participation in a joint UK and Ireland bid to host the  European Championships football tournament, the department involved has said.By Mark Rainey and David YoungFriday, th March , : pm  "       "  Following reports on Friday that DUP Economy Minister Gordon Lyons was not in a position to support the bid, a spokesperson for his department said he remains committed to the proposal.In a letter to remaining Executive ministers, seen by the PA news agency, Mr Lyons acknowledges the political situation in Northern Ireland means support cannot be offered to the tournament bid.Northern Ireland could potentially host seven matchesit was involved in a successful bid for the Euros. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply." "" width"" srcset"https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMNTUzNjgz.jpg width w, https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMNTUzNjgz.jpg width w" layout"intrinsic" class"i-amphtml-layout-intrinsic i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"intrinsic"" fallback layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"The Henri Delaunay trophy is displayed prior to the Uefa Euro  final in Paris. â€œThe cross-cutting nature of Northern Ireland participation in the Euros and the lack of both a decision-making mechanism and agreed budget means NI cannot provide â€˜in principle supportâ€™ for the bid at this stage,â€ Mr Lyons wrote.He said while Northern Ireland would need to invest around Â£ million, the majority of which would be spent from  onwards, there would be a potential economic benefit of such an investment.â€œThe main obstacles to Northern Irelandâ€™s participation in the Euros remain the lack of stadium capacity and clarity on and provision for the substantial costs,â€ he wrote.The National Stadium at Windsor Park in Belfast has a capacity of , â€“ signicantly short of the , minimum required for hosting games at the Euros.Matches could potentially be staged at the GAAâ€™s nearby Casement Park, but it currently lies derelict. A plan to redevelop the venue into a ,-capacity stadium has been beset by delay and controversy.The contents of the letter provoked a backlash from other executive parties, including UUP MLA Mike Nesbitt who claimed Mr Lyons was acting prematurely in discounting support for the bid, and Sinn Feinâ€™s John Finucane who said a â€œcan do attitudeâ€ was needed.However, a Department for Economy spokesperson later told the News Letter that â€œdepartmental officials remain involved in the process,â€ and added: â€œThe Minister fully supports our involvement in any bid, but, as Northern Ireland enters the pre-election period it will be for a new Executive to formally agree our participations.â€œWhile there are clearly obstacles in place at the moment, the Minister is confident these can be title: premature to end ni involvement in bid for euro  mike nesbitt
story: Detectives call for information to help crack notorious murder case which saw Protestant minister beaten with nail-studded bats  years ago   â€˜Savage and unprovoked sectarian attackâ€™ on -year-old boy condemnedNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsPremature to end NI involvement in bid for Euro : Mike NesbittIt is too soon for Northern Ireland to rule itself out of a joint bid to host the Euro  finals, UUP MLA Mike Nesbitt has said.By Mark RaineyFriday, th March , : amUpdated Friday, th March , : am  "       "  Mr Nesbitt was commenting after Stormontâ€™s Economy Minister Gordon Lyons said that the lack of a ing executive and budget in place means Northern Ireland cannot be part of the bid along with the other UK regions and the Republic of Ireland. In a letter to other Stormont ministers, the DUPâ€™s Mr Lyons cites the lack of stadiums with the required capacity to host matches as one of the main reasons.The letter, which has been seen by the BBC, says work is continuing to finalise the cost benefit assessment of NI hosting seven matches.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The Euros trophyEstimates suggest than an investment of just over Â£ million will bring aof Â£ million.Mr Nesbitt said there is a precedent from the bid for the  Rugby World Cup.â€œDuring a previous period when the Executive was down, the then Head of the Civil Service found a workaround, whereby the leaders of the Executive parties signed a commitment to confirm thatthe Executive had been in place, it would back the finances necessary for the bid.â€œThis was accepted by the decision makers, although in the end the event was awarded to France.â€UUP MLA Mike NesbittMr Nesbitt added: â€œGiven the hundreds of millions of pounds a successful bid could generate for the local economy, the Economy Minister must withdraw his claim and work collaboratively with the party leaders to progress the bid for the benefit of the people he was elected to serve.â€READ: UK and Ireland submit initial bid for Euro  - what happens next â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: sports direct reveals uks loved sports teams including arsenal chelsea
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityThe sports retailer analysed teams associated with leagues across eight sports from up and down the country and crafted a list based on a number of critical factors.The researchers looked at everything from the teams brand sentiment on social media to its number of online searches.The ranking was also constructed by looking at online mentions, social following and fan engagement.Sports Direct store. Credit: PA "Sports Teams are the bread and butter of the sporting world," the sportswear brand said.It added: "They matter immensely to fans and to iniduals themselves, but which ones are the most loved across the UK "Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â :Â Six Nations referees  - meet the refs assigned to every game:Â Winter Olympics: Triumphant curling teams land in ScotlandÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â Sports Direct has rounded up the UKs most popular sports and its definitely an interesting mix.Most Loved Sports. Credit: Sports Direct Unsurprisingly, Football tops the list withÂ an average of ,, loves on social media, the retailer has confirmed.Coming in second and third is Rugby League and Union respectively and rounding up the ranking is Athletics.FootballRugby LeagueRugby UnionIce HockeyCricketNetballRowingAthleticsDid you know that you can shop by sport on the Sports Direct websiteIf youre looking for gear and equipment to try out a new sport, youllÂ find all the kits you could possibly need in the ious sports categories on its website.Â Whether youre a running rookie or youre nuts about the NFL, Sports Direct can keep you right.Â .removeShop the collection via the Sports Direct website.Top  sports in the UK. Credit: Sports Direct Sports Direct has crafted its top  list and we arent surprised to see Football dominate the top  spots of the most popular sports teams in the UK.Â However, youll find other sports teams in the ranking this year with beloved Ice Hockey, Rugby Union, Netball and Athletics making the top  list.Â You can see the full breakdown of the sports team rankings via the Sports Direct website which includes fan favourites like Cricket and Rowing too.Arsenal - FootballLiverpool- FootballChaÂ - FootballManÂ City - FootballWest HamÂ - FootballCardf Devils - Ice HockeyGloucester - Rugby UnionShaftesbury Barnett Harriers - AthleticsGuildford Flames - Ice HockeyHarlequins - Rugby UnionNorthampton Saints - Rugby UnionSaracens - Rugby UnionTeam Bath Netball - NetballLeicester Tigers - Rugby UnionWoodford Green and Essex Ladies - AthleticsFootball fans can shop for their teams kits and wear strips from some of the countrys biggest teams including Manchester United, Newcastle United, Tottenham Hotspur and more.Meanwhile, Rugby Union fans canÂ sports strips from Wales, England and Scotland by picking one up from the Sports Direct website.

title: penarth art fair set summer
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityThe fair had been cancelled for the past couple of years due to the pandemic, but willin July this year.The event will take place at Penarth Pavilion fromÂ from Friday, July , to Sunday, July .So far, nine local artists, sculptors and galleries have booked stands at the fair, as well asÂ the Queen Street Gallery from Neath.Of those who have booked stands, two are Penarth-based artistsÂ Nia Bennett and Sasha Kingston.Other artists fromÂ Cardf, Ogmore, Pontypridd and Llantwit Major will also be attending.Only three spots are left at the fair, which is being advertised as a good networking opportunity for artists.Michael Goode, the event organiser, said: "I am very pleased with the response from local artists, sculptors and galleries to sell their work directly to the public in the unique setting of the Penarth Pier Pavilion."It means that I now have only three stands available, so please get in touchyou want more information."To find out more information, contactÂ info@inc-creative.wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: last minute tickets cheltenham festival    buy
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityTickets are highly coveted, which can be seen in the fact that they are already sold out for Day Three and Four of the event, with a week still to go before it all kicks off.However, for those still wanting to see some of the action, there are tickets still left for Day One and Two.Heres where you can find them.ONE WEEK TODAY. ğŸ˜®This noise... pic IOaoBCHQZâ€” CheltenhamRacecourseMarch , How to get tickets for Cheltenham Festival Day OneFor Day One tickets are still available for the Best Mate enclosure which offersÂ "an atmosphere like no other" according to the Jockey Club websiteIt has great views for the racing as it isÂ directly opposite the main grandstand and adjacent to the finish line.Prices for the Best Mate enclosure start at Â£ and can be found on the Jockey Club website hereMeanwhile, there is also still some availability for the Tattersalls enclosure, which is a middle point between the club and the Best Mate enclosure.Tickets for this area are priced from Â£ and cane be found on the Jockey Club website hereBefore there was TIGER ROLL, there was BALTHAZAR KING ğŸ‘‘ï¸âƒ£ @Glenfarclas Cross Country winsï¸âƒ£ Cheltenham wins pic NQzXeaIEkâ€” CheltenhamRacecourseMarch , Day TwoTickets are avaiulable for the Best Mate enclosure from Â£ and the Tattersalls enclosure from Â£ on Day Two.Additionally, tickets are also available for the Club enclosure on this day, at a slightly higher cost of Â£ or more.All of these can be found on the Jockey Club website here

title: prizes won event encouraging local spending
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityAlmost  shops in Penarth are taking part inÂ Pay it Forward with a Penarth Fiver from April  until April .Each time shoppers spend Â£ in one of the participating businesses, then they are given a Penarth Fiver.Every Penarth Fiver is a ticket for the prize draw in which lucky shoppers can win one of  gt hampers.The chances of winning a hamper are increased every time a shopper spends Â£ withÂ no limit on entries per person.Angelina Hall, chair of the Penarth Business Group and co-owner of retail gallery and studio Glass by Design said: "When you spend Â£ in a local business itâ€™s worth far more than that to the community."Independent business owners tend to spend with other local traders, so your money circulates within the town with a signicant multiplier effect."Itâ€™s estimated thatevery adult in Penarth spent an extra Â£ a week locally, it would add Â£. million a year to our local economy.":The initiative comes from Penarth Business Forum which is working on maintaining the businesses in the area and promoting local spending.The group have other plans for Penarth, with initiative planned as long awayÂ as Christmas.Forum member Mel Grfin, of award-winning independent bookshop Grfin Books, said: "Weâ€™re already collaborating on a new approach to lighting up Penarth this Christmas, which we hope will bring extra sparkle and magic to the town.Â Watch this space." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: mark drakeford lifting mask wearing restrictions wales
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityMrÂ Drakeford was speaking while defending the news that compulsory mask-wearing in shops and on public transport in Wales will end on Monday - despite cases rising due to a new iant of the virus.During a press conference this lunchtime, Mr Drakeford said that, while people will no longer be legally required to wear masks on public transport or in retail settings from Monday, the Welsh Governments â€˜strong adviceâ€™ would be to continue to wear them.He also confirmed that from the same date, there will be no legal requirement to self-isolate after testing positive for the virus, and issued the same â€˜strong adviceâ€™ that people should do it.He said to help with people continuing to isolate, the Â£ isolation payment for families on low incomes would remain in place until June and that free lateral flow testing for people who think they have symptoms will also remain available.When askednow was the right time to do this considering the increase in cases relating to the BA strain of covid â€“ which Mr Drakeford called â€œmore transmissible than the omicron iantâ€ â€“ the first minister responded that it had previously been planned to end all restrictions in this weeks review, but he and his cabinet felt they were unable to do so due to the increase in cases.He likened the move to other viruses including measles.â€œWe have to manage it like we would other conditions," he said. "If you have measles, you wouldnâ€™t go to work with it. Thatâ€™s not law, itâ€™s what is right.â€He also called on the public to be sensible and use what they have learnt over the past two years. Mr Drakeford said: â€œFor a disease that is moving from being pandemic to endemic, the public response has to move as well.â€œBecause the cases are higher than expected, we are not able to move beyond that place and that is why we have not fully removed the restrictions..removeâ€œPeople are able to do the right thing from their experience of two years of the virus and our strong advice as well.â€MORE NEWS:Mr Drakeford also highlighted how, unlike in Wales, it was never a legal requirement to self-isolate after a positive covid test in Scotland, and yet isolation levels were not reported to be lower compared to other nations.He also urged employers to not force their staff into workthey test positive after the self-isolation period ends.â€œNo employer should put their staff in that position," he said. "They shouldnâ€™t do it for all the public health reasons, but they shouldnâ€™t do it for their business either.â€He continued: â€œIf you force an employee to go in, all that will happen is more people will get infected and then the business will be infected and affected.â€What are the changes From Monday, March , it will not be a legal requirement to wear masks on public transport and in retail settings, although it is still strongly advised.From the same date, it will not be a legal requirement to self-isolate after testing positive, but again it is strongly advised.The Â£ isolation payment for low-income families will continue until June. It is hoped that this will continue furtherit is needed and the funds from the UK government allow.Free lateral flow tests will be available in Wales until around June but it is hoped they will be available longer depending on UK government funding.You must still wear a mask in all health and social care settings unless exempt.Businesses must continue to carry out risk assessments and implement measures to prevent covid spreading as much as possible.Bosses should not force employees who have tested positive for covid to go into work.Teachers, staff and secondary school pupils should wear continue to wear masks for the rest of the term.The next review will take place on Thursday, April . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: queens platinum jubilee flowers create royal garden home
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityAs we head into summer and the weather improves, what better way to markÂ the jubilee than sprucing up your garden.Â This year, the Queen has picked out a special rose to commemorate her th year on the throne.Â There is also a hanging basket on offer from You Garden which is perfect for designing a royal garden. " alt"Penarth Times: The pink roses in the East Terrace Garden at Windsor Castle" class"editor-image"The pink roses in the East Terrace Garden at Windsor Castle This beautulÂ Hybrid Tea Rose has been officially selected by Her Majesty to mark the Platinum Jubilee.The flower comes in a delicate shade of pink and has a sweet fragrance.Â " alt"Penarth Times: The Queen Elizabeth II Rose " class"editor-image"The Queen Elizabeth II RoseÂ£. from the sale of each rose will be donated toÂ The Queen Elizabeth Scholarship Trust.Buy now from You Garden for Â£..Â This patriotic hanging basket includes dainty petunias on trailing stems.It has a vibrant mix of red, white and blue flowers which are quick and easy to maintain.Â " alt"Penarth Times: Union Jack Pre-Planted Basket " class"editor-image"Union Jack Pre-Planted BasketThe flowers come in a cm durable plastic hanging basket and are pre-planted.Â Buy now from You Garden for Â£..Â These petunias come as  multi-sown plug plants in a mixture of red, white and blue, ready to grow on before planting out." alt"Penarth Times: Patriotic Petunia " class"editor-image"Patriotic PetuniaThe colours are perfect for summer and are super easy to plant.Â Buy now from You Garden for Â£..Â

title: penarth basement auction guide price
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityThe basement could be converted into an apartment. Picture: Paul Fosh Auctions"   Watch: Victorian basement up for auction with a guide price of Â£The basement is currently being used for storage. Picture: Paul Fosh Auctions"   Watch: Victorian basement up for auction with a guide price of Â£The current basement layout. Picture: Paul Fosh Auctions"   Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"THE basement of a Victorian building in Stanwell Road, Penarth is up for auction - with a guide price of Â£.The property, located underneathÂ Washington Buildings in the town centre,Â has been put up for sale at Newport-based Paul Fosh Auctions.The auction begins at midday on Tuesday, April  with bidding ending from pm on Thursday, April .Video: Paul Fosh AuctionsSean Roper, of Paul Fosh Auctions, said: "The basement of the eye-catching Victorian-era building could offer scope for all manner of alternative uses, from conversion to an apartment, as an office or for storage, subject to obtaining the relevant planning consents."In Washington Buildings in the heart of Penarth amid a wealth of independent shops and close to the towns railway station, its in an ideal location."The property is listed with a guide price of Â£nil so a bid of few hundred pounds could secure this bargain basement lot in one of south Wales most fashionable towns." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: schools asked teach   hours week
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityThe Schools White Paper, published in full on Monday, will detail how school weeks should runÂ for at least -and-a-half hours, from for example .am to .pm Monday to Friday.While most school weeks across primary and secondary schools in England cover thisof time, the Department for Education said there are some â€œdiscrepanciesâ€ which could see a pupil who receives  minutesâ€™ less teaching time per day lose out on around two weeks of schooling per year.As one of several measures set out in the White Paper, the DfE said the change aimed to build upon the Governmentâ€™s Levelling Up mission for schools, which aims for % of pupils leaving primary school to have reached expected standards in numeracy and literacy.On Tuesday, the long-awaited Special Educational Needs and DisabilityReview will also be published.â€œThe Send and alternative provision green paper will build on education support and change the culture and practice in mainstream schools to be more inclusive, helping the workforce to adapt to every pupilâ€™s needs,â€ the DfE said.The Labour Partyâ€™s shadow education secretary, Bridget Phillipson, said that the proposals amounted to telling most schools to â€œcarry on as normalâ€.She said that after two years of â€œpandemic chaosâ€ the plan would leave parents, teachers and pupils â€œwondering where the ambition for childrenâ€™s futures isâ€.â€œFor almost eight in  schools, the Education Secretaryâ€™s big idea is to carry on as normal,â€ she said.â€œHundreds of thousands of primary children live in an area with no â€˜goodâ€™ schools, the gap in learning between the most and least well-off pupils has widened during Covid, four in  young people leave education without the skills they need and young people are experiencing a mental health crisis. Yet the government has no answers,â€ Ms Phillipson said..removeLabour pointed out that % of schools had days that met the averageof between six hours  minutes and six hours  minutes.Headteachers have also said they are â€œunconvincedâ€ of the benefits of a minimum expectation for theof the school week.Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: â€œWe are unconvinced by the benefits of introducing a minimum expectation on theof the school week of . hours.â€He said that the vast majority of schools already met this expectation or came â€œvery closeâ€ to meeting it, and that it was important to understand the factors that might lead to a shorter week in some schools.â€œFor example, it may be the case in some rural schools that start and finish times are affected by transport arrangements,â€ he said.â€œAdding time on to the school week may sound straightforward, but there are many issues which need to be considered in inidual schools, and we would encourage the government not to rush any changes.â€â€œWe look forward to seeing the full details of the schools white paper and the SEND and alternative provision green paper,â€ he added.And Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leadersâ€™ union NAHT, said: â€œWe hope that during the year before these proposals are implemented, there can be a review of the evidence supporting this plan.â€â€œSimply adding five or ten minutes to a day is unlikely to bring much,any, benefit. The government says it will be guided by evidence â€“ they need to meet that undertaking,â€ he said.Kevin Courtney, joint general secretary of the NEU teaching union, said that the education sector was â€œcrying outâ€ for a Schools White Paper and Send Green Paper that addressed â€œthe huge challenges that battered and bruised schools face to support all their pupils during and beyond a pandemicâ€.â€œThe expectation of a . hour week for pupils is a classic example of Government trying to hit a target but missing the point,â€ he said.â€œThe vast majority of schoolsâ€™ days are of thisor a little more or less. We are looking for much more sophisticated change.â€â€œWhere is the multaceted recovery plan  What should happen in the extra - mins some pupils will now spend in school  How will pupil wellbeing and education staff workloads be improved to ensure their time together is as impactful as both want and deserve â€ he added.â€œChildren, parents and those that teach and support them need more from a government policy  than easy headlines like this.â€Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said: â€œEvery child deserves support from excellent teachers, who in turn deserve to be backed by a supportive and inclusive school, whether they live in Doncaster or Dartmouth, whether they plan to study T-levels or A-levels, whatever their background.â€œOver my time as Education Secretary, my guiding focus has been creating opportunity for all, with strong schools and great teachers for every child. Every plan and policy I will set out in next weekâ€™s Schools White Paper works towards this goal.â€œThe Schools White Paper, closely followed by the Send Green Paper, will demonstrate levelling up in action, delivering fairness for every child and making sure nobody is left behind.â€.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Schools asked to teach for . hours a week or more article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: joe biden calls regime change moscow likens invasion ww horrors
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityâ€œFor Godâ€™s sake this man cannot remain in power,â€ the US president said, apparently calling for regime change in Moscow at the end of a speech from Poland on Saturday.He said â€œ youâ€™re able to listen: you, the Russian people, are not our enemyâ€ before evoking the Naziâ€™s siege of Leningrad and likening it to the atrocities in Ukraine.â€œThese are not the actions of a great nation,â€ Mr Biden said, in front of the Royal Castle, a landmark in Warsaw that was badly damaged during Adolf Hitlerâ€™s war.â€œOf all people, you the Russian people, as well as all people across Europe still have the memory of being in a similar situation in the s and s, the situation of World War Two, still fresh in the mind of many grandparents in the region.â€â€œWhatever your generation experienced, whether it experienced the siege of Leningrad, or heard about it from your parents and grandparents, train stations overflowing with terried families fleeing their homes, nights sheltering in basements and cellars, mornings sting through the rubble in your home â€“ these are not memories of the past â€“ not any more, itâ€™s exactly what the Russian army is doing in Ukraine right now.â€Multiple rockets struck the western Ukrainian city of Lviv near the Polish border during Mr Bidenâ€™s visit, which came as Russia faced the prospect of further setbacks in the war.The US president said Moscowâ€™s troops have â€œmet their match with brave and stf Ukrainian resistanceâ€ and have strengthened the resolve and unity of both the defending forces and the West.â€œRussia wanted less of a Nato presence on his border but now he has a stronger presence, a larger presence,â€ he said. vw,vw,px, px"US president Joe Biden delivers a speech at the Royal Castle in Warsaw .removeMr Biden said , Russians had left their country in a single month in a â€œremarkable brain drainâ€ as Mr Putin, who he earlier called a â€œbutcherâ€, had â€œstrangled democracyâ€.Addressing the thousand-strong audience that included refugees who have fled the war, he told Ukrainians â€œwe stand with you â€“ periodâ€ as he defended the nationâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelensky.â€œPutin has the gall to say heâ€™s denazying Ukraine. Itâ€™s a lie, itâ€™s just cynical â€“ he knows that,â€ Mr Biden said.â€œAnd itâ€™s also obscene. President Zelensky was democratically elected, heâ€™s Jewish, his fatherâ€™s family was wiped out in the Nazi holocaust and Putin has the audacity â€“ like all autocrats before him â€“ to believe that might will make right.â€The brave Ukrainian resistance is a front in a larger fight: for the essential democratic principles that unite all free people.These principles are essential for a free society, but have always been embattled.Every generation has had to defeat democracyâ€™s mortal foes.â€” President BidenMarch , But as he made an impassioned defence of democracy, he reminded European nations they must end â€œdependence on Russian fossil fuelsâ€.Sanctions, he said, have been sapping Russiaâ€™s strength and have reduced the rouble â€œto rubbleâ€.But Mr Biden warned: â€œThis battle will not be won in days, or months either. We need to steel ourselves for the long fight ahead.â€Despite clearly calling for Mr Putin to go at the end of his speech, a White House official tried to argue that the US Presidentâ€™s point was that the Russian leader â€œcannot be allowed to exercise power over his neighbours or the regionâ€.â€œHe was not discussing Putinâ€™s power in Russia, or regime change,â€ the official added, before reports in the US suggested the remarks in question had not been scripted.Unwise comment:Itâ€™s for the Russian people to draw thisconclusion.Putin  Xiwill now read â€˜regime changeâ€™ as POTUSâ€™ wider objective â€“ beyond supporting Ukraine.Putin will spin this, dig in and fight harder. pic GEbcAaLâ€” Tobias Ellwood MPMarch , Tobias Ellwood, the Conservative MP who chairs the Commons Defence Committee, said Mr Bidenâ€™s comment was â€œunwiseâ€.He warned the Russian president will now see regime change as Mr Bidenâ€™s wider objective, adding: â€œPutin will spin this, dig in and fight harder.â€Mr Biden stopped at RAF Mildenhall, a base in Suffolk that supports US military operations, on his way back to Washington so that his Air Force One jet could refuel.Moscow has given an indication it could scale back its offensive to focus on what it claimed was the â€œmain goal, liberation of Donbasâ€, the region bordering Russia in the east of Ukraine.Mr Zelenskyâ€™s forces were regaining ground around the capital of Kyiv and the UK Ministry of Defencesaid Russians are â€œproving reluctant to engage in large scale urban infantry operationsâ€.Instead, the MoD said, they were preferring the â€œindiscriminate use of air and artillery bombardments in an attempt to demoralise defending forcesâ€. vw,vw,px, px"A Ukrainian soldier on top of his APC on the front line position near Kharkiv, Ukraine However, there were fresh signs it was Mr Putinâ€™s troops who were struggling with morale, as Western intelligence suggested a Russian brigade commander, Colonel Medvechek, was deliberately run down and possibly killed by his own troops.An adviser to the Ukrainian ministry of defence, Markian Lubkivskyi, predicted troops could on Saturday take back Kherson, the first major city that the Kremlinâ€™s forces seized.He was sceptical that the Russian Presidentâ€™s aims had truly changed away from trying to take the whole nation, but said it does appear â€œthe enemy is focused on the eastern part of Ukraineâ€.The port city Kherson, in the south east, fell to the Russians early this month in their first major gain.But Mr Lubkivskyi told BBC Radio â€™s Today programme: â€œI believe that today the city will be fully under the control of Ukrainian armed forces.â€œWe have finished in the last two days the operation in the Kyiv region so other armed forces are now focused on the southern part trying to get free Kherson and some other Ukrainian cities.â€.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Joe Biden calls for regime title: russian sanctions lifted invading forces withdrawn truss says
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityThe Foreign Secretary said in an interview published on Sunday that the threat of â€œsnapback sanctionsâ€ would be retainedthe Russian president did attack again.Ms Truss told the Sundaythat a â€œnegotiations unitâ€ had been established in the Foreign Office to aid possible peace talks.With the Kremlinâ€™s troops struggling, her comments will be seen as a possible incentive for Mr Putin to cut his losses and broker a deal with Ukraine.Moscow has given indications after a month of war that it might scale back its ambitions to fight for control of the Donbas region in the east of Ukraine.But Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky warned he would not give up territory in peace talks as he noted that his troops have delivered â€œpowerful blowsâ€ to invading forces.Boris Johnson said that western allies are looking to â€œsteadily ratchet upâ€ the sanctions that have sought to punish Mr Putin and those who prop up his regime.Ms Truss said: â€œThose sanctions should only come off with a full ceasefire and withdrawal, but also commitments that there will be no further aggression.â€œAnd also, thereâ€™s the opportunity to have snapback sanctionsthere is further aggression in future. That is a real lever that I think can be used.â€Her remarks fit with those of her US counterpart Antony Blinken, who has said the travel bans and asset freezes are â€œnot designed to be permanentâ€.The secretary of state said the sanctions could â€œgo awayâ€ in the event of an â€œin effect, irreversibleâ€ withdrawal of Russian troops..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Russian sanctions could be lted after invading forces withdrawn, Truss says article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: no six nations today   find round  begins watch
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communitySimply put, the players need a rest. Weeks three and five are typically break weeks during the championship to give the teams times to recuperate.If you are desperate to see how Round  will play out though, you donâ€™t have long to wait. Games will resume next weekendWales Alex Cuthbert tackles Scotlands Stuart McInally during the Guinness Six Nations match at the Principality Stadium, Cardf. Picture: PA BT Murrayfield, EdinburghSaturday, February .pmFollowing last weeks defeat to Wales, Stuart McInally insists Scotland remain in the Guinness Six Nations title hunt.Scotland had beaten England seven days earlier and next week meet France â€“ the only unbeaten side in the Championship after two rounds â€“ at Murrayfield.Edinburgh hooker McInally said: â€œThe initial feeling after a loss is devastation and disappointment, you want to deliver for the group and for the people of Scotland.â€œItâ€™s disappointing, but the Championshipâ€™s still wide open.â€œWeâ€™ve got France at home next and weâ€™ll go into that full of belief. Weâ€™ve had some good results over them recently and we canâ€™t wait to move on.â€How to watch: Scotland v France will be shown live on BBC One or youÂ can catch up via BBC iPlayer.England v WalesCourtney Lawes has completed histo play protocols and comes into contention to face Wales next week. Picture: PA Twickenham Stadium, LondonSaturday, February .pmCourtney Lawes has resumed full training in time to reinforce the middle phase of Englandâ€™s Guinness Six Nations title push.Lawes was unable to play in the opening two rounds of the tournament because of concussion but has now completed histo play protocols and comes into contention to face Wales next Saturday.Defence coach, Anthony Seibold, said: "Courtney trained fully today , which is obviously really good news for himself and England. He looked sharp.".removeMeanwhile, Wasps flanker Jack Willis is set to make his first appearance in a year after finally recovering from the serious knee injury sustained against Italy at Twickenham in the  championship.New Wales flanker Jac Morgan admits playing at Twickenham next week would be special given the historic rugby rivalry between England and Wales.Morgan won his first cap on Saturday as reigning Six Nations champions Wales bounced back from a Dublin drubbing against Ireland to beat Scotland - in Cardf.The Welsh-speaking Ospreys openside says he was so nervous before kick-off that he almost forgot the words of the national anthem â€˜Hen Wlad Fy Nhadauâ€™.â€œItâ€™s always a dream to play for your country from a young age,â€ said the -year-old.â€œGrowing up England is one of the biggest games with the rivalry between the two countries over the years.â€œEverybody knows how big the game is with the history between the two sides."Morgan produced an impressive debut display last weekend, as Wales revived their Six Nations title hopes before heading to Twickenham next Saturday.How to watch: England v Wales will be shown live on ITV or on SC or youÂ can catch up via the ITV Hub.Johnny Sexton expected to be fit for Irelandâ€™s clash with Italy. Picture: PA Aviva Stadium, DublinSunday, February pmIreland head coach Andy Farrell expects captain Johnny Sexton to be fit for next weekendâ€™s clash with Italy after losing Ronan Kelleher for the remainder of the Guinness Six Nations.Fly-half Sexton missed last Saturdayâ€™s - defeat away to France because of a hamstring injury but has ed to training with the squad during a two-day camp in Dublin.Asked for an update on Sexton, Farrell replied: â€œAll good. Heâ€™s going through his protocols.â€œHe joined in training yesterday, heâ€™s worked through the end stages of rehab and we expect him to be fully fit next week.â€Ireland centre Robbie Henshaw also insists he feels fresh and focused as he attempts to force his way back into Andy Farrellâ€™s starting XV for the remainder of the Guinness Six Nations.â€œItâ€™s been a bit of a rocky one for me this year,â€ said Henshaw, who came off the bench for Ireland in last weekendâ€™s - loss to France.â€œI feel fresh, to be honest, so Iâ€™m ready to go, ready to step forward now.â€How to watch: Ireland v ItalyÂ will be shown live on ITV or youÂ can catch up via the ITV Hub. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience â€“ the local communityThe fierce rivals both have title ambitions but neither team can afford any further slip-ups at Twickenham.The competition might only be at the halfway point, but it will effectively be game over for whichever team loses.Both countries lost their opening matches â€“ England being defeated by Scotland and Wales suffering an emphatic reversal in Ireland â€“ but then put themselves back on track with respective victories over Italy and Scotland.After finishing fth in last seasonâ€™s tournament, England know they must kick on towards tough assignments next month against Ireland and France, while Walesâ€™ continued hopes of a successful title defence hinge on the outcome at Twickenham â€“ a ground where they have not claimed a Six Nations win since .Weâ€™re here for those unforgettable moments. There were a further , lab-confirmed cases of coronavirus in the UK as of am on Saturday, taking the overall number to ,. A further  deaths were recorded.The number of coronavirus cases in Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon increased by  in the last  hours, official figures show.A total of , cases had been confirmed in Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon when the UK coronavirus daily dashboard was updated on March  , up from , on Thursday. He was .       " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,."
