Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.An RAF Association, which included serving Wg Cdr Jacqueline Rankin, and led by Carrickfergus RAFA chairman, Wg Cdr Noel Williams, paid tribute after the service, during which the Rev Paul Clarke delivered the eulogy, the RAF Association Ode was read and the Last Post was played by the British Legion Bugler. David and Joan Moffatt on their wedding day in .Danny Kinahan, the Veterans Commissioner, also attended the funeral.David Moffatt was born in Belfast on February , . He was the son of David Samuel and AmyMoffatt. His father had served with the Royal Irish Constabulary and the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Their house in Woodvale Drive was badly damaged during the Blitz of , necessitating the family live with a relative at Dundonald before moving to a permanent home at Loopland Road.David was educated at Everton Elementary School on the Crumlin Road. On leaving school, he became an apprentice with the shipbuilding firm of Harland and Wolff, Belfast, where he spent the next four years. He was also a member of the Crown Boxing Club, Belfast.Air Marshal Reynolds chatting with -year-old Lancaster Bomber Rear Gunner David Moffatt at a Battle of Britain act of remembrance in Carrickfergus.He enlisted in the RAF in February  and after initial training, he qualied as an Air Gunner at No  Gunnery School on the Isle of Man.Posted to  Squadron Bomber Command on August  , he undertook his first raid on August  against Russelheim in Germany.Several operations against Le Havre and Calais in support of Army operations followed in August and September interspersed with further action over Germany. From September  onwards he operated mostly against German targets including in the Baltic, disrupting U-boat training.Towards the end of his  sortie tour he took part in raids on oil production facilities at Scholven Buer and Merseberg-Leuna. He flew his last sortie on December   over Scholven-Buer in the Ruhr Valley. He flew with a typically Commonwealth crew. His pilot was a New Zealander and his fellow gunner was a Canadian.David, who earned the - Star, the France and Germany Star and the War Medal, left the RAF in April .He went on to become a dog handler with the politan Police, serving for  years and earning the Police Medal. His working le later included a period as chief security officer for an electronics firm.He had met Joan who was a WAAF while serving with No  Squadron. They were married on April ,  in Whitton, Middlesex. They were married for  years and received a message from the Queen on their th anniversary. Joan died in  after a battle with cancer at the age of . David, a keen golfer, decided to leave Lanzarote, where the couple had been living, andto Northern Ireland. Residing in Carrickfergus, David was a familiar face at Wings Appeal stalls and other fundraising initiatives organised by the RAFA branch.In a an earlier tribute, Wg Cdr Williams said: â€œHe will be sadly missed by his family, RAF Association colleagues, and by the public who would have seen him at the many Wings Appeal stalls throughout the town as he raised funds for the welfare of other veterans.â€The Carrick RAFA branch chairman added that Mr Moffatt was the â€œbeloved husband of the late Joan, father of Carol and the late Raymond, a devoted father, grandfather and great-grandfather and uncle.â€Warrant Officer Moffattâ€™s funeral service was followed by a private family committal in Roselawn Crematorium, Belfast.Read More Read MoreSpitfire flypast and presentation after Battle of Britain service in CarrickCarrickfergusBelfast  "       "   for the newsletterKeep up with the latest news and views from NorthernIrelandWorldSign Up       " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,." Having dedicated her entire le to public service it is fitting that we mark this momentous anniversary as an expression of both our gratitude and congratulations., Councillor Michelle-Knight McQuillanand Jamie Austin " "" width"" srcset"https:www.northernirelandworld webimg TUFZMTMNTkMDIz.jpg width w, https:www.northernirelandworld webimg TUFZMTMNTkMDIz.jpg width w" layout"intrinsic" class"i-amphtml-layout-intrinsic i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"intrinsic", Councillor Michelle-Knight McQuillanand Jamie Austin " fallback layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"Pictured at the launch of Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Councilâ€™s Platinum Jubilee Programme are the Mayor, Councillor Richard Holmes, with Julie Welsh , Councillor Michelle-Knight McQuillanand Jamie Austin â€œParticipation and engagement is at the heart of our Jubilee programme and to support this, we set up a Small Grants scheme to extend our celebrations in to the wider community where a range of local initiatives will take place to bring people together. Itâ€™s my hope that the spirit associated with jubilees of the past can be rekindled as neighbours, families and friends make new connections in  inspired by this very special year.â€Alderman Michelle Knight McQuillan, Chair of Councilâ€™s Jubilee Working Group added: â€œI am delighted to introduce Councilâ€™s Jubilee programme which is our way of reflecting on HM The Queenâ€™s remarkable -year-reign. This is a unique occasion, and we have developed a mix of engaging initiatives for everyone to get involved with.â€œThroughout the year weâ€™ll have special civic mementoes for newborn babies, centenarians and couples marking  years of marriage. Weâ€™ll be taking part in the Queenâ€™s Green Canopy by creating new native woodland spaces which will enhance the natural environment and developing a new heritage trail to delve deeper into the areaâ€™s Royal Connections. â€œThereâ€™s lot more taking place so please visit our website for full details about what we have planned and how you can play a part.â€œOther upcoming highlights include the bestowing of the Freedom of the Borough on the RAF, an event for recipients of the Queenâ€™s Award for Voluntary Service, the Northern Ireland International Air Show in Portrush, primary schoolsâ€™ athletics championships and intergenerational opportunities connecting nursery pupils with our older residents who attended previous Royal visits to the Borough.â€Full details about the programme are available to view now by going to www.causewaycoastandglens.gov.uk platinumjubileeRead more: Causeway CoastGlens Borough CouncilMayor  "       "   for the newsletterKeep up with the latest news and views from NorthernIrelandWorldSign Up       " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,." title: recommendation for post primary pupils to wear facemasks to be scrapped after easter
story: It will no longer be recommended that post-primary pupils wear a face covering in corridors or confined communal areas following the Easter break. This will result in post-primary pupils no longer being recommended to wear a face covering on school premises. The news was confirmed by Education Minister Michelle McIlveen.She said, As was the case with the change relating to the use of face coverings in classrooms, this further change takes place in the context of a broadly improving epidemiological landscape in schools. Nonetheless, COVID continues to circulate in our communities and in our schools and we should continue to reduce the risks of COVID in our schools through the range of other mitigating measures that remain in place to protect all pupils and staff.  It is for this reason thatany inidual wishes to continue to use a face covering anywhere at school, I would encourage them to do so. At this point pupils will still be recommended to wear a face covering when using public or school transport. This position will be kept under review.  A guidance note will issue to schools on this issue later today and my Departmentâ€™s COVID guidance will be updated to reflect this position.  addthis,     Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High
